Early Access Review

Today I decided to go raptor hunting.

After 15 minutes of cruising the skies in my Pteranodon, I finally located a raptor.

So I jumped off my bird, and tried to tame the raptor by shooting tranquilizer arrows at it, resulting in it being mad, and me regretting my decision to go raptor hunting.

I was too busy running to notice how big this specific cliff was, so as I leapt gracefully off it, I soon realised that this was a bad idea.

---- 20 seconds later ----

Respawned at my home, walked out the door, and got eaten by a raptor 2 meters from my house.



12/10 - would go raptor hunting again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1: We start building a hut. Raptor kills us.

2: Naked, ran back to base, died naked.

3: We gather resources before going back to base. Sneak up on raptor. Died again. It is now a raptor with spears in its side. We just gave it confidence.

4: We train a turtle dino. Name him 'Bait'. Send him in. We finally kill raptor.

5: We now have our hut back.

6: The hut wasn't in a good spot. Bait carries our stuff to a new spot. Thanks, Bait. No hard feelings?

This is a great survival game that requires planning, tough decisions, and solid progression. Both PVP and PVE offer challenge and extended playability. 13.5 hours in, and we're only getting started. The devs are some of the best in the business and are worthy of your dollars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi There!

I've put around 450 hours into ARK: Survival Evolved which, compared to many reviews, isn't a huge amount. In this time, however, I've played on both PVP and PVE servers and had a go at hosting a server of my own.

When I first bought ARK I quit the game after 2 minutes and didn't return to it for months. My PC isn't a beast, but it plays all the games I own at a decent Frames Per Second with good settings. I was absolutely astounded, however, when I could barely hit 10 FPS on the lowest of settings. It was completely unplayable and a great deal of the community had the same problem. A few months later and the developers have patched and updated the game so much that, with a few 'launch parameters', I can play this game at around 50 FPS with good settings. This game IS demanding, but I would think negatively towards anyone who doesn't recommend this game based on it's performance. It's come along way already - think how much further it can be optimised!

But most people know about the performance issues and if YOU didn't know about them before this, I suggest you read into it on the forums etc. to make sure you'll be happy with the game you purchase. Now that the boring stuff is out of the way, let's talk about the gameplay!

The first server I joined was an Official PVP server. This means that the gather rate, XP gain, taming speed etc. was all at standard speed (x1). If you're new to the game, or you've only played on x1 servers this may not seem that bad, but trust me, it gets VERY tedious, VERY quickly. You could end up having to babysit an unconscious T-Rex for hours upon hours while it tames, only for it to get killed in a raid or PVP fight in minutes. If you have the time and patience, then please be my guest.

Now, if all the servers had these settings and the modding community wasn't as great as it is, I would have probably never played this game again. Instead, you can find a plethora of servers packed with mods and custom settings that, in my opinion, REALLY bring the game to life! Some servers are a little bit silly, being about to tame an extremely high level Bronto in 2 mins for example, but if that's your cup of tea, don't let anyone stop you!

The aforementioned mods are numerous and varied, ranging from new content such as advanced machinery, to level changing scripts that make wild dinos stronger and even total coversion mods that change the whole game so you're either a pirate or stuck permanently in 'cave-man mode'.

I for one, will never be able to go back to a vanilla (un-modded) server with x1 settings. It's too much of a chore. If you're hesitant about wether you'll be able to put up with it too, check the Steam Workshop and you'll see what I mean. Check YouTube too. There are many famous youtubers with daily episodes.

I purposely have avoided detailed descriptions of things you can do in this game because I think it's more fun to explore them yourself. Besides, there are many reviews with that kind of info already.

I hope this review helped at least some what!

-XCAL

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a single mounted saber tooth destroyed my tribes house and all of our belongings, I decided it was time to head out and be a nomad. Fully expecting to die on this journey, I didn't pay attention to where I was going, but took off. The first night consisted of making myself some armor and tools. After crafting a spear and collecting all the meet I could carry, I was off. The first day was a roller coster of emotions and close calls as I roamed the island from supply drop to supply drop. With each new loot box, I became more powerful and cautiously optimistic that this would work out. I found myself well armed and starving atop a mountain with a few parachutes I had just collected.
I did the only logical thing and dove off the mountain, soaring across a ravine and past brontosaurs like a scene from jurassic park. I landed next to another supply drop, and to my surprise, found the makings of a decent wooden house.
With the ability to make a small abode, I decided traveling alone had gotten lonely, so i used my bow and tranq arrows to take down a small dilo, that would be named Mr. Spitter. Life was good, we traveled together and became close friends. Mr. Spitter had my back and I had his, but all of my gear had gotten too heavy, and the little dilo couldn't help much. It was time for a mount.
The only mount of choice for a wander in this game is the raptor, its speed and lethality make it a perfect traveling companion. with some time and hunting, I brought down a raptor and tamed it slowly. So slowly, im fact, that I got Mr. Spitter a mate, and hunted with them while my raptor was tamed. I returned to the raptor just before he became a loyal companion to place my new forged saddle on him and rode off into the sun.
Usually this would be the happy ending, but in all survivor games like this one, there is no happy ending. Either you quit while you're content, or you live long enough to see everything taken from you. My new family and i traveled together until I found a supply drop under water. With the loot pulling me forward like a moth to a flame, I dove in the river and my trusty companions followed me in. Little did I know what lurked beneath the surface. Piranha swarmed us and devoured Mr. Spitter alive before I could even react. I pulled out my spear just in time for my second dilo to die. I couldn't let Speedy, my raptor, suffer the same fate. In a flurry of thrusts, I managed to save Speedy by a hair. The loot that laid inside contained the remaining pieces i needed for a house.
Filled with sorrow, I decided it was time to head home and rebuild a base for my tribe, but I soon realized I was lost. Speedy and I roamed for hours searching for landmarks to guide us home. I finally found the path home and eagerly followed the beach along the river to where I could rest for the night. Speedy was tired from running, and we were both to the limits of what we could bare to carry. I decided to give speedy a break and jump off, just to luckily find a stegosaraus egg. I thought it would be nice to return to the tribe with another dinosaur that we could all hatch and train together. I didn't notice the two large dinodaurs who were watching the egg closely, and didn't appreciate a stranger taking their young. THey were on me before I could draw my weapon. I had over encumbered myself, and Speedy counldn't move. I died slowly trying to drop the egg, and received the final blow as i attemted to join speedy to make my get away. As I lay dying on the beach, I watched as Speedy was slowly beaten to death by two enemies he should have never met.
My wishful thinking turned to greed, and lead to dispair. I awoke at the shambles of our base, naked and alone, with nothing left to show for my time on the island.
Honestly a great game if you enjoy a true survival format and I highly recomend it to anyone willing to put the time in to get the rewards they want.

10/10 game

Serious Review

Ok this game is straight up one of the best survival games out there as of right now. This game is a survival game with a twist, it has dinosaurs along with other extinct animals. This game actually reignited my interest in dinosaurs from when i was a little kid. If you want the best experience for this game, i would advise you to play on PVE servers or a private server with friends.

Ark's Pro's

This game has great dev's, They update the game at least twice a week, and push out new content at least once a week. So as of right now, this game will not be getting stale for the people who play alot for a very long time.  ARK has REALLY beautiful graphics.This game also features a huge open world enviornment along with a day/night cycle and temperature. There is also a little bit of endgame content which includes taking down tough creatures and collecting artifacts which is found in dangerous caves to summon the final boss. ARK is capable of supporting mods for the people who love creating modifications.

Ark's Con's

The game is still pretty poorly optimized so don't be suprised when your game runs at half the frames you are used to. Official PVP servers are normally plauged by really big PVP tribes that will raid you the chance they get to. This will not affect you if you play on PVE or private servers. Official servers are pretty unstable as of right now. But by far the worst con in my opinion is the taming system. Taming some creatures can take as long as 10 hours or even longer. I really think they need to cut the taming time down a lot. But thankfully you dont exactly have to stand over them the whole time, you can do other things while you are taming a creature. But if you want to avoid long taming times, join some unofficial servers that provides faster taming times.

Overall, This game has much better pro's than con's. You can fix most con's by just joining the right servers. The dev's are really helpful and updates very often so you shouldnt have to worry about bugs in the game that much. I will give this game a thumbs up and recommend this game to people who love survival games. And if you love dinosaurs, you should buy this game now as it is the best dinosaur game out there in my opinion.

TL;DR (Too long, didn't read)

Pro
- Great Graphics
- Consistent Updates
- Open world With Day/Night cycle and Temperature
- End game content
- Supports Mods
- Dinosaurs

Con's
- Poorly Optimized at the moment
- Official PVP servers are normally ruled by a single large tribe that will kill you on sight
- Long Taming times
- Official servers lag alot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy Dilo, what a game!

I tamed a dodo. It died on the way back thanks to some dilos.
I tamed a parasaur. It died on the way back at the claws of some dilos.
I tamed a dilo. It killed everything on the way back to my house.

I made a mistake and set its behaviour to 'aggressive'...it started attacking a giant turtle. I tried to stop it! I tried all the whistle buttons, but nothing worked. I discovered that way that you can use Z to defecate.

So I watched my lovely Lana (that was her name) getting ripped apart while crapping my pants.

The graphics are good, but the performance issues are huge (as of 6/6/2015). Even high-end machines can't run it with steady 60fps.

My laptop has a i7-4700HQ and a GTX780m, and with medium settings I get 8-17 fps. I didn't have the chance yet to test it on my desktop PC with SLI, though I heard it doesn't suppoert SLI (yet, hopefully).

I certainly can recommend it. It is Early Access, keep it in mind, so bugs, bad performance et alteri can be expected. But from what I have seen, the devs are really invested in their game, lots of updates, good communication so far....I have high hopes for this game.

Maybe I will update this review at a later point when my 980TIs have been shipped, to see if you can kinda brute-force the performance of the game.

Early Access Review

TL;DR : great game but has performances and finishing touchs to be made,

i write this after just above 1050 hours played,
in those 1050 hours i've expirienced
* starting with nothing and dying over and over again to learn the game
* starting with stuff and becoming a great power in a server
* getting a decent and normal server being overrun by a chinese tribe
* starting over , and over, and over
* convering a public official server in to a somewhat of a democracy with a website and stats and element of control

The good :
the survival aspects of the game are great up to around level 60 its probably the best survival expirience game out there currently, (after level 60 you are a bit OP and only die to self stupidity)
the 'things to do' are virtually endless (i didnt feel like i ran out of things to accomplish even after 1000 hours)
the graphics is stunning
the base building and 'tribe wars' and overall community aspect of the game is great
the resource gathering is nicely balanced , very hard at start, grindy at mid, and once you  min max with dinos and what not its great even as a solo player
there are planty of items in the game and types of dinos
The Bad :
the lag, the lag is real, rubber banding is a plague and really hurts the game expirience, i know there is limited ability to do something about that, even more so on official servers, but still, thats the core expirience of the game
the fps, as someone with a bit of above avrg computer (3960x, 980x2, 32gb ram, ssd and so on) i get 30fps at points and fps is very jumpy, expected from an early access game, but stating this for the record
overall i've had a great time with this game and i've stoped playing it mostly coz i ran out of time irl to play a high demanding game like that,

keep up the good work developers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game caught my interest months ago, and I was watching it since then. I've been very cautious about survival games after the past few I tried have all let me down, bigtime. I usually shy away from PvP in games, so naturally I was hesitant to play this one. A few weeks ago, I received it as a gift from my significant other, and finally gave it a shot.

First of all, what worried me the most about this game, was the many many stories I read about joining and being instantly ganked, being killed in their sleep, being griefed, trolled, and every other horrible PvP thing that can possibly happen. So far I just have not experienced this. Maybe I have just been very lucky....but so far I have not yet ran into someone who instantly tried to kill me. Everyone has been friendly, saying hello on voice, offering supplies, and I even met a tribe leader that took me into the tribe to teach me the basics. I just have not seen the toxicity that some other reviews talk about. But again, maybe I just got lucky.

The game is beautiful. A screenshotter's paradise. It is graphics intensive but Im able to play on high without many issues (I get short freezes when I enter a new biome while flying, that's about it). There are also frequent latency issues on the official servers.

Content is added all the time. It seems like every few days there is a new dino being added, and there are pretty much daily updates. I saw many negative reviews that say the devs don't care"
date: but I am not sure where that idea came from. Maybe I'm missing something
recommended:
but they seem quite passionate about the game to me.

For me the game is very addictive. It is HARD for me to get "sucked into" a game on Steam. I usually play for about 12 hours and then move on. But so far in Ark I'm at 60 hours and usually log off still wanting to play more.

There are some small things that bug me
hoursPlayed: and they are kinda silly things...mainly the artistic freedom the devs use on the dinos. I know they said they aren't going for total accuracy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game Details

Published by:  Studio Wildcard
Developed by: Studio Wildcard ,Instinct Games ,Efecto Studios ,Virtual Basement
Genre:  Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
Release Date: 2 June, 2015
Completionist Gameplay: 100+

Let’s start this review off with the most talked about issue surrounding the game: its performance. While there is a very comprehensive menu with lots of settings you’d never have thought to create in regards to the visual settings, even with a blend of medium to low settings I seem to max out on 15 frames per second with a few random glitches. While it is playable and no where near as bad as it was when it first came out, it isn’t ideal. If your system can somehow run the higher settings, then the game is incredibly beautiful and you’re going to want to take hundreds of screenshots.

Before you start to play, you’ll have the option of creating your survivalist. You are presented with sliders for head, torso, leg, foot and arm widths, lengths and heights. You can change the colour of your survivalist’s hair and eyes, though you can’t really see your eyes anyway and the hair colours are kind of dull. You unfortunately only have one hairstyle, and I’m hoping that once the game leaves Early Access it will have several options to choose from. Honestly, the best part about the sliders overall is that you can have different character heights from all the other players around you, something that not even The Sims 4 has managed to accomplish.

As you wake up in the world of Ark, you notice the many HUD indicators for survival purposes. Some of these include stamina, food, water, health, oxygen and your level progress. Watching and being aware of these is the most important thing that you can do in this game. If you have too low stamina, you won’t be able to run away from the raptor that is chasing you. If you have too low water or food, your screen will start to become clouded with the same red effect we’re all used too in survival games.
These indicators can also be affected by the weather. Severe heat can damage your health, and running through a humid rainforest will take a higher toll on your stamina and hydration levels. A handy feature is being able to drink rain straight from the sky for when you’ve died and lost your waterskin or are too far away from a river, pond or the ocean.

Crafting is a huge component in Ark. If you’re familiar with Rust, the crafting system in Ark is somewhat similar. As you level up, you gain engrams that can be used to unlock blueprints. Blueprints ten levels ahead of you will be hidden, encouraging you to continue to level up to find out what they are. This system also encourages a lot of planning, forward thinking and just plain luck, as you can’t unlock all of the engrams at the same time.

Last but not least, the one major feature that distinguishes Ark from the many other survival games out on the market; the dinosaurs. Able to be tamed and ridden, a source of food and a way to make the resource gathering faster, they are a vital component of the game. As you learn which dinosaurs are dangerous and which are not, you gain confidence with your ability to survive in the land of Ark. Taming dinosaurs is an adrenaline-filled process that requires a lot of teamwork, but the payoff is worth it when you put a saddle on your first T-Rex and stomp off into the sunset. In a major case of art imitating life I accidentally seemed to have exterminated the entire dodo population at one point during my playtime as they were the only non-dangerous sources of meat in the game. Thankfully, it doesn’t take too long for dinosaurs to respawn and when they do they tend to respawn in the same places. This can either make your game raptor-filled hell if you accidentally build your base too close to their spawn points on the island, or very easy, if you build your base on one of the southern islands that no carnivores inhabit.

Overall Verdict
While the performance of this game is lacking and a few key survival concepts of the game haven’t been re-imaged from the other survival games out there, Ark: Survival Evolved is a very fun game that will fulfill your childhood dreams of having a pet Tyrannosaurus Rex, even if you lose everything and your tribe in the process.

If you'd like to read more reviews from me, join my steam group!

The game itself is still a great game, the developers have bought everything they said they will, it's developing and growing. But my concerns were some of the people on the servers and the amount of time needed in order to accomplish anything decent.

PLEASE READ: The main issue is how easily you can lose things. You could spend hours and hours getting a metal base and tame a very high level dino and all of that could be taken away from you during the time you went downstairs to eat your dinner.

IMPORTANT: I have played this game since day 1 on release. I have seen how it's developed from the very start and that is why I mention later on how I think it got worse. I did love the game from the start but there were certain things that ruined it for me.

One thing I also need to address is that PVE isn't interesting, yeah sure you can get everything but there is no challenge or exploration involved as you will never stumble across other people. PVE might be fun for you but it definitely isn't for me, it would get boring, quickly.

PVP/PVE : If they implemented something such as PVE/P where you shouldn't attack other tribes or do damage to anything they own unless you declare war on them and both sides agree to it. But, if one side doesn't agree and the other attacks them anyway they should be punished pretty hard about it. Not sure how, but there should be something involved.
That seems a little more fair in my opinion, I understand how the game works, PVP speaks for itself...right? But there is also a part of actual fair play, if a massive tribe attacks me for the sh**'s and giggles when I own 2 little dinos and have a small stone base then that is pretty boring and un-necessary. If 2 huge tribes have a serious war, that would be cool as hell and would bring so much more to the game, the PVP potential would be much better and enjoyable if you actually wanted to participate in a battle with someone.

PLEASE NOTE: This review might help someone that simply wants to find out about ARK, I believe I clear up points such as time consuption, possible dissapointment and the possible opportunities for fun that I have had and many people also can. Also if they want to look at the positives of the game they can simply click the tab directly next to this one that states 'Positive'.
to read all the good things it has to offer. This review isn't a definite answer on what the game is like, as after all my problems couldn't mean anything to you and you might enjoy the game regardless of whatever other people say.

Anyone that would like to recommend private servers to me or other players, go ahead but some people don't like private servers including me. I do not like how easy things are, things are given way to easily and too quick. Ark servers are too slow and private ones are too fast. So far there is no balance that is just right" in my opinion. I guess that's why the game is still early access so they can change that in the future. Please bare in mind that some people prefer to tame a dino in half an hour and have a large stone base after an hour of gameplay and some do geniuanly like the fact that things take a long time.
Everyone has their own preference.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I watched this game (EA) release with caution – early access has almost become a synonym for ‘take your money and leave you with a rubbish product’ but after watching a lot of streams/gameplay footage and looking into the game I took a chance. This game has lived up to all of my hopes and far surpassed some – easily worth the money and STRONGLY recommended to anyone interested in the genre as a whole.


NEGATIVE REVIEWS:
It is unfortunate that this game has such a solid portion of negative reviews. A strong majority of the negative reviews are complaining that it is unoptimised (as to be expected in early access) and that when they play on low the game doesn’t look good compared to the trailers. I have a decent computer admittedly but I can run on ultra quite playable (scale back to high + to be smoother though) and it looks just as good as the trailer so the graphics are there, the optimisation is coming. The devs are incredibly active and the game is regularly patched in relation to not only preplanned elements but bugs and community suggestions.

Feel free to have a look at my screenshots if you want to see what it looks like at higher (but not full) settings.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/346110/discussions/0/615086038675991453/


The main issues I have experienced is the dino pathing once tamed can be a little rough, especially once you start getting more and more dinos. On more than one occasion our little hunting party of 3-5 Dilos ends up missing one who is later found with its head in a rock somewhere. Far from game breaking but something to be worked on a bit.

The control of tamed dinos can be a little clumsy (Using whistles to follow/stop works well but changing aggression requires you to go up face to face and cycle through a menu) and it would be great if you could assign groups - if a hunting party of 5 dinos is in the same area as someone else from your tribe with other followers, you manually have to tell each of them to stop - using the 'stop all' whistle will stop all the dinos in the tribe, not just the ones you have following. Note this is quite handy as it allows tribe wide dino control (which has come in VERY handy) but an additional grouping option with 'follow/stop my group' would make things much easier.
An option to remotely set dino aggression stance would also be a godsend - In a tribe where we have 20-30 tamed dinos, changing all aggression stances is a task in itself.


GAMEPLAY:
As far as gameplay, there is very little I could say against it. The game premise is great, content is through the roof. The levelling mechanic I feel works quite well and gives a small sense of purpose that you build your own experience around. It also allows you to customise your character to fulfil the role you wish to play.

It is probably best to watch a few videos on taming and other core mechanics so you don’t waste your time as some things in this game do require a large commitment. Overall I think taming works well but do note that taming large dinos is a massive effort... A small Dilo may take 10-20 minutes to tame but once you start going bigger, it starts hurting. Larger herbivores (Trike, stego etc) take over an hour. Our T Rex took 3ish hours and our Bronto took a whopping 4.5 hours to tame (During which time you manage a two progress meters and defend from anyone/thing that comes by). While it is painful it does ensure that the apex animals are the prized possessions they should be.


Content wise... I have played a fair bit and haven’t even scratched the surface. We have a small tribe and have built up a bit of a base, tamed a Rex and a Bronto as well as a menagerie of other dinos but still haven’t cleared through more than one small island on the map.

One thing that I am noticing now our base is expanding is the permanent impact you can have. When we first started our shack on the beach we were on the edge of a forest - Now the mountain is cleared and as we have built there it isn’t growing back. Very interesting sense of permanent change.

While we are comfortable in our little area, we still have yet to go into caves, the main mountains or deep underwater. I am currently sitting on 38 hours - The amount of time it would take to 'finish' all the content is staggering and more is coming.



PVE/PVP:
While I normally stay right away from pure PVP (survival) games, this one makes it work.

There are still a few of the sociopaths that seem to be everywhere online these days but overall it works quite well. I think the strong PVE backbone (ie. Dinos are bloody dangerous) tones the DayZ effect down a bit and makes for quite a good dynamic. There is still a deep distrust and caution applied when meeting other random people but it is far from a KOS-fest, indeed you will often find yourself cooperating while your interests align. (My tribe has been formed from me and one mate recruiting other stragglers)

PVE works great and levelling makes you far from indestructible (even low level Dilos can be an issue if your weapon is broken or you are taken by surprise without support). I have not seen the ‘endgame’ bosses (Super large creatures you summon with materials found on the largest and most dangerous animals on the Ark) but if you are into the MMO raiding style approach, that is there for you too.


SUMMARY:
The beauty of this game though is you can make your own story - Having a tribe is great as it allows you to get larger scale things done (eg. building an expansive and well defended base) but I have equally enjoyed running around solo or with one other on hunting trips, operating out of small temporary outposts. The modding potential of this game is promised to be significant as the devs are giving access to their own editor for creation of mods Originally posted by  The Right Hand:You will have access day 1 to our entirely functional 100% exactly the same as ours custom copy of the Unreal 4 Editor including all of our assets and everything else about the game to do whatever you want with. Anything you can dream of. Mod away.This means that you can almost guarantee there will be a niche for everyone (have a look at Arma mods...) and will make the game playable (and even expanded) for many, many years to come.

Early access is a bit of a minefield but over the space of the last few days with this game, I have had more enjoyment than I have with the vast majority of my other games and it has well and truly been worth the outlay.


Have a look at the trailer and a few vids - if your interest is piqued, it is worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played PVE this entire time, since beginning of August. It's now end of April. Not really interested in PVP. The game is made for PVP and PVE is quite the afterthought.

I've played this game many hours so far, so you may be wondering how I can give a negative review and recommend that you not buy this game. I'll explain.

This game requires so much time that literally, you pretty much can't play this game the way it's intended and be employed at the same time. It's just a fact and most will agree. The game is designed by the developers to hook you and devour you. You have to work excessively hard with long hours to tame dinosaurs and breed them. For example, if you don't tame with kibble and just berries, you have to literally sit there for 10 hours and monitor a high level mammoth until it's tamed. Breeding dinosaurs is even worse. A baby giga requires 28 hours straight of handfeeding before it can reach the juvenile stage. Think about that. 28 hrs at your computer hand feeding and waiting. Does that sound like a game" to you or a second life? What's worse is there is no salary for all that hard work. If you're all down for spending innumberable hours of your life toiling away and that's your only challenge
recommended: then yay for you. Get this game.\n\nI wanted to quit 500 hours ago but my tribe keeps asking me to stay and help them. So I stay and it's not fun. Three quarters of the time I'm in this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK! Before I give my 2 cent I would like to say this.

IF YOU ARE EXPECTING A SMOOTH RELEASE WITH NO HITCHES STOP READING AND DON'T BUY THE GAME RIGHT NOW!!!

I'm tired of these people thinking that they can play a finished project when the project is not finished or refined and then complaining about it. This is an early access game.

That being said the game has a lot of potential and from the few mins I've played I found it pretty fun. Though getting everything off the bat kind of took away from the experience. Thank you devs I do love the fact you're giving me gifts but I think I can manage.

Optimization is needed big time, but I know that will come in due course but untill then I'm fine at the med setting I have it on right now with my GTX 770.

If you're expecting a game that was shown in the trailers but you don't have a hefty GPU like most of the negative reviewers, Just wait and don't bother buying. But if you can look past that and want to play an unfinished build that they have so far like me. Go for it!

EDIT: 06/03/2015

My Current PC Specs:

CPU: i7-4790 3.60GHz
GPU: GTX 770 4GB
RAM: 16GB
OS: Windows 7

So after an hour or so I found a sweet spot with my graphics card and it's running at a decent 25-30 FPS with max Textures running at 1920 x 1080. draw distance is low and various setting set from low to med. Taken screen shots to prove it.

I know I don't have a super high end PC but mine is better than most. that being said after several hours of gameplay I can say it's a real fun game to play. there's a lot of room to improve and yes the otimazation still needs work (but then again it's just been a day). The graphics are quite nice even though I don't have them set to high and it runs nicely on my rig (So if you have anything close to my specs I believe you will get similar results you just have to fiddle a bit).

So I still keep my initial stand on it. This is an early access game so expect bugs and what nots and I still recommend this game for those willing to look over the obvious bugs. I do however not recommend this game to those running lower then a Nvidia 7xx series card or equivalent unless there is someone out there with something lower that can testify it works well on their rig.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I clocked 3000+ hours on ARK of which I actually played around 2200 hours (rest was afk time). Of those 2200 hours I have played estimated 400 hours on an unofficial server and the rest on official servers in EU (mostly PvPvE, a little bit PVE and PVP hardcore). I really loved ARK, but this love is dying slowly for the last two months.

Many will ask now why somebody who played so many hours would NOT recommend buying ARK. There are several reasons:

1. Recent changes to the strength of tamed dinosaurs
2. Implementation of a totally overpowered dino named Giganotosaurus
3. Ridiculuosly long lags for more than 4 months now
4. Flawed physics
5. Lack of communication with community

In more Detail:

1. With patch 231 Wildcard nerfed the attributes of tamed animals. The problem is the scale in which they did it and the fact that most players were satisfied with the state tamed animals were in and saw no reason for changing that. Wildcard went overboard and lowered attributes like hitpoints and damage by up to 80 percent, rendering many tamed animals useless. This is very annoying for players who had many high-level perfect tamed and leveled animals. Animals which were used to farm metal, stone, wood etc. now have a much much lower yield than before. This has as a consequence that getting resources for crafting now becomes a nuisance.

If Wildcard would have nerfed tamed animals only by 20 percent instead of the actual 80 percent, animals would have been weaker but still usefull and players might have accepted that. But nerfing them by 80 percent is a affront to many players.

2. Back when Wildcard implemented the alpha dinos (raptor, carno, rex) they said that they wouldn't be tamable because this would impact the balance of the game to much. But only two months later they implemented the Giganotosaurus which is far worse than an alpha dino and made it tamable. And to make things worse they gave it the ability to destroy stone structures. Since then it was used hundreds of times by alpha tribes to destroy potential competitors before they even could upgrade their bases to metal. This shifted balance even more towards large and already powerful tribes and hasn't been addressed by Wildcard yet.

3. For more than 4 months now there have been so called 'megalags', intermittend lags up to 15 seconds, often happening every 1 or 2 minutes. On servers with lower count of structures (buildings) lags are less prolonged as on servers with a high count of structures. Wildcard explained those lags with problems with the so called garbage collection and stated already three times in past patchnotes, that they improved the garbage collection. But because of no effect on lags at all (!) I think this were just lies. Additionally there are severe and frequent drops of the framerate while travelling across the island. This issue was also explained by Wildcard and also allegedly 'improved' without any noticable effect.

4. Temperatures of minus 20 degrees Celsius underwater show that Wildcard devs cut school a little too often. Other things are little animals pushing much larger animals back while attacking them, no bullet drop with sniper rifles, but severe drop with other weapons like rpg launcher, building structures floating in the air after destruction of foundations and so on.

5. At first Wildcard communicated quite well with the community, but lately they push hotfixes without any notification, they push back patches without giving information or giving it hours late and they are giving statements to problems like Giganotosaurus and the actual balancing fail only because they feel pressure from the community. They act more and more like politicians and not like the 'cool dudes' they were in the beginning.


I won't conceal the fact that there are many nice things in this game, but at this moment I cannot recommend anyone buying this game due to the problems I described before. I recommend waiting several months and searching for actual information then.

I most likely will pause playing ARK untill this balancing patch is reversed and other problems mentioned are solved too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game so far.

The Good:
Looks nice.
Dinosaurs are fun.
Server controls everything, so it's hard to cheat.
Flying, diving, cave exploration, bosses to summon and fight.
Large crafting tree with loads to work your way toward.
Emphasis on teamwork, sharing, and trusting within a Tribe.

The Bad:
Buggy
Runs badly on older GPUs, but it's already gotten much better.
Can have problems connecting or loading the game, AKA Buggy.(A patch released post review seems to have solved this problem for everyone I know, including myself)
Official servers are constantly packed and hard to get into.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The game is already better in many ways than Rust, which has been in development for much longer. If you can get past the bugs while they develop the game, it is worth every penny of $25. If you don't have a GPU equal or better than a r7 260x or maybe GTX 750 Ti, I'd give it at least a month or more to be optimized. Otherwise you may be playing at a really low frame rate. They have already improved it quite a bit for a lot of people though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit : 10 June, 8 Days Since Launch
I honestly cannot recommend the game AT THIS STATE. I fully understand it is a EARLY ACCESS GAME, This doesn't change the fact that i don't reccommend it at this state.

I have a firm belief this game will be fantastic in the future but, unless you wish to let the current state of the game deter from the experience of the full release i'd advise you to hold off on purchasing the game until a further date.

Pros:
+ Amazing Sandbox Experience
+ MASSIVE AMOUNT OF CONTENT (Quite suprised the game launched into early access with such a large amount of content)
+ Building System is fairly standard and not lacking in any way
+ Nice RPG-like elements to the game. (Leveling is awesome)
There are a bunch of more Pros but i'd advise you to experience them for yourself at a later date
+ The developers are insane with their work ethic, An update gets released almost hourly!

Cons:
- Poor optimization (Feel as if i don't need to beat the dead horse on this one; Laggy, regardless of specs)
- Bugs
- I initially percieved the hunger system to be ridiculous, after spending more time playing the game the more i approve of it, however i do not like not having a place to store food so that they can be preserved longer

It would seem that the pros outweight the cons, why is this review is still a 'not recommended'? Because i don't want the poor optimisation to deter from the maximum possible experience you can achieve when the game has been patched and is running at it's best.

I have without a doubt, 100% certainty that this game will be fixed in time, but until then save your money :) (Unless ofcourse you must buy the game, i won't blame you, i did the same ;) )

EDIT: Some people don't understand. Steam gives you one of two options, 'Recommended', that is to essentially say 'Hey you! You should buy this game now' and the other option being 'Not Recommended' which is to say 'Hey you! you shouldn't buy this game now'.

If this was a proper review rather than steams review" system review i would give the game high marks for being a great in-depth survival game and beating out it's genre competitors
date: But this is not a proper review system. I don't recommend buying this game yet
recommended: however i most likely will later in the future.\n\nThe day this review turns to a 'Recommended' grows closer and closer with each patch"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this review I have played for just about 900 hours
ARK: Survival Evolved has become one of my favorite games and easily the best survival game I’ve ever played. Most of the time when you invest in early access you’re gambling on a game that can reach full potential or be forgotten by the devs as they make a break for it with your money. ARK is the first early access game that I’ve personally played that doesn’t feel like early access. It’s got a lot more content than most finished games. The developers are usually always coming up with new content to keep the game fresh and the base game is fantastic while only getting better (most of the time anyway). There’s a few big issues with the current state of the game, but I’m willing to give the devs the benefit of the doubt that they will try to balance it out before launch.

Pros:
-Hundreds of hours play time either by yourself or with a friend. For $29.99 this game has lasted me much longer than almost every full priced $60.00 game I’ve purchased in the past 10 years.
-Many different dinosaur species to tame and more on the way
-Beautiful world that has great map design. Everything feels hand crafted.
-Building a base feels more like building a home rather than a hole to hide in until PVP
-Dinosaurs control well and you’ll really develop strong bonds with your tames (including incredible sadness if they die)
-Graphics are beautiful (if you can run them) and help immerse you into the well-designed world
-Forming a tribe can lead to fantastic friendships
-PVP is incredibly tense and when played well you can get into seriously intense action
-Very rewarding but difficult learning curve

Cons:
-At times the game can feel like a chore. Lots of grinding and some taming can take more than 3 hours
-Very unbalanced PVP that can really turn most people off
-Kibble that can shorten tames are being implemented poorly (EG late game dinosaur eggs required for mid-early game dinosaurs)
-Giganotosaurus completely broken (turned off in my private server)
-Needs better optimization

All in all ARK is a fantastic game. If you’re even mildly curious about it give it a shot. It’s been a game that has consumed all of my time and I love every minute of it.
I highly suggest staying away from official servers and try to find a nice unofficial one. They usually have better tame times and active admins can remove problem players fast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: Confused - go for a swim - get eaten by a shark
Day 2: Still confused - pick up resources and build base and learn the game
Day 3 : Try to tame a phiomia - run out of berries and patience 0 abandon idea and proceed to hunt dodos
Day 4: Try to tame a dilo - friend kills said dilo
Day 4 continued: Try to tame second dilo - scorpion falls from the sky and knocks me out - friend kills scorpion - dilo appears and attempts to eat me - said friend tries to defend my unconscious body only to stab me in the head and kill me and the dilo in one hit
Day 5: Attempt to tame trike - trike bumps me into canyon where carno is picking daisies - Carno proceeds to make me his lunch date
Day 6 : Tame a Dodo....


10/10 would bring said friend again

Update : So here's my take after 200 hrs of playing this game - Yeah it's buggy at times, the dino pathing on certain dinos is slightly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but then early access you can't complain  that much :)
My oppinion is based on PVE and some PVP every now and then for fun.

PVE - Besides building a base to defend your tamed dinos, yourself and tribemates, exploring the caves and wilflife - Most servers have a pretty friendly community from what I've seen and encountered - People are usually quick to help you when taming, locating lost dinos - in my case our server actually has a Lost/Found list on reddit - people post coordinates and help eachother out - Plus a little birdy told me PVE may get tribe wars (only if mutual as far as I know) so if you did want some PVP at some stage I suppose the option is there. (not entirely sure on that as to be fair I haven't checked so don't quote me there)

PVP - There's a massive rage fest over offline raiding .. and I'm not going to get into it much but let me asks you this : Do you think that in war people should wait for you to be awake to attack your base? If you answered yes then this game is not for you!
You may argue that if you were asleep you would wake from the noise of your walls being broken through -(let's be honest it is after all a video game right?)
You didn't see any of the losing parties of wars screaming about how spineless, unfair things are ... war isn't fair?  I'll leave it at that seeing as PVP isn't really why I'm playing anyway - Feel free to browse the forums and read and make up your mind on that end.

So should you play this game? From a PVE stand point - Hell YES!?! - Who doesn't want a pet Trex to torment little dodos or scare your friends,tribemates or others you can catch off guard with a roar that blows minds?

PS : Smile :)

Here we go again.

10/10 would praise Supreme God of Ark again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is so much good stuff in this game from the graphics to the atmopshere and at times I feel as though I'm working towards having lots of fun but eventually I realize ultimately the philosophy of the game means the game will never have any real depth.  A great survival game should let the players create the fun instead of the game trying to make the fun for you. In Ark there is no point in talking to other tribes and battling with other tribes doesn't even exist really. There are no tactical battles, just curbstomps by the team with who builds ugly giant metal structures and tames the same 2-3 dinos over and over again. Essentially whoever gets on the server first and invests 100+ hours can build an indestructable base made of metal guarded by plant turrets and then scout the map once every few days to make sure no rival bases are in contruction that could ever build anything that could damage them. Normally all the powerful tribes ally and the saddest thing is watching new player after new player join a server, spend about 20 hours on that server and then leave once they realize a tribe or tribes have build foundations all over an area of the map so no one else can build there and the noobs have to inhabbit useless areas.

The problem really is a balance issue.  As a middle player at level 60 with a few dinos I can raid a lower player and destroy everything they have done in seconds and if they wanted to fight me or even damage one of my walls it would take them hours upon hours. The same could be said if I was to go up against a high player. He could destroy me and all my dinos without much effort yet if I attacked him I would have to spend hours upon hours to destroy just one turret. People that invest time playing and are high levels can have an advantage sure but not to this extremist extent that it just defeats the purpose of playing.

As I said in the beginning the problem is the games philosophy. Once a tribe becomes powerful on a server they nearly never fall and the dynamic remains the same pretty much forever. A free-to-play and very basic game by the name of Unturned gets this concept right where ARK fails. In Unturned in the course of a week many teams rise, have their time as #1, then they fall, etc. I'm pretty sure in the space of an entire servers existence the same Alpha tribe remains Alpha always in ARK even when outnumbed just because they got on first and can manipulate the bugs in the game such as building pillars/foundations all over 66% of the map.

I understand this game is in Beta but the reason I'm giving a negative review is because the developers seem more interested in wowing its audience with new dinosaurs and items all the time instead of fixing the game mechanics required for a dynamic experience. I have Zero respect for developers who go for style over substance and ARK is very much style over substance. Everyone says it: You HAVE to play on a private server (this should be a strong message to developers STOP releasing more dinos and FIX the game dynamic). You have to play on a private server if you want to have fun and have all the tribes starting from the same place but good luck finding one without an abusive admin or one that will just go down making all your hard work pointless.

Overall: Great Game Concept, Enjoyable at times, Super Addicting but a bad execution and philosophy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Out hunting with my friends, when I saw something in the trees. It was bright red, like fire, and looked to be glowing.

It only took a moment for me to realize what it was and report it to my friends.

Now, one of us, he'd played the game for longer, he was the most experienced, and he said we couldn't tolerate that. An alpha was too much of a threat to allow near our base. He was going to hunt it down, and needed some volunteers. I wanted to go, even though it was pretty dangerous, and we were on a hardcore server. I'd never had a fight with an alpha before, thought it'd be cool.

So, we got together our squad of tamed dinos. 11 dilos, and a raptor named Jesus, and went out searching. I led the way, as I was the one who'd spotted it originally. Odd thing, though. When we showed up, nothing was there. No alpha, no normal dino, not even a dodo. The area was devoid of all animal life. We shrugged our shoulders, figured we'd missed her. Couldn't be too hard to track her down, though, right?

Clever girl.

We turn around to leave, and an alpha raptor jumps out of seemingly nowhere. How she managed to stay hidden when she's glowing, I've no idea. I saw her kill one of our dilos and Jesus before she pretty much oneshotted me.

I lost all my stuff and levels, but you know what? I'm not even mad. It was awesome way to die. A+, would accidentally lead friends into trap again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everything is better with dinosaurs right? Here you'll find it out!Note: This game is still in early access. There might be many changes throughout the development.
Hint: At the end of this review you will find a TL;DR section.

----------------------------------------------------------------

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
It seems to be the best idea in the genre of survival games. A Rust-like game with RPG elements and the best of all: tameable dinosaurs. Who didn't ever dream as a kid to have a T-Rex or Carnotaurus as a pet? The dream will finally come true with ARK - Survival Evolved".

The start is very familiar for those who are used to survival games. You're stranded on an island with nothing but your panties on you. A strange artefact is implemented in your arm and the world is filled with wild and dangerous creatures; dinosaurs. Like in every other survival game you have to start as a gatherer and hunter with the goal to build up some walls to find cover against the harsh nature
date: the dinosaurs and probably against other gatherers.\nBit by bit you farm everything you need and will be able to build your first own shelter. The time has come to discover the island
recommended:
farm more specific ressources and collect supplies at the so-called ARKs. They're findable everywhere on the island and glow in different colors. You'll find out what they mean in time.

Back to the more important or probably most interesting part of ARK: taming dinosaurs. You need to knock them out - even the biggest of all. Either with your bare hands or - if you're more advanced - with tranquil arrows. Every dinosaur has his own favorite food that will make the tameprocess easier and a lot faster. Till now the tameprocess is very time wasting. Some dinosaurs like a high level T-Rex still need hours for taming. But in the end it will be worth the time you put in - many dinosaurs are real farming monsters. E.g. a mammoth will turn a forest into a warfield in seconds and rewards you with more wood and berries than you're able to carry around. Every tamed dinosaur is able to level up which allows you to assign statpoints.

Don't throw the berries your mammoth farmed away. With some berries
hoursPlayed: coal and water you might get some dye out of it. Paint your walls
voteText: your roof and your floor - not enough? Try the dye on armor and even your tools.\n\nBut every golden coin has a not so shiny side. As I mentioned before
helpfulPercent: the taming and also the farming process takes a lot of time. Casual players won't have fun or won't see so much progress as other hardcore gamers will.\nThe community is surprisingly friendly but even here are black sheeps. They're called offline raiders. They wait for you to go offline and will steal your hard farmed ressources in notime. Without a tribe
votesHelpful: a proper base made out of stone or metal and in advanced time turrets
votesTotal: you won't keep your stuff for long.\n\nThe graphics are stunning. The island and all now available dinosaurs are made with the love for detail.  But for this you have to have a even better PC. Stuttering
votesFunny: server or PC sided
commentsCount: in the current development state is not unusual. Anyways
column16:
bugs here and there - like dinosaurs glitching through walls or stuck in another- are not game breaking anymore. You'll find everytime a way out of the missery.

One thing I have to mention in the end: Nearly every day the game gets updated and developers reveal information about new dinosaurs. You may get a unfinished project now but the chance that it will be a finished game in a year is really high.


●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
If bugs in the game won't bug you

I was a little leary about getting this game and I don't normally get to many Early Access games, however after reading some of the other reviews I completely agree with the ones stating the bad reviews came from people being very impatient at launch of the early access with the launches issues. These guys patched through the important items quick fast and in a hurry. Awesome Job and a good sign for things in the future. Now for a quick pro and con.

Pro
*So far everything seen in the trailer I have been able to do.
*Tons of content right off the bat with more to come.
*Crafting system took me a whole of about 5 minutes to figure out and the only thing missing was rocks.
I spawned of the eastern beach which had very few but patch notes say they fixed it.
*Tribes

Con
*Ninja raptors
*Lost the items I got for buying early access in 1 minute as people were waiting nearby to kill newbies. Not the games fault so not really a con but it would be nice if the special skins we got were permenant like an engram you could learn and then craft an existing item into.

EDIT*
SO about 200+ hours later than this review I still love playing this game. These guys keep coming out with more content and the craziest pace I have ever seen. Do you people even sleep??? Devs listen to the community and put forth a concerted effort to attempt to prevent hacking and cheating even offering money for those types of software to be reported. They also listen to most suggestions such as dinos that gather fiber and even the scythe. Man we were hurting for some way to farm that fiber and now it's almost to easy. Keep up the good work and I definitely feel like I got more than I paid for from you guys.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The world of ARK is a harsh unforgiving one. It punishes you extremely harshly for any mistake, which may have been as simple as “I needed to drink so I did, which meant I didn’t see the 3 raptors behind a bush who are now enjoying a little midday snack”.

Sometimes It made me want to put down the game and cry in the corner, which happened when my first tamed dinosaur “Kevin” was tragically killed by a giant scorpion! The game has some nice touches though which allowed me to erect a gravestone in his memory.
RIP Kevin.

Despite all this danger and misery, there is something that takes the sting off and indeed is what I feel makes this game. Actually surviving!  Sure, you’re gonna die a dozen or so times before you finally work out how it all fits together, but once you learn to be cautious, learn which creatures to hunt and (usually) which ones to run from as fast as you’re little human legs can go, learn what things you really need and build and setup that first camp, the game makes you feel a real sense achievement.

Despite all the danger lurking around every corner (or above you in the sky or below you in the water), despite the hardships you must go through to gather those resources, you have done it. You are Bear Grylls.
But Bear Grylls alone couldn’t defend his friendly dino mount and camp from a rampaging T-Rex!
But he could if that other great survivalist, Ray Mears, was in the area!

Which is where this game really comes into it’s own.  Working together with your friends and forming a tribe is where the real enjoyment for me happens. That’s why it’s an MMO and is why I play the game.

The servers currently allow 70 players on at a time which helps to prevent overcrowding which would certainly ruin the feel of the game. It also works well as I rarely see any maxed out servers.

Each server is also a new start for all players. So if you join a friend (in my case brother) who’s been playing ark for a while, if you both jump onto a new server you will both wakeup in loin cloths on a beach and have to etch out a living from scratch. To me this helped me to not overly rely on my brother as he was just as vulnerable as I am and also meant he wasn’t slowing down his gameplay to help set me up in the game.

And working together allows you to travel further, explore dangerous places and take down huge creatures. Alone it’s not impossible, but together it works and feels better.

Meeting other players is also an interesting (and sometimes nerve racking) experience. Wondering along and suddenly 3 guys riding T-Rexs emerge from the trees! Do I run? Will they perhaps trade? Offer my lowly character free gear to help me survive? Point me in the direction of new wonders and resources? Or will they just kill me and take my stuff? So far, all of these things have happened to me, and I enjoyed it all (even my murder by thieves).

All in all, ARK is a fantastic gaming environment full of possibilities and adventures with plenty of danger! There’s the odd bug and having the option to switch between 1st and 3rd person would be nice along with other minor gripes. But these things can be fixed and other things may change, it’s not at full release after all.

For now, my tribe and I are happy to roam the world of ARK, trying to go beyond surviving and build a lasting civilisation! Or maybe just a dry hut. And with more content to come and the many mods being created by the community, I can see myself playing this game for a long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The launch was a little shaky because people couldn't find games to join and the singleplayer options weren't available, but now that I've played ~3 in game days I can say this is probably the best survival crafting game I have played. And I've played a lot of them. It's like Rust with better pacing and more content. I would recommend 7daystodie over this if you're a zombie fan (7daystodie has farming, crafting, voxel terrain for mining, etc). It's without a doubt the best open world zombie game. This game is the best game to play if you like survival & extreme wildlife. It's got dinosaurs and dodo birds!

Pros
-incredible graphics
-runs smoothly on a laptop with a recent card (mine is nvidia 860m)
-full and actually well implemented gamepad support (optional but enjoyable)
-progression is fun without taking too long
-using different tools on different resources lets you target specific resources
-tamable animals and dinosaurs (can be used for attacking, defense and can be mounted)
-spear fishing! (beware giant sharks)
-Some dinosaurs are a threat but you can easily outrun them if you're not ready to fight
-leveling system to improve your character and learn new recipes
-mods
-offline local play!!!!!!!!
-characters can move between servers and local play (special locations in game to do this)
-you poop
-you can poop on command (worthy of separate mention)

Cons
-It isn't optimized so if you want to play maxed out graphics even a beast desktop will have trouble
-KOS is better than other games but bad if you're traveling with important things & tamed animals (people may kill them)
-if you die, you have a pretty short time to reclaim your stuff before your body decomposes
-a little difficult to navigate, you can't tell where you are on a map
-food spoils fast
-early game is tough with water because early water containers leak over time
-you need to be completely submerged in water to drink it (be careful in murky water - lots of crocs and scorpions!)

Moot
-KOS can be disable - PVE servers
-Mods are allowed and will improve the game in any and every way you desire
-food is easy to obtain so spoiling isn't really an issue except when taming dinosaurs
-if you have a waterskin (or other container), you can fill it and drink it while being only ankle deep in water


There are a few flaws related to performance that will be handled with optimization, but it's hard to make legitimate complaints about design choices and mechanics because those will be changeable with mods. It's a lot of fun and it's difficult to play without making progress. I had a rough start looking for rocks and couldn't find any for a whole game day, but I kept moving and found some a little far from shore. Great game, would definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An incredibly fun survival game with lots to do! Well worth the price tag even in early access form.

Negatives
- Not very well optimised although 40-60fps is possible on most decent gfx cards

Positives
- Great progression system
- Lots of items to build/craft
- Awesome looking water
- Dinos are a fun addition that adds another layer to survival
- Realtively balanced with constant updates
- Great private server options and a single player mode
- Incredible amount of content and depth for a recently released early access game

I haven't had this much fun on a survival game since the early DayZ of DayZ mod and possibly Arma 2 Overpoch. the building and menu system isn't quite as polished as Rust but for me the format of the game and depth puts it miles ahead of Rust for enjoyment. It's very addictive and there's a long grind but it rarely becomes tedious, especially with a group of friends.

Overall pretty much as good as it gets for an early access survival game. I had alot of expectations for the game and although early performance issues were off-putting once you get under the hood there's alot of fun to be had!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't mind my hours, I've played this in offline mode VIA local hosting.

The game is great, dinosaurs feel legit, lively; little bit wonky but a few minor patches here and there will fix them
I feel like this game was rushed, putting too much effort into in-game content but how can anyone experience those in-game content if they can't even get in-game?

Terrible optimisation, good lord; I mean I know GTA 5 was delayed.... But it was WELL worth the wait considering the amount of effort into optimisation, regardless. The game is absolutely gorgeous, if you live long enough to see the rest of the island without being ripped apart by a raptor.

The customization seems funny, reign of kings-esque type feel; I haven't dug deep into the combat system as of yet, but I'll update the review when I do, as of now it feels a little hit or miss and swing like crazy, I don't see any parry/block button.

I do however enjoy the leveling system, feels like a survival MMO's putting points into different skills, I can imagine like having a colony of people with each different skills, I.E Blacksmith, gatherer, hunter; ECT.

It has its ups and downs, I do think the raptor spawns should be removed from the coast, as it gives new spawns hard time trying to gather things in the beginning, maybe move them towards the middle of the island?

PRO'S+
+Awesome graphics
+Detailed world and players
+Character Customization
+DINOS
+PVP (Personal PRO)
+DODO BIRDS
+Hundreds of hours worth to explore
+Taming DINOS

CON'S-
-Horrible Optimisation (Hoped to be patched)
-Hit or miss Combat system
-Small bugs such as terrain missing
-Raptors spawn in new spawn areas (Personal CON)

Pretty much it boils down to Optimisation, if that was fixed I'd recommened this game 10/10
But sadly they worked on content, rather than the core itself

I'll stick a landing at 9/10, fix the Optimisation and bam got a 10, great game I see a lot of potiental and I really want to see this in development! worth the buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is regarding gameplay/genre expectations for ARK: Survival Evolved. It does not cover; graphics, content, Survival of the Fittest, or other already covered aspects of other reviews.
Ark: Survival Evolved is not for the faint of heart or the short sighted. As a survival  genre game at it's core, it requires a large level of logistical skills in order to see maximum results. If you don't like the idea of losing progress, survival games aren't for you. If you like the idea of out-thinking the system, and learning to be a better player within your provided environment, then you'll likely excell in this game.

Ark is a dangerous world. Many people take for granted the civillian life they live. As an example, in this player's opinion; dIno pens with roofs is a must. Building roofless pens must be done high enough so that large monsters can't walk over, or reach in. But roofless pens still allow flying creatures to get in, or enemy players if on PvP.
Travelling with all your best stuff all the time is a great way to make sure that every wipe (death without corpse recovery) is the worst it can be. Instead, travelling with equipment you can replace easily might be more advantageous until a player is more familiar with their surroundings.
Many players think I'm being attacked
recommended: run home!". Then they lose their house to dino attack. Dieing and respawning and saving your house and it's contents is way more beneficial. Sometimes it's impossible to avoid aggro(aggression from an attacker) on your house

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of June sixth, the devs have released a patch that really fixed a lot of the optimization issues.  I have put over thirty hours into the game in two days.  I'd be playing it right now-- but I'm currenty at a place where the net's just not that great so I have to wait. (Unfortunately, might I add.)  That being said; a review.

The game is, to put it frankly, fun.  It's pretty.  Animations are GENERALLY great.  The AI for the dinosaurs could use some tweaking-- I'd like to see the specific species given a little more flavor that's more for them and the supposed personalities they'll have once the game's fully released; but that's in due time!  So far I feel as though the devs have earned every penny I spent on this game.  It can be challenging going solo, however.  There's an actual sense of progression to the game-- you don't want to run into raptors before you're ready for them.  Though once you're in leather armor you'll be able to go fisticuff with the lower leveled ones to tame them.

There's a few cons to the game, naturally.  I don't personally enjoy the Sleeping" players being in game upon logout-- though I can see why it's a thing.  Personal preference.  Dinosaurs sometimes keep their momentum when you kill them
date: causing them to artifact or slide or fly away.  Your body can randomly die when logged out. (Either a bug or I logged out outside of my house and froze to death.) There were

Early Access Review

Update Oct 5; Chinese hackers have taken over the official server I played on most and have wiped nearly everyone.

Update Nov 3;
TL;DR: Hackers are rampant, devs have done nothing and they censor anything and everything they can get their hands on regarding hackers.

Hackers are still a problem. And by that I mean the original hackers that have taken over the server are still there! Never been banned or even investigated. Any attempt to bring them to the attention of the developers is met with silence when using the appropriate e-mail report procedure, and when that fails and any attempts made to contact the devs through the forumns the threads are locked and deleted (and before anyone says anything, the threads were polite and constructive all the way through to. The reviews are literally the only place where talk about hackers aren't instantly censored since they don't have any control over it.



Original review below

This game would be amazing if we lived in a world where people don't want to ruin the game for other people. Game mechanics and concept and is fun to play, and the devs are great with adding content regularly, however fairly incompetant with everything else.

The game is a griefers paradise. Hackers run rampant, game breaking mechanic exploits are left unchanged with half ♥♥♥♥♥ attempts at stopping it that don't actually address the issue (On both PvP and PvE servers). I've seen people harassed off of servers, then followed to other servers and harassed there as well until they quit the game all together and the devs will not intervene.

Solo games are tedious and boring with no real objective, goal or focus so the best bet is to try and find a good private server but honestly I'd say just don't bother.

P.S. Read the whole review before you comment -.-

P.P.S Yes, I am reviewing the experience of the game and giving it a bad rating. Not sure about everyone else but I prefer for reviews to be relevent to whether or not the game will be enjoyable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start off, I wouldn't say this is a bad game, but I would say it's definitely not a game for everyone. The main reason I made this a negative review is simply because I don't find it fun, and that's the reason we play games is it not?

To start off, this game features and incredible amount of grinding in the form of resource gathering and it takes a very long time to actually get anything, and when you finally do get to some kind of goal you usually just get screwed over and lose everything anyway...I feel this game just doesn't reward the player for their time and effort that they put in - which can be a lot, I might add. Don't get me wrong I'm no stranger to grindy games, I play my fair share of MMOs and the like...but the thing is, in an MMO you don't constantly get screwed over and lose everything over and over again, I can see how some people find this fun (okay...maybe not fun unless you're a masochist, but tolerable), but for me it's enraging. When I log out from a game I want to feel like i've accomplished something...the only time I ever quit out of this game is in rage after I lose everything.

The second thing that really puts me off this game is the fact it's impossible to navigate using the map, it is only a rough sketch of the terrain you have discovered so far and it doesn't show your location at all, now I understand that this is a design choice...but I think it's a, quite frankly, utterly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ one. The map, which to the games credit is beautiful and immense in scope, is just too vast to not have any kind of navigation system, even if you do get some kind of improved map later on (I got to around lvl 23 or so) you shouldn't have to go that long, and likely a lot longer seeing as I didn't see any kind of map recipe in the coming levels, with no means of navigation or finding your base after a longish expedition other than dying to spawn back at your bed, which is hardly an option as you will lose everything on you...and it kind of defeats the whole purpose, this game would be so much more enjoyable if you had a (decent) map.

Another thing that I don't like is that (at least on multiplayer this is, not sure about single as I didn't play it) you can't just log out from this game, you have to make sure your character has enough food, and your dinos (if they didn't get murdered by insects the second the patch introducing them went live, that is) must also be in a safe enclosure and have enough food to not die of hunger until you next get on, oh...also, if you are on a PVPVE or PVP server, you will also have to hope nobody comes and murders you in your sleep, takes all your stuff, griefs your base or kills your dinos. Granted that last bit is more of a people thing and is true for any survival type game, but it's something that I personally don't like. Also...as far as i'm aware, even on the PVE only (I was on a PVPVE server) servers It is my understanding that you can still get raided and have your stuff stolen, although I don't think thye can kill you or your dinos while you are asleep. Assuming this isn't some tall tale, that doesn't sit quite right with me, PVE should not have to worry about being raided...that's kind of the reason why you play PVE.

Like I said at the start of this review, this isn't a bad game...not at all, I know many people love it and with good reason, I think the map on this game is gorgeous and mindnumbingly massive, I also love the whole basis around training dinos and making a tribe and all that, the combat also seems quite good (well, at least what it's supposed to be, more on that in a bit), there are a few quality of life things that could be done to the combat, such as being able to un-nock an arrow from your bow but that's a minor thing that will probably be added. One thing I did notice though, even playing on one of the lowest ping servers that I could find for an NZ player such as myself, combat is quite jumpy and there is a lot of glitching going on, the dinosaur AI could also use some work, for dinos that are skittish, you kind of just chase them till they run into a rock and get stuck and then proceed to brutally stab them to death, and for the larger ones that will fight back, you can avoid their attacks ridiculously easily, the fast nippy aggressive dinos like raptors and dilos kind of just glitch around, don't really hurt you much and are just annoying to take down due to said glitching.

The final thing that must be mentioned, which can be somewhat forgiven for being early in development, is the seemingly poor optimization. I wouldn't say I own a super beast million dollar dual SLI GTX titan rig or anything, but I own a pretty respectable GTX 770 rig with a good amount of RAM and a perfectly capable CPU (which though it may be, is next on my upgrade list), but this game has far worse performance than it should have, most settings had to be toned down to medium and low just in order to play the game at 30 frames or so, which is good enough but not great, added to this sub-par framerate, there are frequent micro-freezes and bouts of slideshow like framerates. Thankfully I didn't experience any crashes in my time, although there were many times where it felt like one was coming. Another thing that is annoying is that it takes a very long time to actually log into the game, on my first login to a server, it took about 15 minutes and subsequent logins about 8-10. This makes it very hard just to go oh
date: I know lets play some arc for half an hour or so"
recommended: if you decide to go play some arc you are gonna wanna make it a decent sized sesh if it takes that long to login and load.\n\nAnyway
hoursPlayed: if you have made it this far in my wall of text review then I commend you. I always seem to get carried away writing steam reviews

An amazing game with an amazing concept that has also borrowed many design philosophies from games like Rust (Without creating a pancake shoot-on-sight mess with guns everywhere by making them tedious to make & rare and by introducing dozens of other things to take up a player's time like gardening or building complex structures) but It so sadly collapses under It's own weight due to the progression system being a steaming pile of shÌt on a dozen different fronts. I'm just gonna list a few of these and hopefully you'll see what I mean.

-----------

1. Dinosaur Levels. One of the more glaring issues in this game is the level system that dinosaurs have. Humans (players) have a near identical system too but It's fair game as everyone starts on 1 and can only reach a maximum of level 94. Dinosaurs have a completely different ball-game however as they can spawn in being as high as level 95-120~ being insanely strong the moment they decide to pop into the game. If you happen to be able to tame one of these high level dinos, you can level them up an addtional 34 more levels and ontop of that, there's a disgustingly complex breeding system that allows you to mate two dinos and have them make an egg which you can then choose to waste several days (Actual real-life days) of your life incubating it to make a baby that inherit the stats/levels" from the high-level dino parents by random
