reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's time I finally review ARK! I got a one day early access to this game, and ever since that day I have been ADDICTED to it!

I'll start off by saying, the only way you will love this game is if you can actually play it. Currently, the optimization is fairly poor for average users. You should not expect more then 30FPS in it's current build. However, as long as you can actually play with okay frames it is amazing.

It combined the feel of building from reign of kings, or rust. Combined with MMO type feel of leveling and crafting.

This game is competetive! Fight other tribes, get the best dinosaurs, and be the first to get a gun and start taking over the ARK!

Wether you play PvE, or PVP, this game is challenging and never gets dull.

The devs update this game CONSTANTLY. They have weekly updates and new dinosaurs come out regularly too! What they have managed to pull off in such early stages in the game is incredible, it has so much content  you can spend thousands of hours playing this game and never get bored.

I haven't been able to touch another game since playing this, and I don't see tha changing anytime in the near future. Grab your friends, get on a server together and start building your life up! It's so much fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ARK is a very interesting survival game.  I must admit that I am biased because I've always loved dinosaurs, from Dizzy Dizzy Dinosaur to the plastic dinosaur figurines that had a playmat with a volcano that would erupt when combined with vinegar and baking soda.

Moving past the nostalgia...  The game can be unforgiving at first, which basically means that players just starting out should be VERY cautious when exploring. The first creatures encountred, except for maybe the Dodo bird, are all potentially dangerous. I don't want to give away any spoilers for those who enjoy discovering the game's values and mechanics on their own, so I'll just explain a bit why I enjoy the game.  1st off, the game is absolutely beautiful, pending the PC's power and capabilities on which it's running.  While this is a plus, it's also tough on mid-level machines, even on the lowest of detail settings.  Even though the watered down visuals appear more similarly to early King's Quests games, ARK is still phenomenally enjoyable, especially when played with friends.

There are a lot of aspects to ARK that I haven't seen in other survival games, which is quickly becoming one of my favorite genres.  Mounting dinosaurs as a means of transportation is definitely something that makes this game unique, as well as being able to tame almost all of the creatures you encounter.

The environment changes oftenly as well, with rainstorms passing through occasionally.  This is a very cool aspect as I always enjoy weather in games, especiialy when it affects the gameplay, such as getting cold and needing to take shelter, which is present in ARK.

The developers of ARK are constantly updating the game with patches to increase optimization, fix bugs that have been reported by the community, and oh yeah, giving away free stuff in contests! The contests have been a variety of challenges, such as taming all creatures in the game, to sending in pictures of your base and tribe (clan).  The activeness of the developers shows just how important this game is to them and the community which supports it.  While the game is in early access, there is a multitude of different aspects that are intended to be in the final product, which are all listed under the early access portion of the product page.

One thing I would enjoy seeing in the future is an option to randomize the map. I always enjoy a randomly generated environment, such as in 7 Days to Die. The defaut map in ARK, however, is enormous with so much environment to explore that this is really more of a final release type suggestion to increase replay value.

Well, I thank everyone who took the time to read this review and I hope it helps. There are many other reviews that have more specifics about the game, but I don't like giving away spoilers as I don't enjoy being spoiled" myself.

9/10 final rating
date: just because it's tough to run on PCs at the moment
recommended: but that should change with more and more optimization updates."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you enjoy sleeping?
Do you like waking up to find everything you've built is still there?
Have you ever had a shred of trust for anyone before?
Do you like to play other games instead of just one all the time?
Do you have a concept of peace?
Do you try to help fellow players, and have truly good intentions?

If you answered yes, this is not the game for you!


You can invest hours into making a home to have it destroyed in seconds, and that my friends is not a worthy investment of your time, even as games go.

And I don’t want to hear that “it’s part of the game” or “it’s just a game”. People make a conscious choice to play that way, to raid, grief, lie, deceive, attack without cause, destroy what other’s have worked to create. It is completely unnecessary and the game can be played just fine without any of that.
So yes, it is part of the game, but it doesn’t have to be, and that’s what gets me.


It's a game with fantastic potential, but it's plagued by its players.
(if you must buy this game, join a specifically PvE server, PvP is a joke, like so many other games)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is everything we asked for! Although on launch it isn't very well optimized so I have to play on medium to low settings (I have a GTX 960 and i7-4790k)

Collecting resources reminds me of rust and the character creation is hilarious (Reign of Kings style)
People are complaining that there isn't Single player, but there is now! They said Single player would be here on June 2nd which the game released and they just updated the game to add Solo.

There's nothing like feeling the ground rumble where you look to your left and there's a Brachiosaurus! Or maybe a horde of raptor sprinting toward you where you go to burrow away in a nice cozy home crafted with your bare hands!

leveling is awesome in this game and one of the things I enjoy most, Once you level up you can add points to numerous things. Say you want food to go down slower, add a point to it when you get to a new level, same with thirst or health and even stamina!

Once you level you can learn new things to craft giving you even more to add to your arsenal and cozy home!

I definitely recommend this game, tons of stuff to do and keep you busy trying to get the resources to craft something new, as well as tribes to have your friends join you in your adventure!

Pick this game up if you like Dinosaurs, Survival games, and Amazing Graphics!

Early Access Review

I´ll keep this Review real short, because they update this game 5 times a day and everything is changing a lot.

Pros:

- Amazing graphics and effects
- Great variety to apply skillpoints
- Many many different dinosaurs. And more of them are getting patched into the game
- Playing PvE is actually an option, because a few of the them are  really hard to kill!


Cons:

- PERFORMANCE!! They need to optimize the game really bad!
- You are forced to play in a team, because u have limited skillpoints and you are not able to get all of the skills.
- No option to reskill!
- To build a bigger base takes actually hours. They need to reduce the materials required to craft buildings.
- The time to tame a dinosaur could be reduced aswell. To tame a bronto could take up to 4 hours or more!
- Food! Food! Food! Your character is always hungry. If its freezing cold outside you actually need to eat a whole stack of meat to keep up your foodbar.

Well, as i said before everything named above could be improved with a patch tomorrow, so keep this in mind.
But i would definitely recommend this survival game! :)

EDIT: (10.01.2016)

- Perfomance got improved
- Taming duration can be reduced individually for each server
- You don´t need that much food anymore
- Patches are still coming weekly.

Amazing job devs. They keep on listening what has to be improved. *thumbs up*

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very binary. Either you will like it or you will have a horrible time with it. DO NOT, and I repeat, DO NOT buy this game if you plan to play by yourself. This is a sandbox survival game that lets you get attacked by other players while you are offline and you cant defend youself. This means that if you arent in a large tribe or arent lucky, someone will find you and they will kill you and destroy all your stuff, which means that you have to start all over EVERY SINGLE TIME.

The only way you can progress in this game playing solo is if you get extremely lucky and no one finds your base before you research metal, but for a new player, that means you have to level up and farm for materials, and that would take a really long time to do.

I cant recommend this game based on the fact progress requires extreme luck/ and or forcing a play style people might not want to play, however, if you do intend to play with a large group, this game would be lots of fun. I managed to reach that point before the wipe and riding around on trexs and raptors was very enjoyable, but after the wipe and being thrown back into the rat race, I finally reallized how little skill this game takes. No matter how well you set up your base, someone will find you and kill you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first reaction playing the game wasn't good at all, it really wasn’t!
The performance was really choppy, I expected to be able to play this game on high to ultra settings on my new gaming pc, but a few patches later the frame rate improved quite a lot, and the game didn’t feel like a crappy console port anymore.

Once I gave it a real chance, it turned out to be a great game with a lot of depth.
It’s great fun to explore, and tame dinosaurs, which can take a bit too long in my opinion, but luckily you can join community servers with faster taming times!

Sure things are a bit unpolished here and there, but the game is still in early access, and for me it's one of the best early access games available on Steam.

The game is updated frequently, and the developers are really listening to the community for feedback and actually implement a lot of idea’s that were suggested by the them.

They are also active on the discussion boards, and actually reply, and they let the community know what patches or new features will be planned or coming up, even before the patch hits your PC!
Something some game developers can learn from! *Looking at Valve*


Pros.
◘ One of the best Early Access games on Steam.
◘ Tame Dinosaurs and give them names!
◘ Active community and developers.
◘ Frequent updates with new features and content.
◘ Steam Workshop integration, with community build mods. This will increase the replayability a lot!

Cons.
◘ Taming times are way too long on vanilla servers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Background on my perspective & history with gaming so you can decide if my opinion matters:

I am a 24 year old American musician living abroad in Taiwan with my wife. I do not speak mandarian so my only English communication is really inside of ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes, FB with friends and family, etc...

I come from a gaming history on the PC with my first love of games being MMORPG like Conquer Online, runescape, WOW, etc...

Quickly as I moved to consoles I fell in love with single player RPGs such as the witcher series, bioshock 1-3***, all of the Elder Scrolls, fable (< I'm sorry), borderlands series, dying light, etc

I have always played these games as if they were persistent worlds and truly dove into the progression min / maxing elements. When I play a game I immerse myself in it, following the current expert YouTube players, watching twitch streams, becoming actively engaged in forums... Anything I can to get a leg up and progress efficiently in these RPG esc games.

Now disclaimer: I have never truly played a persistent MMO survival game until Ark

This was the game I had thought I was playing in all of the above but had yet to truly experience.

1000+ hours of skyrim left me empty in that I had mastered the map... There was no true progression left, and mainly with all the games listed before I was only benefiting myself. Yes we have guilds and clans in some of the MMO's but for the exception of guide war game modes there was little point for me to be pouring in hours into these games except to be more pvp powerful than the next joe. I have been searching for a game without even knowing one could exist that was truly persistent, populated, challenging, and rewarding on more than a min / max scale.... That was until I found Ark Survival Evolved - I will now begin my review

Ark Survival Evolved

This is a game for those who love adapting play styles, techniques, load outs in order to advance and grow in a persistent world of challenge.

This is a game for anyone who is fascinated by the jungles of Farcry and the building mechanics (that are being polished now) of a crafting game.

This is a game for those who can be social, responsible, and can communicate with others to grow on a communal level.

This is a game for those who want a world to dive into and truly immerse themselves for 1000+ hours

I have found the community to actually be incredibly helpful , supportive, giving, and kind - keep in mind I'm a mature" gamer 24+ that knows how to "handle" global chat - if your a young kid who goes on a temper tantrum after losing 10 hours of work you will get eaten alive in this game and you will quit.

This is a game that going into you MUST understand NOTHING is permanent

This is a game where you MUST learn from what happens to you and understand that everything you lose or gain is YOUR FAULT and you must adapt accordingly - this can include how you interact with other players

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beaware: This review is subject to change after the game goes into beta stage

Also this is a review not recommending the game for those who ain't used to early access or at least games in alpha stage

Pro/Con
The game's community:
Some will kill you at the begining, some won't
Some will let you join their tribe, some won't
Some will help you, some won't
Some will eat you, some won't (canibalism is available)
Some will rob you, some won't
Some will drag you about while offline, some won't
Some will drug you, some won't
Etc...
You get the point right?
From my experience there is basically all sorts of people you will find in this game.

Pros :
-Uses Unreal engine 4 (Better visuals, etc...)
-It has freaking dinos man, how can you say no to that (tame, ride and kill them) (make a dilophasauras army)
-RPG style mechanics for both the player and their dinos
-Persistant (when you log off your character goes to sleep, thats when players like me drag your body into water infested with sharks by the way)
- Can form tribes
- Up to 70 players on one server
- Easy to learn, plus if new players need help there is normally someone in the global chat on most servers whiling to help out

Cons:
- Your average survival game but with a jurassic theme (nothing too special about it).
-Lacking in options to costumise your character (beards, hair style, etc... , for now it is basic)
-Heavily lacking in optimisation for all around PCs.
-New players and their houses are easy targets for veterans since there is a leveling system and tech tree (did you spend 2 days making that wooden house with a dino pen and tamed all those dinos as well as leveled them, well too bad ill blow it all up with explosives :-) ) (PvP servers only).
-Building even low tier structures costs a lot of resources (you would be better raiding, hunting and collecting from supply drops than settling down) .
-Enjoy watching a t-rex fly after killing it (it's actually hilarious) (a lot of glitches to take advantage off as well).
-Currently there is only one map The Island" and its not randomly generated.
-Joining a tribe means that once you leave it all that you have worked hard to build becomes the tribe's property (it's a great way to scam people so you can have all their stuff (dinos and structures)

Conclusion
Look ill be honest
date: the game is bloody amazing and entertaining
recommended: even now at alpha stage it provides much more fun then a game twice it's price but the reason to why i don't recommend this game even knowing it's still in alpha is because it needs a lot of patching to make it more bearable for some players and i bought this because i have high hopes for it but i would recommend to other potential buyers to give it some time before buying it
hoursPlayed: the developers have made it a top priority to fix it's optimisation issues but best buy it at maybe beta stage

It is futile to try to win, you are already behind the power curve, and the chinese do not sleep.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cant believe after 477 hours I would actually not recommend this game. Ark is a grinbdfest and a time management game. The more time you can commit to play and the more you learn to grind, the better you do. You cant outplay other plays. You cant perform better and make any meaningful advances as the game encourages waiting out your enemy. I am sure there are tons of private servers that fix these inherent problems with the game but the overall point is the official servers encourage gameplay through the grind.

If you are a devoted PvP player who likes dominating others and has a large amount of time to commit, this game is probably for you, but I wont recommend a game to anyone that supplements gameplay with grinding and outweighing your enemy.

As a few people have mentioned. It is a somewhat better situation on private servers. Unfortunately, the game has no PvE endgame currently and the PvP is too heavily time mismanaged by forcing players to spend hours taming and gathering resources, as opposed to engaging in actual combat, which makes the game so unbelievably grindy. Get players fighting in person, not fighting bases while they are offline.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note, I am assessing the game based on early access and not as a full game, thank you.

And yes, I said no, even after playing so long because you get to this stage when you have played long. No I would not recommend it especially as an early access. Here's why:

1) Community is rubbish.
As many of the above reviews have mentioned, this is seriously a downside if you are planning on early access and community response. Its true, many a critic, casual gamers and newcomers alike are now all experiencing Faction dominance, tribe stealing, griefing, etc. Some die 5 times the moment they respawn, some join a tribe, build for weeks to months only to have their gaming efforts kicked out of tribe and turned over to the chief, who could be a b*st*rd.

Solution: For an Early Access game, you want your community expansive, subjective and evolving, not dominating and uncooperative. The only way to avoid tribes becoming disaster is to take out tribe governance option and leave one tribe option, which is everything owned personally, but shared riding along with a random generated map like Ark so that no one dominates, and no one have superiority over any land mass.

2) Overgrinding versus overplay.

You want everyone on equal playing field the moment you release it as an early access. Grinding too much will differentiate individuals to a highly variable inequality. Its early access, and some reports are already mentioning the idea of official server resets. I mean cmon, its early access, set up the speed of gathering, taming and what not, you want casual gamers to comment on it too, not shy them away, you are gonna swipe the data once the game releases anyway. When you set the time pace too such a slow rate, yet lose you items so easily you leave no time for actual action gameplay. An hour of grinding for 5 mins of action and that doesn't even include the risks (which are plenty) to lose them all in a blink of an eye. Also note updates are daily, taming takes hours, the risk is higher that in one of those taming sessions, its gonna end up on a server maintanence period and boom, you'll lose the entire procedure by getting kicked out of server.

Solution: There are already plenty of unofficial servers now coming out with 5xtaming, 3xExp, etc. It shows you the community have spoken, they want the grinding hours DOWN! Especially on official servers. Set up faster everything in certain official servers or have all of them revamped till the early access is over. Plan for a revamped Ark map that has random generation that includes seperated large archipellagoes connected only through seas of different arks in the pairs of three. This can also be done by having different maps for different servers or a random generated start of different islands. You avoid land dominance in this manner.

3) Bugs that contribute to the above two points. There are bugs almost everywhere in the game, but that's no surprise, its the fact that it affects the above two points is what bugs me. When you have bugs that send dinos flying away at lightspeed after a spear or chop while your starving, place structures wrongly losing a huge resource stock on it and only getting half back, remove resources because some idiot wants his stamp on Ark mining spots, randomly jump out of a flying bird ( I mean cmon, whose lazy/stupid enough not to secure that use button while flying? Few codes and that use button wont work while flying..is that soooo hard? ), dinos keep rushing on you while you harvest therefore end up hitting them or killing them and more than half the dinos dont know how to follow properly and/or get stuck into spots leaving you exposed to losing both your dinos and yourself, etc its time to NOT ignore the bugs. Again, take note all this requires hours of grinding and to lose them to bugs, you break apart the community into haves and haves not, where one cudn't careless of the bugs and those that do, tend to take the game less seriously. You want all players to invest their interest into the game and these bugs is one main reason why you have a community problem due to the bugs that cause unstable grinding and overt stress that shys away gamers that could have spend way more hours on record.

Solution: Stop adding all those other funny stuff...enough is enough, the bugs and interface have to go or you will submit your pride and joy into a very uncertain and risky future. You have no more cards behind your sleeves, there is no more dino movie coming out to publicize for you, its time to stop the hanky panky and completely eradicate the bugs that were existant since god knowns when. Its time to at least prepare the game into a version that is at least releasable.

4)YOLO:
Almost everything in this game's gameplay is a YOLO dive. If you die, thats it, there's nothing saving your data. IF you do want to save your data, you STILL have to kill yourself. Seriously, what's with all the game's impact on YOLO?  You can't save halfway, you can't save your character for download while keeping them alive (Meaning if the server resets, any server, your entire character development goes), there are no checkpoint spots, you characters is entirely exposed when you're off with only a bed that can respawn you with a cooldown and weak health. Seriously, this game has a hardcore grinding mechanics for a YOLO trip. We already have a real life, don't make this game another one of those let's try to be real thing with unfair life-like mechanics, its a very wrong move for a survival game, instead go arcade monster hunter freedom and minecraft-like. You'd want this game to last long, not just for a short time period before it vanishes even before its released.

5) Game processing and optimizing is very poor not because of vamped up graphics but server to pc data transfer that causes those stop frames and huge FPS when you know your pc can run it, just taking time to process it. This means, not only does this game demand high system requirements, it also demands high internet bandwidth. You'd have a pretty sucky time with gameplay if you're connection sucks. That itself eradicates even more potential players, not to mention potential dedicated servers that can't handle that much requirements. It's almost like this game demands a whole lot from you but offers little in return at this stage.

So no...unfortunately I would not recommend others to this game at this stage in early access. I definitely will when the solutions to the problems above are handled but for now, it's not that I won't but I believe I can't, it doesn't even allow me to do that because I would feel like I'm treating other gamers unfairly. I say this after playing for 203.8 hours of gaming it as an avid gamer with a casual perspective for gaming.

Contrast option:
- Most of the positive reviews are true, the game has depth for it to be released, but as above, it lacks quality.
- I would say the highest ranking in survival games in terms of graphics and sandbox freedom
- High customizability (as of recent skins and patches)
- Smooth transcendence between solo and co-op play. One minute you feel alone, the next theres a random dude half naked running across the beach yelling YOLO!!!" (The mic voice even fades in and out in strength compared to the distance you are to the voice source)
- Variable high definition weather (However this looses points to the overhardcore grinding mentioned above as the weather influences your survivability to a level displeasing or stressfull rather than engaging and adrenaline kicked excitement)
- The game encourages tribe joining  and player cooperation but as seen by proof of many such a state
date: due to the above mentioned negative points
recommended: almost all of the long standing servers with larger memory banks often end up corrupted or with negative based community.\n\n*Note my opinions of this game is subject to change on a later date after the improvements*"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've revisited this game to see if anything has improved in the last 12 months.  Because there are comments that refer to my original review I'll leave that text here.  The updated review can be found further down.

-----Original Review-----
I'll start with this simple statement: This is not a game to play alone.

The crafting system pretty much requires that you work with other people to have access to all the craftable items.  Some people will need to specialise in building construction, others in tools, weapons and armour.  Unless you do that you'll find that you run out of Engram Points by the time you reach the level cap (60) and can't buy the upper tier schematics.

I had high hopes for this game.  It's horribly unforgiving though.  On my first login my character was dead before he'd even finished scratching his shiny wrist implant, having woken up next to a crocodile who seemed to take offense at its dinner suddenly becoming self-aware and put a stop to it as quickly as possible.

Anything you try to do in this game is going to take a whole mess of time.  The big attraction in the game, taming and riding dinosaurs, can take anywhere up to four hours (real time) during which you have to sit next to your prospective steed force feeding it whatever its favourite food is with the occasional narcotic berry slipped in to keep it from running away while you wait for Stockholm syndrome to kick in.  During that time you're very unlikely to be able to go anywhere else, so you're a sitting duck for any carnivore who decides a nice soft human looks much more appetizing than any of the bite sized morsels it walks past on its way to you.

The pvp aspect of the game is also very punishing.  To make a base you'll spend hours levelling up to unlock the necessary schematics, gathering materials, picking out a spot with access to water and far enough from the beaten track to avoid being killed while you're building and then putting together a few modest rooms with a lockable door in which you can safely log off, knowing that your unconscious body will remain in the game until you log back in.  Unfortunately those hours of effort can be undone in a matter of minutes by the first person to wander by, bash down a wall, ransack your supplies and drag your body away for blood draining and/or butchering.  Apparently having tamed dinosaurs as guardians is the way to avoid this.  I've already addressed the problems there.  Or make sure you play exclusively on pve servers where the coast is covered in enough thatched huts and campfires that you'll wonder if you haven't accidentally wandered into a Pacific island resort.

This is pre-release of course and a lot of the problems can be solved with a few tweaks.  Times can be changed, damage can be retuned, hell, maybe they'll even manage to make the AI more sophisticated and create the living ecosystem" they've been advertising instead of the sandbox of dinosaurs versus megalodons that it is currently.  That won't change my core problem with the game though - the rigidity of the building system.

If
recommended: you don't enjoy the building system in Rust or The Forest
hoursPlayed: where walls and floor snap together in predefined ways
voteText: you're going to have a hard time enjoying this game.  Say goodbye to any plan of building bridges between islands - you can't build a span more than a few blocks of a foundation piece and as soon as the ground drops away more than a metre that's the end of your foundation.  I long for epic constructions
helpfulPercent:
a Jurassic Park style gate between two cliffs or a village on stilts above a lagoon.  Sadly that kind of thing remains purely in the realm of the voxel-based building games.
-----End Original Review-----

I originally said this wasn't a game designed for playing alone.  That remains true.  What I didn't mention is that you shouldn't buy this game if you don't intend to devote a large proportion of your waking hours to it.  I alluded to the time-heavy nature of the game but I never spelled it out in these terms : If you do not treat this game as a job you will not succeed in online play.

I was not aware of blueprints when I wrote the original review - they can supplement your engrams and can be found in what are basically supply drops.  Supply drops are rated with different colours showing the value of the contained loot and are visible from as far as your draw distance will allow so the more lucrative drops will be hotly contested.  On a pvp server you can probably forget it unless you're online during a lull.  The established tribes on each server will by now be strong enough to dictate who can play on that server.

The game appears to be much more unforgiving than I remember.  Heat and cold are even more out of whack
votesHelpful: with my character overheating while waist deep in water and freezing to death while crouched next to a roaring campfire.  The multitude of new creatures added to the game mean that it's rare to go far without something attacking you - In the hour I played it tonight I was spawn killed by pirahnas
votesTotal: snakes and some kind of winged creature that I only heard
votesFunny: never saw
commentsCount: before I was dead.\n\nThe game world itself is horribly unintuitive.  Rocks on the ground are sometimes just textures rather than resource nodes.  Likewise driftwood on the beach is just a texture
column16: not something you can pick up to avoid having to punch a tree down to get materials to make your tools.  Berries and fibres can be picked from almost anything leafy that isn't a tree.  Except for the leafy stuff that you can't harvest from that looks just like the stuff you can.  Predators and prey mingle together completely unconcerned meaning you can't assume an area with grazing herbivores is in any way safe - a snake or a raptor will ignore all of them in favour of taking down the player.\n\nI don't think it's reasonable for the developers to claim this game is in early access at this point. reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's 3 AM IRL and I'm flying my scouting ptera to travel from the main base to our remote village. Midway i spot another tribe's base, noticing no turrets gives me courage to go closer and have a look at it. The turrets were hidden and took my ptera down in 30ms.As cigarette smoke starts filling the room, I soon realize I'm out in the wilderness kilometres away from any friendly settlement, running out of ammo. A carno charges at me from the bushes, I defeat it in a tense fight. A T-rex appears behind my back, and I barely evade it's first strike and rush towards the hillside close by. I mindlessly start running up north towards our remote village. After running away for minutes, I arrive at a glade and spot the cliff the village is located on and I remember that my clifftop village is unaccessible by foot. I start building a platform to reach it, and when i reach about 20m of height, I catch sight of the near identical cliff on which the village is built. An hour, and 2 rebuilds later my platform reaches the top of the cliff and I'm in safety.

10/10 Would play until dawn trying to reach my safe haven.

PS: Best graphic simulator ever! 10/10 would reapply settings and mess around with them to get the fps i had a day ago.

TL;DR : Ark is very promising and could be an enjoyable game in it's current state. Graphics are gorgeous but won't even run on my friend's custom built very high end rig properly without inconsistent fps drops. Gameplay mechanics are UTTERMOSTLY interesting but are not perfectly polished. The music is composed by Gareth Coker who composed the wonderful themes of Ori and the blind forest<3, and are therefore very inspiring, but for instance constant in and out restart of combat music gets annoying and repetitive after a while. Gameplay experience in overall is satisfying. But players who hate to grind mindlessly, or are not prepared to lose their items or buildings anytime should not consider playing it. Given it's an early access game glitches, bugs and poor optimization are present, building placement should be redesigned, game balance should be adjusted.Devs are active, tho they should put their focus on graphics optimization, building system polishment, and PROPER game balance changes to appeal to more casual players. Instead of pushing content and MAKING A HORRIBLE DECISION with nerfing tamed dino stats.






Ark is a promising title in the currently popular survival genre. If you are into survival games and enjoy playing with many people as a community sharing resources, you are guaranteed to have a lot of fun. But the game is hardcore and is therefore not suited for the faint-hearted and in it's current state has it's flaws, given it's an early access game, and that the devs are active, improvements are certainly coming.

It's basically a MMO-ish survival game, with crafting system, building placement, and companion/mount taming. It's heavily focused on PvPvE gameplay(meaning it kind of forces you to play in a tribe but there is a constant threat of encountering aggressive players) and is very unforgiving (If anyone played KMMOs could know what it means when a game is about THE GRIND, and this game wants you to hoard high amounts of materials to progress in the tech tree and craft higher end items. with official multiplier rates it's very very grindy. Atop of that you could lose anything, anytime, anywhere.) The grind is eased by the clan system, which are from now on are mentioned as tribes. Players could form tribes and share bases and mounts and basically all their wealth.

To even maximalize time sink effect, taming or breeding dinos and other beasts, takes from an hour to 16+hrs, without the ability to completely leave the game unattended for extended periods.

Building placement is very tricky and is hard to use properly. Given your mats are earned with hard work, this is very annoying in certain situations.

Game balance is heading in a disastrous direction after tamed dinos had their stats nerfed badly.
Instead game designers should have at least lowered mat requirements and taming duration globally.

Graphics are very unoptimized and settings are currently broken ( you have to reapply settings every now and then(after alt-tabs, steam overlay. View distance for instance won't differ on max and low settings, some settings give better results when maxed out than on medium)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING: REVIEW IS NOW (fairly) OBSOLETE.

The developers need to fix major optimization issues, which is fairly understandable considering it's an early access game. If you have a higher-end PC, then I would probably recommend it to you with the 20 minutes of experience I've had with it (still expect bugs, glitches, and still not high framerates). Refunded but I'll definitely repurchase it for a higher price in the future if the problem is addressed.


EDIT: I believe a lot of people are failing to understand that optimization is not a player based matter and not about how good your PC is. Optimization is a responsibility of the developers to ensure that people with PCs of various performance levels can enjoy the game. This is why I can run other games which have arguably equal to or better graphics and still get a higher framerate than ARK: Survival Evolved.

As for the actual gameplay involved, I cannot provide a solid review. This is just to notify potential gamers that there is a problem with optimization that needs to be addressed and to reconsider if they don't have a decent enough computer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Eat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please do not buy this game.

In some games you can do griefing, or PvP. You can ruin someone's afternoon.

This game lets you ruin their week. It is full of psychopathic children with a scorched earth mentality. Every pet I raised was four hours of collecting resources and training and failing and trying again. And every pet was killed by one man flying an eagle.

The eagle then destroyed the roof to my fort. And the walls. Then he clawed every person who was asleep, offline, inside. Then he destroyed every wall, every torch, every fire pit. He destroyed our bridge and our towers. He destroyed because we created.

The game for you is wandering around trying to create. The game for everyone else is murdering you and destroying literally everything with your name on it, because they can, because it is there.

Not to steal resources. We had nothing the eagle man wanted. Just because.

The antagonist from Preacher said, go ahead, cut a guy's ♥♥♥♥ off, if you have to send a message, but leave the guy an inch to ♥♥♥♥ with.

The eagle man left us no inch to ♥♥♥♥ with.

There is nothing you can create in this game that one man in invulnerable armor and an eagle cannot take away. As people get frustrated and quit, all that are left are the eagle men and the naked newcomers. A seventh circle of hell where every frozen sinner is chewing on the guys' head in front of them, forever. The absolute worst that humanity has to offer on display, forever.

Do not buy this game. The user base is the worst.

They wouldn't give me a refund. I beg you. Do not give them money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

6.5 hours in and I can say this game has LOADS of potential. Some tips for optimum performance:

1) Your supercomputer is nice, but scale back the graphics until further optimization occurs.
2) Avoid official servers. They're potatos with ethernet lines atm.
3) See that ocean? Looks cool and refreshing right? One word: megalodon. Beware.

This is the first survival game that has managed to pull me in viciously in ages. Given less time constraints, I'd have 20+ hours in easily. The crafting is near perfect, the leveling system is clever and interesting, the dinos range from interesting to genuinely terrifying. The community is surprisingly helpful for a game like this and opitimization issues aside, it runs splendidly.

About FPS/optimization. I run a GTX 750Ti, 8gb of RAM, and an i5 4690k. Aside from the occasional server lag, it runs smooth as butter on a T-rex's belly most of the time at medium settings and the game still looks beautiful.

Should you get it?

Do you love dinosaurs?
Ever wanted to ride one?
Smash one's head in with a stone hatchet?
Use your own feces (or someone else's) to grow crops?
Run from Raptors?
Be eaten by said Raptors?
Kill and eat Dodo birds for fun?
Punch a prehistoric crocodile in the throat?
Form tribes with your friends?
Argue over whose plants the tribe's fecal pile should fertilize today?

If you said yes to any/all of these, buy it. It's currently a boatload of fun and will only get better with time. The devs are already releasing updates and trying to smooth out the gameplay before they build on what's already there. I see a pretty fantastic future for ARK, come and be a part of it.

But seriously, watch out for the Raptors. They're clever girls.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I did like the game sometimes. We played on an Official PvP server. There wasn't really much PvP, it was more like PvE until you get stitched up by a tribe.

The thing I didn't like about this game is that it takes over your life. If you log off the game, there's a high chance your buildings will be destroyed and your stuff looted and dinos killed. Therefore, it's a bad idea to log off the game. Taming the dinosaurs was kind of rewarding, but they'll probably be dead when you log back in.

I know what some of you are thinking, play on an unofficial server. This doesn't make any difference. Since I stopped playing, some friends still play the game all the time, even though it's unofficial.

PvP encounters are seldom and you'd not be ready for them or the enemy would not be ready for them.

There's always something you have to do before you log off. Do all the plants have enough fertalizer? Do the dinos have enough food? Is the important stuff in the vault? Does the fridge have sparkpowder and the generator have gas? You may now log off. But expect all your things could be gone tomorrow.

If you're thinking I should have played PvE, this is not what I wanted. I like to fight other players, but that is not really a thing, at least in official. And the reason why I'd not play on unofficial is because this game eats time, which is why I stopped and now avoid it like the plague.

Cos it is a plague. A plague on time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS:

-Very fun to play

-Challenging

-A big variety of weapons to make and use

-Open world

-Huge map

-Has both PvE and PvP servers available

-YOU CAN RIDE A MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TYRANNOSAURUS

CONS:

-Pretty badly optimized at its current state, doesn't run very well even on higher-end computers

-In multiplayer the dinosaurs and other creatures can be out of sync, which causes them to teleport and jump around a lot. Latency can make it impossible to fight raptors etc.

-Takes a LOT of time to really get into

-At the moment, griefing is way too easy (in my opinion), since you can wreck bases that took, let's say, 40 hours to build, in maybe an hour or two.

-Argentavis is very overpowered in its current state, since it can pick up even ankylosaurs. It's also a very safe mount to use to raid bases, even safer than a Tyrannosaurus.

CONCLUSION:

Overall a very solid game that just requires quite a bit of balancing and tweaking. Optimization could also be nice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Linux/Apple users: Devs don't place us at the same priority with Window's users.

TL;DR Unless you have a few friends to play LAN, do not buy.  Anything good about it is ruined by a couple critical issues, bad bugs, and all the terrible people who populate servers.

I much prefer playing in single player, or on non dedicated servers.  Both because the people aren't awful, but also because the game actually runs differently.  However, for a game that is supposed to be a multiplayer open world survival, not having the multiplayer working right makes me feel like I didn't get what I was trying to buy.

The major issues was the way the game plays.  Basically, if you go on a multiplayer server there's a top tribe.  In PvP that tribe rules with an iron fist, enforcing whatever server rules they like.  Their superior blueprints, resources and dinos will always enable them to crush any up and coming group, or small tribes.  For example, *every* PvP server I played on, the top tribe had a ban on Gigas, calling them too powerful to trust to lower tribes.  And I was blocked from the holiday events, because other players didn't want to share the drops.

On the one hand, this is totally cool.  It's an open world, and it's amazing that it let's people do anything, and who wouldn't want to put out the eye of new rival clans entering your server/island?

On the other hand, as someone new to the game, I have basically experienced nothing but the misery that comes with watching hours of my time be destroyed, along with my emotional attachment to my homes and tamed dinosaurs.  As you hit stone age tools and weapons, top tribes take notice and start to suppress you.  It makes leveling more difficult and gathering top tier resources impossible.  This effectively blocks you from high level & end game content, unless you are in the top tribe.

Truely, the game is difficult.  Which makes the losses so much more painful.  And because live servers run all the time, you'll likely wake to your things destroyed.  The only way to combat this, is to be part of a large tribe... or, the top tribe.  Leading to all servers I visted having one top tribe that basically controlled the server.

Those tribes put people through all sorts of hazzing & harassment.  The worst case, my gf (whom I play games with regularly) was sexually harassed, after being locked in a cage (which is an in game mechanic).  She cried for two hours, having lost weeks of labor, and being imprisoned and sexually harassed.

Certainly, this is not the developers fault, although it did happen on an official server.

My point is that, when its awful... it gets very very awful.  And then you basically have to restart from scratch.  There are whole groups of people who just roam from server to server talking about how they were abused by this person or that group, and which servers to avoid.

On PvE servers, top tribes simply control all the best spots to build, or build collumns to block other tribes from building in their terriorty.  Bases are huge, and top tribes basically have zoos everywhere.  Many servers look like deserts where there are no wild animals, and no resources.

Considering the difficulty of the game, this (early access) game's bugs are pretty critical.  Oops, your dino pops through a wall/floor and died/disappeared?  Oh well, hours of work gone.

I've basically quit online play, and play a small game singe player/offline with roommates.  Problem is, you don't have enough skill points to do everything alone, so even single player/offline is difficult.

Unless you have a server and some friends to play with, do not buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With Ark: Survival Evolved now #1 on the Steam Top Sellers List, I figured it is time to write my review.

Day 1, spawn into a brand new server with 4 friends, spend 3 hours picking up rocks, berries, dodo corpses while furiously running along the coast looking for the best place to begin our colonization.

After about 15 hours of work (albeit very enjoyable work filled with throwing poop at each other, slingshotting rocks at brontosauri and leading them back into friends, ect. ect. ect.) we established a beach home, tamed raptors, a trike, and some dilos, we felt accomplished.

Not long after, we had our first experience with PvP raiding, which for all intensive purposes, felt like someone taking your brand new computer and pushing it down a flight of stairs. In otherwords, it felt extremely unforgiving, personal, and gutwrenching as we watched from a tranq arrow induced coma, as several players beat our dinos and base into the ground.

With that said, we learned a valuable lesson, never build a base out of wood without first building weapons, a defensive wall, and possibly a gun. Even as harsh as the pvp in the game can be, it is without a doubt completely exhilarating, you never get used to a sudden gunshot, or a group of raptor riders chasing you through longgrass, or breaking through a forest, backpeddeling while hastily firing an assault rifle into the treeline as a saddled T-Rex or Spinosaurus crashes through with jaws agape searching for your torso.

Now with nearly 300 hours into the game, and no sign of becoming bored with the game in all of its unflinching ruthlessness, I can honestly say this game deserves a long and dedicated look.

As far as the games developer team goes, I have yet to see a team so interested in their own creation! From consistantly and quickly releasing new content, teasing upcoming new content, interacting with and assisting the current player community, and even playing the game with us in their downtime. 10/10 on the devs for not pulling a DayZ-like scenario.

TLDR - Game is great, put the time in with no regrets, throw poop and rocks, help actually shape the game while it's in development, and last but definitely not least - This is how early access and game developers are supposed to act!

Update 2: So the devs have finally upped the hp of the ptera and the argent and upped the dmg of the ptera, so they finally seem useable again, the current update (231.7) is a good step in the right direction, hopefully they continue like this. Hopefully they learn from this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey everyone. So, I'm going to mark this game as Not Recommend. As the game continues to be worked on, it becomes easier and easier to run, but also becomes more and more complex with how many dinos there are.
Basically, I wouldnt recommend this not just because of performance issues but also because of the other players. It's hard to take any players seriously or trust them when sometime they'll end up killing you, your dinos, or griefing your base while offline. Sadly, it's not a matter of if you'll get killed/griefed... it's a matter of when. If you've poured over 600 hours into this game like myself, then you'd understand the pain associated with getting wiped after 600 hours of playing in peace. I played on a PvPvE server, and knew it would happen eventually, but I didnt even get a chance to defend myself. I was offline and so was my tribe.
As a seasoned player, this game was easy when I first started playing. However... When I created a new character on a different server, it was extremely difficult to stay alive. If you like struggling for 3+ hours starting out in a new game, then this is definitely for you! But, if you like to survive based on your skills as a player, then this probably isnt for you (not anymore). The beach is packed with Dilos, Raptors, Sabercats, Eagles (or Argents), sometimes a Rex with the occasional ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Bronto.
Covered the players
Talked about starting fresh
The build system...
As a crafter and builder, this game is beautiful! Absolutely love the crafting system. Hit this, hit that, grab this and that.. press Craft and tada! You have a pickaxe. lol. You can gather a lot, and craft a lot, but if you are on a pvp server, dont make it obvious by how much you are packing. (Dont wear fabricated armor and carry around a fabricated weapon... Shows you got good supplies at your base) A raiding tribe sees this, they mark you, find you, and watch to see when you go offline.. anyways lol. Crafting. The amount of supplies needed to craft is pretty on par with what you get, but not on how easy it is to consume/destroy. Maybe it is, maybe it isnt.. Maybe the developers intended for a solo player to raid a tribe's triple metal wall base, load up all their supplies on a rex and walk away.. who knows.. lol. Bottom line is...
It's still early access and there are balance issues to be addressed. I dont think more dinos need to be added unless they are dinos that help balance. (Snails that create paste to help build more metal walls for example). If it were easier by being a smarter player to build... Id be down with that. I wouldnt be ok with it just being easier to build... then there would be noob huts everywhere. O_O

Review in a nutshell- Play this game if you love dinos and just want to play casual. Dont get attached to anything. It will most likely die, or burn to the ground.. :'(

If any Dev was actually paying attention to this review- Thanks for listening and adding PVE pvp" flag like I recommended. lol. Now just add PvP "pve" flag too... so PVP server tribes can have times of peace (and cant remove it until a set amount of time has passed)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let us note that this is DAY 1 and still in Early Access.

Let us also remind people that this game will be released and finished next year.

Let us ALSO remind everyone that this game has had 20 patches in the past 48 hours with the Devs planning to do updates every 2 days roughly.

So do not judge this game harshly if it falls behind in certain areas. It is still being heavily and carefully worked on.

------------------------------------------------------------

My Experience so far has been great, frame rate is still struggling as expected but did go up after a few patches. The crafting system is nice and progressive and forces you to do things to level up and unlock more recipes. As expected you don't lose recipes when you die or levels making it very easy to recover from death. The building mechanic so far is solid and players from Rust legacy will be familar with it. Taming is difficult as it should be but is very rewarding. Most people have also not even seen a full 15% of the game yet at the time of this, gauranteed. This game is massive and takes a lot of leveling to unlock all the craftables while also encouraging you to venture deeper into the island as you get stronger.

All expected bugs and performance issues aside it is a very promising Early Access game. The fact that this has mixed reviews already comes from the majority of inexperienced people with Early Access games ♥♥♥♥♥ing that something doesn't work Day 1.

Nothing ever works Day 1 launch, get over it. Stop destroying a games rep for no reason.

220 hours all wasted. This was one of the best games I've ever played, until one day I wake up dead, everything is gone (once again) and I finally come to the conclusion that the grief out weighs the entertainment value. It would be just fine if we lost everything in combat to better skilled players or even being simply out number and conquered by force. But, this game is all about hitting people when they are offline. Don't believe me? Drop $25 and see for yourself.

Do you live a sad existence? Do you hate the world and want to take it out on others? Buy this game and learn other tribes' schedules, hit those tribes while they are offline (because you are a coward) and then laugh your sorry self to sleep about it. You may even get the chance to see someone you sleep raided raging in global chat about how spineless you are, then deep down inside you may once feel a small amount of sadistic joy (but not too deep because lets face it, you're shallow and probably always will be).

So, with that being said, death to all griefers!!!

Game 10/10 + toxic community = game 1/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was amazing shortly after the wipe when I first started since  I had an even playing field as the people who were playing longer then me.  However it quickly became apperent that if you can't give up working  , school and sleeping you will get literally no where in this game.   The game is designed to make the strong tribe wipe out any threat that starts building up power just so they can stay the strongest.  After watching some youtube videos I found there were some servers full of nice people that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s went out of their way to make a survivor and just troll them nonstop  by griefing dinos and bases everyway they could.  I even saw one dude get outed after griefing and bought another copy of the game just to go back and  troll them some more.

Gameplay review;

There is so much amazingness about the game but its surrounded  by so much ♥♥♥♥ and bugs it is  hard to give this a solid  review.  Without spending days to farm kibble a high level dinosaur can take you upwards of 12hours to tame.  That is 12 hours you have to spend playing the game you can't even start it and come back later since you have to protect your dinosaur from wild dinosaurs and trolls + keep the torpor raised and food on it.
After taming the dinosaur you have to have somewhere to keep it safe otherwise there is an extremely high chance it will be dead by the time you log on the next day.


They are  constantly pushing out new content at an incredible rate but they aren't fixing some major issues the game has.


Tribe glitch:  There is a chance upon leaving a tribe and joining one that your previous tribe will just become completely owned by the new tribe.  So  you have to be careful who you recruit as if they leave and join a dif tribe you could lose 100% of everything you own and have absolutely no way to fix it.

Falling through the map:  Isn't 100% death but without points in  stam / oxygen it pretty much is.  Oh rememeber that dinosaur you spent 12 hours to tame and 1 week farming up resources to build him a safe dinopen?  Yeah he fell through the map with you and drown.

Two biggest glitches I know about.


When I first bought this game it was amazing.  I literally lost myself in it and it was worse then crack or heroin for me.  I'd stay up  4 days in a row with a couple friends playing it nonstop.  sleep for maybe 5 hours and repeat.  Had about 12 active tribe members and a pretty big base.  Was pretty awesome.  I was a peaceful tribe who only traded  and helped new players get started.   Until one day I got drug into a war between the 2 strongest tribes and wiped out in 1 night of being offline.  My entire base and all 200+ of my dinos were killed.   1000 hours of work and I have absolutely nothing to show for it.


TL;DR  I definitely got my moneys worth buying the game and I'd definitely go back and buy it again if I could.   However where the game is now I don't recommend anyone buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ark: Survival Evolved lives up to its name. It takes the most successful components of survival games, crafting, collecting resources, eating, building shelter, and brings all these things to another level: Surviving on an island with Dinosaurs. Building a base is not as easy as you would think on an island with Dinosaurs, as the larger ones can easily destroy any dwelling created simply by walking on it. You have several types of materials to build structures with including; Thatch, Wood, Stone, and Metal. There are over 60 different types of dinosaurs so far in the game and the developers are always adding new content. Some Dinosaurs can be tamed and used as protection, pack mules, for egg or ♥♥♥♥ farming, resource collecting, or even to ride.

You can play Ark: Survival Evolved both as a single player game, as well as in multiplayer mode, either on public or privately hosted servers. You are not limited to first-person perspective as some survival games do, a third-person perspective is an option. You can also tailor various aspects of the game to your own personal playstyle, using the settings prior to launching the game in single player. Make the nights shorter and the days longer, adjust the regrowth rate of flora and fauna, there are dozens of options to choose from.

Ark: Survival Evolved initially made me wary, because of the concept of a survival game on an island with dinosaurs; However, once I played it I realized the amazing potential it had. Some Dinosaurs are passive, and of course many are hostile and predatory, but there is a great balance to the game and if you play it smart, you can survive a long time and have a lot of fun. The developers seem to really be interested in making this an amazing game, even going as far as to reward players who are able to find exploits. Visually speaking I think the game is on par with a lot of the more recent survival titles and the details of the dinosaurs are amazing. This game is good enough, if you enjoy survival games it is worth paying full price for. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is ARK: Survival Evolved?

It's Bear Grylls in Jurassic Park. You wake up on a strange island, lost to time, with nothing to your name except a ragged loin cloth, and chances are it's going to stay that way for awhile.
The Island is not a forgiving place, your best chance at survival in the early hours is to gather resources quick and stay close to some big herbivores that might turn aggressive on a carnivore if it comes your way.  This can only protect you for so long, eventually you're going to have to scavenge food, construct shelter and, hopefully, some tools that will ease you on your way to a more permanent residence on the island.

You aren't the top of the foodchain out here, but you can be, if you're quick and cunning.

But maybe that's not for you. Maybe you're more of a Lego-minded sort, just wanting to build something impressive in an ancient world, and guess what? This game is still the place for you.
It's Minecraft on a whole new level. If you just want to build, adjust your singleplayer game to your liking, make yourself invincible if you wish, and go to town. No Dino will hurt you and you can build to your hearts content.

Frankly, the only question you should ask yourself about ARK isn't whether you'll like it--you will, it has something for everyone--the thing you have to answer is Can my computer handle it?"
That's the only true difficulty in purchasing this game. It's beautiful
recommended: and it can make even the heartiest of gaming rigs chug for support. My own PC is top of the line but when I crank up this game my tower's gentle fans turn into the engines of jumbo jet to ensure I keep running smoothly.\nI do
hoursPlayed: I've never had the game crash on me
voteText: and rarely suffer any slowdown
helpfulPercent:
but I can hear the effort it takes for my computer to ensure my enjoyment on The Island.


"Is ARK the game for me?"

ARK is the game for everyone

reviewText:
Early Access Review

------[edit 14/08/2015]------

Before posting comments to say I was playing PVP... I was playing PVE!

Thanks to anyone who read the review and are actually posting relevant comments.

------[end edit 14/08/2015]------


------[Original Review]------


I'll start with noting that a refund has been requested.

Toxic players. Toxic community. I don't care that the game is buggy as anything - It's early access. I'd come to expect it.
Dying within minutes of playing, by people who have nothing better to do, other than kill you a few minutes afer you spawn. Infuriating.

Reading comments from players who have put hundreds of hours into the game, who have now chosen to abandon the game, due to the toxic community, has lead me to request a refund and wash my hands of a bad experience (2 hours gameplay - requested today, so unsure whether will get approved / when)

I've read story, after story of players who login after a day, to come back to all their hard work completely destroyed.
Players spend hours having to rebuild and re-do everything they have worked hard for - leading to diminutive progression. Regression. Abandonment.

Even when I played for the short time, I found abandoned buildings, looted, with nothing left but scrap.
Every person I encountered (on more than one server) killed me, without question (all high level, who could clearly see I was low level).

I don't wish to put any more time into something that others, sadly, have made unplayable / unenjoyable.

People have suggested private servers, or creating a local host.
What's the point in having loads of players, when you disable the ability to do just that.

To me, the game is badly designed. To design something that makes it easy to be a toxic and destructive player, rather than the ability to set the rules, etc. I feel the devs should look into.

Not for me.

Hope I get my refund. If not, then I at least hope that other players learn from my experience, before purchasing.


------[end Original Review]------

Steam have approved my refund. Thankfully I can just move on

i cant stop playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the shining example of a great idea, no...amazing idea held back by various technical limitations or issues. It's just too shoddily executed and put together at the moment. The word that I associate with ARK: Survival Evolved is most definitely inconsistency. ♥♥♥ Rape at your Keyboard was another thing I associated A.R.K. to, as that is what it feels like while playing, but jokes aside this game suffers from a roller coaster experience of execution.  From the good, such as the various dinosaurs, building and weapon variety, and graphics, to the bad; Spawns, AI behavior, and right down to various game mechanics. Worse yet is that all of these factors just end up resulting in a very, very frustrating experience. I have never been so angry at a video game before, because at every single turn I kept wanting to like this game more and more only to get frustrated just as equally.

To get into the inconsistency, let me tackle the spawning system. It's ♥♥♥♥ing ATROCIOUS. I don't even just mean your own character - as you will frequently spawn right next to a hostile creature, to die or take damage as you look at your arms with the spawn animation - but how aggressive enemies will just up and appear out of nowhere at times. Swimming down a stream? Oh, ♥♥♥♥ you here's a Megapiranha. Trudging through a swamp? Hey, check it out a Titanoboa out of the blue! Winding down the beaten path? Here's a Pulmonoscorpius(Scorpion) to ♥♥♥♥ your day up. As I said, they'll appear out of thin air at times, and the most mind boggling thing is when multiple of them are in the same area at once. I once ran around a corner into 4 Titanoboa's who weren't there before. Were they just chilling, shooting the ♥♥♥♥ before coming out to ♥♥♥♥ up the next guy? I guess so. They probably proceeded to high-five each other afterwards as they quadruple teamed my unconscious body. I am not exaggerating. I have seen a Sarcosuchus(Crocodile) rise up from beneath the map to give chase to me. It's ludicrous.

It doesn't even stop at hostile creatures. Even neutral creatures that don't typically attack you, will sometimes out of the blue start a fight with you. I was attempting to tame a Gigantopithecus(aka Jack Links Jerky Sasquatch), and was at it for like an hour and a half when suddenly he just became aggressive at a roaming dinosaur that passed by. The aggression carried over and he attacked me, resulting in my own tamed creature killing him. What the ♥♥♥♥? Why? What even caused this? I didn't even initate anything to have him attack me, nor did I wish to deal with his silly knock back attacks that throw me half way across the map.

Speaking of combat, this game has the most ♥♥♥♥ poor netcode I have ever had to suffer through in a first person video game. The horror is on the level of DayZ, and I don't mean scare factor type horror. Like the zombies in DayZ, Raptors will teleport around you, at ridiculous speeds, making them the equivalent of a Dragonball Z villain. If no one has fought an Alpha Raptor yet, just fasten your seatbelt for essentially a dinosaur with the Kaioken ability. It even ♥♥♥♥ing glows red, I kid you not. Without having a tamed dinosaur to use gigantic AoE's on their attacks to counter the sillyness of the bad hit detection, coupled with some dinosaurs who will displace themselves to all sides of you during combat, I have a hard time imagining you winning any real fights here in a planned manner. Combat just ends up feeling hectic with no real finesse to it(READ: inconsistent). Look at this video. both showcasing the Kaioken Raptor and the combat. Does this scream fun and exciting? He was the local host with cheats enabled, now imagine that with actual lag/latency and getting mauled to death by it.

Still pounding at the inconsistent nature of ARK here, but another factor is the temperature system. It's absolutely bogus beyond belief. I froze to death while inside a cabin with torches and a fire place while being clothed. How is this possible exactly? Other times my character will be freezing....on a tropical beach, mid-day with the Sun in the center of the sky, while wearing hide armor. Then I will proceed to suffer a ridiculous heat wave, dehydrating my character completely. Being cold conversely means you get hungry often as well, which is a very neat concept...if it was done right. It just ends up feeling comical. I stuffed my face with about 30 slabs of cooked meat overnight during a stay in the cold north due to this system. Essentially I had about 10 dinosaurs worth of meat in my stomach, yet I still found myself getting hungry again because it was <30 degrees outside. Uh, okay. The amount of meat I packed in my stomach would have clogged my colon about 50 times over, and instantly given me gout. I'd be more likely to die from constipation or clogged arteries than the starvation that happens because you're cold. If you're a lowbie or just somewhere without immediate access to meats, you're probably going to go berry hunting and stuff your face with every little thing you can see every 5 ♥♥♥♥ing seconds.

There's so much more frustrating and inconsistent things I could mention such as the horrendous building placement system, but honestly I am absolutely exhausted. I've tried giving this game a chance, I really did. I tried letting the frustration subside time and again when I died to some random ♥♥♥♥. However...the game mechanics end up being too incoherent and illogical to really feel overall enjoyment in your experience. The amount of satisfaction you'll feel from taming your first big dinosaur is completely negated and dashed by it dying to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat, or overnight when you're not online. The game is also horrendously optimized, and feels like one of those titles you have to drop $2,000+ USD on a rig to comfortably play. And even those monster rigs will likely suffer FPS dips.

Come back when this game is released. Too many issues currently.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where do I begin. This game has a wonderful concept; survive on an island teeming with dinosaurs for you to hunt, tame and ride. And for the most part it realizes that concept well. The graphics and sounds are quite pretty (if somewhat demanding) and it's a fun experience for about half the time.

The other half the time is when the game falls apart. That video at the top that shows a T-Rex rampage through a gate chasing someone down? Never gonna happen. What IS going to happen is that you and your tribe will spend weeks building a strong base, setting up plant turrets and taming dinos, and when you log out for the night to get some sleep some ♥♥♥♥wit will punch a hole in your walls, kite your dinos to someone else's base so they get killed by that person's turrets, and steal all your hard-earned resources. And more than likely throw them away since this is the kind of asshat who keeps a shack in the woods and only plays to ruin the game for other people. And the game has no way to police these jokers, since (unlike most other players) they dont care about advancing, so they dont have big bases and tamed dinos, and even if you manage to find every thatch hut they have and destroy everything, they'll just laugh it off and start over again since, again, they are only here to ♥♥♥♥ with other players.

The single player is surprisingly dull; the lack of ai controlled humans to interact with makes the game feel empty even with all the dinos around, building anything beyond wood is pointless as any dinos who could actually destroy a wooden structure wont bother unless you ♥♥♥♥ them off, and without an actual end goal the game gets dull and repetitive quickly.

PVE servers arent much better, with people dropping foundations and pillars anywhere they want to stop people from building, making land impossible to come by and essentially forcing you to join one of the big alpha-tribes just so you can actually play the game. It gets even worse when you try to run a cave, since on PVE people can wall off entire sections of the map and feel confident that no one can stop them from monopolizing resources. Its a disturbing showcase of how even the most whimsical fantasy game stops being fun when it gets too close the real world.

TLDR: Singleplayer is dull, PVE is impossible if you dont wanna be part of a super-tribe, and PVP on an official server just is not fun since every third time you log on you'll be starting from scratch with all stone tools. If there was someone around who could invoke a ban on players whose only objective is to ruin the game for everyone else, it might be worth while. But the devs either dont care or are incapable of setting that up. Don't waste your money on this game, or if you do wait until it goes on sale and play a private server.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ARK: Survival Evolved is a game with a lot of potential, but until more balancing is done I can not give this game a good review. Individuals who have played this game for 500+ hours make the game unplayable as they roam the official servers raiding and destroying player's bases that took hours and even days to build in a matter of less than an hour. If you are a low level on one of these official servers you have almost no chance to rise to the top or even slightly advanced due to your dinos that took 10 hours to tame dying in 30 seconds to a level 120 argentavis or all your resources being taken by high levels with guns while all you have is pikes (being in a tribe wont help as they can 1vsInfinity with those birds). No matter what official server you join it will happen because the high levels believe they own the server and do these things just for sport.

Now you might ask, why not just join a private server or create your own private server to play with your friends without constant harrassment by the people willing or with the time to put hundreds of more hours into this game than you? First of all, unless your computer has a lot of RAM you are not hosting your own server and even then one person might have to have two computers with one of them being able to host the server and the other being able to run the game (both take a lot of RAM and CPU so for many people this isn't practical). You could also join another private server hosted by a third party but there is no gaurantee that it will actually be any better than the official servers and they are less reliable than either a public or private server your friends are hosting. Regardless, resorting to a privite server should not be necessary to enjoy a PvP experiance on ARK as the official servers should provide that.

Now, throughout this review you might be wondering why I haven't mentioned PvE as an option, as in PvE players can't kill eachother. That's because PvE itself has another set of issues relating to trolls who build in places inconvienent to you with the knowledge that there is little you can do to stop them. Higher levels might even troll by building around your small thatch base as you are just starting out. Also, sometimes you want to just enjoy a legimate PvP experiance with other players where the fights seem fair and losing them is a result of your tribes inability to properly strategize or engage rather than fights that were doomed at the start due to a huge level discrepancy between the players in each tribe.

Overall, I think ARK: Survival Evolved has good mechanics and great features that give it a lot of potential, but until more balancing is done with regards to players I can not recommend this game to someone who just wants to have some fun in a short amount of time. Accomplishing anything in this game takes way too much time in proportion to how quickly everything can be killed and destroyed that it just isn't worth playing this game if you can't play it for more than 8 hours a day. I hope by full release next year the game is more balanced, but until then I am not recommending this game as a practical game to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoy this game. It has enough content to be fufilling. However, in it's current state, it is unbalanced and funamentally flawed. It's a time sink, and it's not in a good way.

Caves are an interesting feature in the game. You can set up a base, and be nearly indestructible. It's a very strong strategic position, but it makes for a very unfair game. Trexs can hit through walls, killing players and destroying chests and  items that took you hours to make, in seconds. Spiked walls meant to defense against this are worthless. Trexs and large carnivores do AOE damage which hits things through walls. Guns do minimal damage to players, meaning unless you're on a trex, you can't really fight back. You can still push players through walls. You can remove glare using the debug screen. You can remove foliage. All of which provide an advantage for those willing to cheat.

So far, I haven't had any real pvp experience on a pvp server. What it boils down to is base raids. Players attack eachothers bases when they're offline. I had a tribe of 10 players, all playing for about 200 hours. 2000 hours of total gameplay was destroyed in less than 30 minutes.

I'm really a fair guy. I want to recommend this game, but it's honestly best to just wait until it's balanced. The game will be complete and you'll have a fun, fresh, exploit free experience.

PVE servers are a suitable alternative, but that removes a large chunk of the fun.

The game is early access, obviously, but I can't justify spending four hours to tame an animal that is going to die overnight. I've avoided that for the most part, and focused on base building. Bases are just as easily lost.
