reviewText:
Early Access Review

(My Final evaluation is at the end of the review)

Saying i don't recommend this game at this stage is both true and false.. because it depends greatly on your PC setup. (I change the review as the game hopefully progresses)

Having played game for many hours now i experienced more low than highs, as it is the first thing that should be pointed out. While i don't have a high end pc, it is more than powerful enough to handle many of the latest games on 720p-1080p with a decent amount of 20 at it lowest and more than 60 fps and nearly the highest settings.

My first experience i had on ARK however, after lagging (horribly) on preset settings and without launch option, i had to tweak a lot, the game and my PC's setting to average of 8-12 fps in the game.. and while the ONLY option to actually affect the fps more than 0.10 being the scale resolution i can turn most of the setting to high or epic without losing 1 fps at all.

Which brings me to PvP, while you can be wiped out horribly before you even started, should you however managed to survive and thrive, everything can be lost over night. Since the game relays on faced paced combat and quick reactions.. if you one of the people with lower fps like me.. there is virtually no chance to survive at all.

Going from the fps to another issue, random freezing of the game (in the most impossible situations) as those freezes & lags were the cause for at least 90% of my deaths (leaving out the sucides i have to commit in order to be able to log in the next time i get on). Entering a cave is basically impossible, as the fps drops to a maximum of 4 inside of them, and you're dead before you know you were not alone in there.

And as mentioned.. suicide, just for the sake of being able to log in the next time.. everything started fine and normal, until one sudden day it kept timing out while i tried to log in.. it was still in a early stage, and it almost drove me to rage quit before asking a friend to kill me, as it was the last resort before demanding a refund.. While that might work, it is still a very frustrating thing to do.. over and over..


BUT, that doesn't meant there isn't anything good to say about the game, we see updates with fixes and new content almost every day, and the player community that i've met so far is the best in any Online game i have played so far.

However, with that said, the cons outweigh the pros by far.. unless you got at least a Nvidia GTX 750.. or better, in which case most of the stated performance issues will not apply.. but for people not packing a high end graphic card, the games performance will be our worst enemy, and not the Islands predators.

(EDIT #1)

At this point i cannot Recommend this game for people who just want to casually play, or for people with a low Performence PC. At this early stage of the early access most people with have to put up with alot of stressful and frustrating moments (i know i have) And a lack of content can get boring very quickly.

And as i believe the best experience will be once the game sees it's official release.

Just as a Final note, i really want to thank the developers for their dedication and hard work brining a lot of updates (both fixes and further content). But as a player with a not optimal PC setup i also hope for future updates focusing more on optimization and performance, as it is a much needed, as it is a much needed fix" for many players to keep enjoying the game and help it grow in this early acces stage."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game caught my attention at the first glance.
The game has a lot of potential, especially for a game that is in Early Access, and to be honest, the game seems to be well developed with only few bugs which are usually not gamebreaking.
When you start the game you will first get to the character creation view, which at this time is fairly limited, as there is only one female and one male face/hairstyle. After that you get to spawn into the world, which is always somewhere near the coast of The Island.
Next you will have to survive by crafting tools, weapons and clothes and eventually start building a shelter/home.
The game might seem to have a steap learningcurve, but it is actually not that difficult to figure out how to make the items needed to survive and sustain a fairly good base.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The second section of this is my original review of this game when I only had roughly 100 hours into it. Now, as you can see, I have far more. All my experiences come from the 'official' servers. Things are much different in private servers.

I would still say to avoid this at full price. The game is a blast if you enjoy building and taming creatures but is riddled with bugs and glitches. This is also a game that you can't just 'go it alone' if you want to get to the very advanced stuff and still have a life.
Pros:
-Lots of building and crafting
-Taming of dinosaurs because I mean really? Who doesn't love dinos.
-Enough content to keep you busy for several weeks/months
-Fairly challenging survival, especially at the start. Even now I still die occasionally if I'm not careful.
-Options of both PvP and PvE servers

Middle ground:
-Without help or 'tribemembers' it takes far too long to farm out resources and forget about high level dino tames. Some people can work around this like I have, others might find it a deal breaker.
-Options of both PvP and PvE servers. This one is tricky, most of the PvP servers have been taken over by 'alpha' tribes that wipe out lesser tribes when they start to get to a respectable size but there are still a few that are ok. However, the PvE servers are so flooded with players and structures that can't be destroyed that you can't get the full feel of things due to dead spawn points and/or missing resources.

Cons:
-Still lots of bugs, the 'reel back' I mention below is still very much in effect.
-Poor server performance, fps is still low and structures of any respectable size take far too long to load in.
-No true 'end game' to speak of (yet). They do have boss arenas and such in the patch notes for later
-The new dino AI is funky and very annoying, making it nearly impossible to tame a high level dino without glitching it into something.
-Spawns can be difficult on highly populated servers, both for resources and dinos. If a structure is built even remotely close to a spawn point, that spawn point effectively becomes 'dead' with no increase in other spawn points.
-Spawn points are all set to a standard. For example if a rich spawn is in one place, it will continue to be a rich spawn regardless of how many times the timer pops. There's no chance of a minor or lesser resource spawning.


Original Review:
Fascinating and probably one of the better open world sandbox style of games. Also the level of detail that is apparent in the skill trees is impressive.

However......... The game is not optimized in the least bit. My system easily bests the minimum requirements (and I mean to the point where it's silly to even question) yet my game lags and stutters with a top fps range of about 20 all while having the sound and sky effects off. The real annoyance is what I call a 'reel back' , the game will stop allowing actions for 1-2 min and then basically rewind you to wherever you were at before the glitch started. It's not like I ran into a wall and the game is fixing me since the entire game rewinds: dinos, sky effects, time of day etc etc to where it was only a couple minutes ago.

I plan on continuing my play since I spent so much on the game already but for everyone on the fence it might be better to wait a bit, it is still in the testing phase after all and they're charging almost full game price for it. If things get better I'll stop back by to update this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jurassic (P)Ark with Alien Pylons"Story
You wake up on a mysterious planet at an unknown time. Your left arm contains a strange rhombic implant. You are surrounded by a few harmless dinos. It will be short and you will feel hunger and thirst and at night even some freezing. Beat some trees with your barehands and collect some stones at the beach. Every step you take gives you XP and you will levelup quickly. Learn the engrams for simple tools and start build up some primitive hut out of thatch. That's how every story begins.
Graphics
Amazing graphics. Ofc everything depends on your rig. But if you use the ShaderModel5 under DirectX11 textures should look like corny sand and living jungle. But In the last time there are unexplainable framedrops and freezes compared to the very beginning of my play. The game (further-) development seems to be running. But the graphics edges makes it still unconvenient to play smoothly. Also it still runs in a weird fullscreen/scaled window mode which bringup several times the windows mousepointer. Real fullscreen use is not possible because the game crashes then. The most visions of your character seem very blurry. Ofc there are sharp textures on dino skins and even lens flares into the sun. But during the daytime change it's hard to compose one full sharpen screenshot.
Gameplay
It's fun to play for the struggle of life. Hunger and lack of resources forces you into a very active gaming. Always be aware of attacking carnivores. The Dino AI is maybe the best they can do. But sometimes it's ridiculous how dinos get stuck in the landscape or chasing you til death. The taming of dinos
recommended: and building of houses can be your new best time-wasting hobby. Ofc in the endgame it turns into grinding for some very rare resources and insane requirements to craft a high tier weapon or ammo.\nStableness\nUnfortunately the stableness has changed from somekind of ok to weak. Idk the reason for this but if you follow the development you'll notice many content addings (new dinos
hoursPlayed: bosses
voteText: landscapes
helpfulPercent: caves
votesHelpful:
maps) but a hesistating way to announce stableness improvements. Just read some shadow rendering up to 30%. But if I ran shadows on low and the game crashed more often than earlier that improvement is ineffective.
Achievements
This is the poorest part of the game. They are adding slowly achievements which could also make fun to complete the game. Usually most players reached them already in Early Access without unlocking them. But there's no QA on achievement development. Instead of giving an achievement for each dino tamed they use some strange sumup of all initial dinos tamed or killed. The Artifacts gathering achievement was never working and got messedup with adding new caves but also revoking some other artifacts. Short: for achievement hunters it's a nightmare.
Modbase
The modbase is amazingly high grown. I would say like in Skyrim. From advanced medieval architecture to Boss taming and Ressource stacking seems each one very useful if you are through with the vanilla game.
Common Complaints
Introducing Battleeye was a ragequit for many gamers. Didn't know BE before and I wonder why it is so neccessary for the main game if the free PvP mod "Survival of the Fittest" does it need even more. Other complaints are more funny like Why does my Direwolf not lay eggs? or Why did my for 100 hours buildup base get cruely raided on a PvP Server?
Conclusion
ARK is a fun game with very nice graphics. It is still an unique project with lots of potential. But devs have to work hard to give back stabilitiy and deny more disappointments. IMO it's insufficient to just add more content ...
I recommend playing ARK because not recommending it would be an overreact."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The SteamOS/Linux version is very broken graphically and hasn't really been touched since its release. The black particles bug being the most prominent, which can cause the game to be almost unplayable at times. This and a LOT of other bugs have been pointed out repeatedly but not been so much as acknowledged until recently when we were told the as-of yet unreleased XBone version took priority.

To break it down to its simplest form, what is most important to the devs is the money they don't have yet. Once you have paid your concerns are no longer important because they have your money. Currently there is a 5000 post strong thread telling the devs how broken one of their new dino implementations is. The devs have only just now after a month of the thread's existence acknowledged that they did in fact screw up. Lack of communication, trying to direct users to other forums so they can better police dissenters, constant regression of once solved bugs, and general arrogance when it comes to the mistakes they make, makes this games development an unpleseant experience.

If poor performance, Korean MMO grind, and being treated like a second class citizen once you have handed your money over are your kinda thing, go for this game, otherwise stay far away until at least the game's full release. Even then, make sure all the grind and early access quirks have actually been fixed and not just swept under the rug. There are far better Early Access games out there for you in the meantime.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An Ark that Sinks

I want to be able to recommend this game, but in all honesty, I can’t.  Not right now at least. It’s a treadmill to nowhere. If you have a job, you can’t play this game. You don’t have the hours in the week. It’s a shame because the idea of open world PVP Turok-reminiscent FPS is really cool.


Ark right now has some technical optimization problems, but that’s to be expected. It’s in alpha and anybody who expects this game to run well or be optimized, at this stage, is somewhat naïve.

Ok, let’s start with the top: The grind. It’s huge. It’s long. It’s cumbersome. It doesn’t take so long to gather various resources, but some combinations make absolutely no sense and are far out of proportion to what you’re making, that it becomes a clear slowing mechanic rather than a compliment to the game. At what point would anybody need to harvest the 40 animal hides to make a single bed? Why the hell do I need 15 hide to make a mortal and pestle? Have the Devs seen a mortal and pestle? Animal hide doesn’t come into this equation.

And a lot of this game is longwinded and drawn out to no purpose. Taming dinosaurs – depending on what you aspire to, this can be a relatively painless process, but really anything more than a Dodo or one of the minor-raptor things, is going to take a very long time. Doesn’t sound so bad – you’ve got to work at good things, right? Correct. But your dinosaurs won’t be there the next time you log in. They’ll be dead. At some point, you will have to sleep. When you do, someone will night-raid your bunker, and kill your dinosaurs.  That’s 15 minutes to several hours that have just been wasted. And you will be doing this over and over and over gain.

Same thing with bases. You can spend hours gathering all the resources to build a base, put down a bed, put down a storage container. Log off. Go to work, go to the pub, come back, generally live your life. Log on. You’re dead. Your base has been raided and destroyed. Your dinosaurs are dead. Your storage chest is gone, all your resources are gone. Time to rebuild. Rinse, repeat ad infinitum.

While going back and gathering all the resources you will be hot-footing it to the nearest water sources repeatedly because hunger and thirst are a nightmare. Some people have defended this as a great mechanic. It’s not. Not in its current state. You have to eat several hundred berries, or the equivalent of a mammoth, every day, to survive. You can kill so many animals, cook so many steaks, and you will go through them like wildfire. Mashing the E key is not a game mechanic. It’s tedious.  Slow it down and it will become interesting. At the moment, you’re just constantly watching your hunger/thirst drain at ridiculous speed. If that means they have to tweak the gathering values: yes. Do it. People ask what I’d do if I weren’t harvesting berries. I don’t know, play the game? Kill a dinosaur? Kill a player? Build a base? Go get one of the beacons? You know, something interesting.

The gameplay, collectively, creates a strange emergent nihilist’s paradise. Ark is Sisyphean. Everything you build, everything you gain, everything will be destroyed.

And you will push the boulder back up the hill and it will roll back down again. And again. And again. The result is that nothing you do here will matter. Any and all effort you make is wasted. The final result of that is that you end up with a game that is a trolls paradise. See a base? Build a spike wall in front of the door. Is that a narrow pass? Build walls across it.  Did those guys just enter a cave? Quick, board up the cave mouth. You stop trying to play the game to get anywhere and you start playing to game to inconvenience everyone else in a futile attempt to get back at every unseen person who has done the same thing to you while you slept.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am giving this a recommendation, but with some caveats.....

The game is amazing, it is one of the most beautiful games that I have played. The environment is amazing, the creatures are amazing. It is a ton of fun both from the PVE side of things to the PVP side of things. For an EA title it is one of the best that I have played. In my opinion it is better and more playable than some AAA fully released titles that I have played. I have too many hours in as it stands now and cannot stop playing for long, still.

The bad.......

You need a powerful computer to have an enjoyable experience with this game. Do not get it thinking that your midgrade from 4 years ago PC that plays some AAA titles that were developed for consoles very well will play this very well. It will not, Ark will most likely bring your potato to it's knees. The minimum specs for this game will lead you to a bad experience.

The public servers for this game are pretty lame. PVE servers are for the most part rife with structure spam and griefing. The PVP servers are for the most part dominated by a few alpha tribes. Not to say that either will not be enjoyable, they will for a bit, maybe even longer depending on the tribe you align with. They need more active moderation, which is coming according to the developer.

The developers for the game are great, releases and new content have come at a break neck pace. With that being said sometimes it seems the important things are not being addressed in a timely fashion. The developers have also not hit a single target release date/time that they have set. Not a huge deal but don't hang your hat on any specific time they set :)

I am recommending the game, but also very serious about the performance issues if you do not have a well maintained powerful system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros-
Amazing Graphics
Great Survival Experience
Addicting, great with friends
Never bored, new content every week

Cons-
Lag is a major issue for almost everyone, can ruin the game in intense situations
Everything you own can be destroyed while you are offline, either by players or by wild dinos
This includes yourself, meaning you can die while you are offline, and your dinos
A few bugs, worst one I've seen so far is falling through the map and getting stuck

Overall this is actually a really fun game, but it can be very frustrating when you lose most of your progress to bugs, lag, or just because you are sleeping in real life while your dinos are getting killed. Right now it would be a 5/10, but most of these issues are fixable and I'm sure they will be resolved soon. If you want to buy this, it is currently not worth it for $30

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day1: I go to ark pvp server, learn basics and build a small thatch treehouse. Day was productive
Day2. I wake up killed by some level 50 dude. I think, well i knew this was coming, better start over. I build my house of wood this time and i tamed myself a raptor and hunted with it having a good time.
day3: i get killed, yet again by some high level player. I feel bad for my raptor. I head inland close to a mountain and build there in the forest. Spot is well hidden.
day4: I managed to tame a sabercat and I traded a saddle for it with my neighbour. Leveled it upto 30, it took a few hours. Then it got stuck inside a spino leg, i couldnt move out so i had to attack it but the pet died, so did i.
day5. I got a new pet, a pteranodon. Was fun looting the supply drops but then a player with an eagle came and killed me. I upgraded half of my base with stone, since it wasnt still destroyed because it was hidden. I played long that night. At 4 am 4 players with a spino, raptor, sabercat and an eagle came to my base, started taking down the outer wall with the spino and then naded my stone house and broke in and killed me. Stealing everything i had.

Day1 pve server: I went in, everyone was nice and helped me get started, i tamed a sabercat and traded a saddle for it. Killed 2 spinos and it got quite decent levels. Get stuck inside a spino again and died.

Basicly, in pvp players kill you every night and you lose all your progress except levels. In pve you either build big, which is boring and takes a long time. Or you hunt stuff and die to bugs. The game lags like hell with my gtx760 and medium/low settings. And there is a lot of desync. The concept is very good and I had a lot of fun in the pve server. But its just too buggy to recommend it yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Was walking the beach not far from my home when I spotted a Rex attacking a herd of Dinos.  Decided I'd get smart, and steal its meal when it was occupied with attacking another dino that was defending the herd.
Got a lot of Meat, got a lot of Hide, and ran back to my house.  Later enjoyed the evening, tamed a dilo, quickly grew attached to said Dilo.
Decided I'd try and tame another dinosaur.  While in the process, the Trex decided it'd be funny to come and eat it while I was picking berries for the dinosaur that was unconcious and being tamed.

I quickly run away, and resume doing things closer to my house.  A few minutes later, Rex stomps up, kills me, and then charges towards my house.

My brave Dilo decided he'd try and take the rex on.  For a while, as the Dilo was dodging in between the Rexes feet, biting his ankles, I thought I had one heroic dilo.  But, finally, the rex managed to snag it in his teeth.

I watched as Rex devoured my dedicated pet, and than charged me once again.  I of course ended up dying and respawned near my house.  Rex decided I had ♥♥♥♥♥♥ him off enough to tear it down.  I stupidly attack Rex with my fists, actually manage to put up a decent fight, but finally died once again.

Respawned in view of the house, and watched Rex continue to tear down my house bit by bit.  After a few minutes, Rex decides hes getting bored and takes a stroll on the beach.  I sneak back into my house, see that Rex broke all my storage containers, my sleeping bag, my crafting utilities, and pretty much just left me with 3 foundations, 2 walls, and a ceiling.

Have learned not to ♥♥♥♥ off Rexes, their major griefers, and will search endlessly until they find your house.

After 54 hours of gameplay, I can easily say this is the survival game I have been waiting for!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a $25.00 title, this is a fairly promising survival game that has absolutely nothing to do with zombies.

Given that the game is built on UE4 the performance issues that most people report are actually mostly server to client related issues and its obvious that the server still needs optimisation.  There are a few hitches and glitches with local play too but its nothing so horrible that can't be dealt with easily.

Visually the game looks great, the survival progression is pretty good and the dinosaurs, at least the predatory and carnivorous ones...will outright eat you if you don't learn how to deal with them.

There are some rough edges to the build of course, in some aspects, in regards to the shipped assets, ARK looks like a hobbyists project that was just too good not to sell...even down to the executable for the game being shipped as ShooterGame.exe"....a minor detail really but its obvious that there is still room for refinement with this title and..hopefully the huge amount of support the game has been shown since its Twitch marketing campaing will ensure that the game gets it.

Regardless
date: like pretty much all survival games
recommended: this one is in Early Access...so YMMV
hoursPlayed: but overall I find it to be a solid entry to the genre of unfinished survival games that apparently require six years of paid beta testing to succeed."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access review so anything I say now may not be relevent in a few months time.

Positives +
- Plenty of Dinosaur's and other creatures featured
- I really like the Leveling system
- Lots of crafting options
- Expansive Map
- Enjoyable Multiplayer Experience
- The Developers are really active which is good too see

With that be said there are some negatives
- Poor Optimization (GTX 770/I7-4790K & running on low/medium with occasional fps drop)
- Raptors are really OP
- Items sometimes get lost through the floor
- Price is quite high for a game in early access when compared to other survival early access titles.

*There are other things like face/hair options i'd like to see but I didn't include it as a positive/negative as I believe it's something that will be seen in a future update.

Overall I would recommend if your a fan of dinosaur or survival games, however if you are concerned then I'd suggest waiting for a steam sale and getting it cheaper.

Thanks for reading
Dragonheart, The Prince of Wales

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't get fooled by those bad reviews. People doesn't seem to understand that the performance isn't optimized yet. And this is actually the only con I can see in this game.


Pro :

- Beautiful world design
- a lot of crafting recipes
- rpg elements
- freaking dinosaurs
- you can gather different resources from the same source - depends on which tool you use
- you can poop
- single player mode - you can even transfer your character from online to singleplayer
- teamplay is very important
- the community (yes, I was surprised. the first 5 people I met randomly gathered around a fire. instead of killing each other they started helping each other out, ended up in a tribe)

Con :

- the performance is far from optimized. but other than that, it's not a reason NOT to buy in the future. if you got a weak computer you probably should wait a bit.
- they should add a qeue for the servers
- if you have bad luck you spawn in a zone with a lot of angry little dinosaurs , it's a bit hard to get started then. but it's not that much of a deal

Neutral :

- it's a  bit hard to level up imo




So if you are into survival games , if you love dinosaurs and if you enjoy playing in a team - buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought Ark a few weeks back and started to enjoy it from the very beginning.

Since then the devs have updated so much, and continue to keep new things coming I will be playing this for a very long time.

Why I like Ark:
Gameplay is engrossing and really fun, Graphics are stunning, Ambiance is amazing, Controls are easy and fluid, Replayability is off the scale, Strategy (pet/party choices etc) is rewarding and punishing, a total 5 star from me because together all these make Ark my #1 game without doubt!

Pos v Neg votes:
I see many of the negative votes are people complaining about the FPS and optimization of the game. I have an average PC and can run the game perfectly whilst also running the server for my friends to play with me. If you know what youre doing and dont have everything turned full (including console commanded options), you can run it just fine. People should not neg vote Ark for reasons of your own incompetancy sorry (just my opinion).

TL;DR BUY IT, ITS AMAZING !!!! 10000/10

PS. A Bronosaurus pooped on me as I was running underneath it, what more do you want !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this to try only because of Steam's new return policy. Policy not necessary. Other survival games don't draw me in like this one did. It looks good; it plays well. I actually want to explore. Leveling isn't a grind. In fact, I don't even pay attention to it. I just play and that's what I really love about the game. I'm content building, hunting, and exploring. People are friendly for the most part. Characters are server-bound so don't forget to write down your server name!

Today, met another player taming a huge crocodile. Helped him out. Joined his tribe. We now have a triceratops, two parasaurs (like Ducky), two dinos (spitters), and that big ♥♥♥ croc as mounts and pets.

10/10 Would form a dino posse again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has so much potential and is even quite fun at times as you ride and fight with pet dinosaurs, and explore and build bases.

However you will grind for hours and hours for resources; chop down a whole forest to make a little fence.  Smash fields of boulders to make a small stone pestle and mortar to grind things in.  Taming the dinos takes hours upon hours.  You have to wait for a weekend when you can play all day to get one more dinosaur.  Spending all day for each one makes you emotionally invested and it is very stressful since they will die on you.

Its permanent death for your pets.  It's also when a clan mate accidentally kills one of your pets and it is awful if you accidentally lose one of theirs.  Even on PVE this game will suck away hours of your life and cause grief and loss.  You will get stuck having to play hours and hours more than you would like to.

I just watched my daughters baby raptor that she spent all day breeding and raising suddenly die.  She is going to be so upset.  Again and Again you spend hours and hours on things and can loose them in an instant.  I love the creative potential but Ark Survival Evolved is more of a prison yard than a playground.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This will be a fairly long review because I want to highlight all of the problems I find with this game so you know going in what to expect. Keep in mind that this is early access and I do recommend this game. While I find this game enjoyable, they still have a lot of work to do, and when they fix some of the major issues, this game could be one of my favorite games.

Performance:
This game is extremely laggy for no other reason than it's poorly optimized, if it is at all. I have 8 gbs of ram and a decent internet connection and can run most games on high graphics. I have to play this game on low graphics in order for it not to be a chugging mess. This problem is exacerbated since the world has so much going on, with there being so many plants and rocks and destuctible stuff just lying around, it makes the lag even worse. Even with everything on the lowest settings, there are times when it will have a severe lag spike that lasts for several seconds.

Visuals:
Since a lot of people have to run the game on low, let's start with that. It's aweful. Everything looks as if it's made of putty and it looks like it was colored by kids using water colors. If you can run it on medium or better, you are in for a treat. The difference between low and medium is huge. The game looks beautiful on medium, the models look great and the colors are a lot crisper and more vibrant.

Dinosaurs:
You have the famous dinos as well as some cool, but more obscure dinosaurs and they plan on adding more in the future. I don't really have too many complaints in this area and can only wait to see what they add in the future.

Bugs:
One of the dinosaurs is a large bug that looks like ants with wings. I feel that they should be nerfed as they are currently really strong and can easily kill anyone who isn't prepared. They attack in groups of 3-6+, have a poison that gets rid of your stamina so you can't run away, do a lot of damage which quickly adds up with an entire swarm of them attacking you at the same time, and the worst part, at least for me, they often cause a lag spike that completely freezes the game for 5+ seconds. When you see them ahead of time, there isn't lag, but for some reason if they pop out of nowhere, the game would just completely freeze. I had this happen two times, both times it was only because I had some of my dinosaurs with me so they were able to kill them, but it was close and I barely had any health remaining when my game started working again.

Taiming:
This game uses a very interesting method to taim dinos. You have to knock them out and then feed them either meat or berries/vegetation, as well as narcotics or narcoberries to keep them unconcious. It's odd, but I think it's a cool little system. The problem I do have with the taiming system is that even the weak, basic dinosaurs take a while to taim when they get to a high-ish level. If something is level 60 or over, it will likely take at least a half hour to taim it. A level 120 Bronto, currently the longest time to taim, takes about 3 hours with the best food possible, which is extremely expensive and time consuming to make, as well as having a short lifespan before spoiling, and with regular berries, it takes over 14 hours to taim it, assuming someone doesn't come along and kills it or it runs out of food and rapidly loses taiming progress.

Sound:
The game sounds pretty good and they have been adding to the sounds the dinos make. The crafting sound is annoying, it sounds like a metal hammer tapping on a metal table. Normally it's annoying, but tolerable, but with things like arrows which get made in less than a second, the nonstop barrage of sound is enough to drive anyone insane. There really should be a slider specifically for the crafting, since at the moment it's in with the sound effects, which includes all of the dinos and other things I do enjoy.

Building:
I have a love-hate relationship with the building system. It isn't all that restrictive, while at the same time being realistic. You can build large structures, you can build on special platforms on some of the larger dinosaurs, and you have to add supports to your structure, you can't just have a massive building floating in the sky and supported by one foundation on the side. That being said, it uses a snap system that is atrocious. You can't rotate objects with a key or anything like that, you have to finagle your mouse in just such a way that the game finally gives you the orientation and placement you want. Fences are especially bad since they have to be connected to work and can rotate 300 degrees when you're trying to place them, and for the most part it will jump from one extreme to the other with it being very difficult to get it to go straight or make a 90 degree angle. Slopes, sloped roofs, etc. are a huge pain since they're almost always ridiculously oriented and will only go the way you want if you move it into a very tiny window. You better have surgeon-like precision or extreme patience if you plan on building anything.

That's everything I can think of for the moment, might add more later. With all of its faults, I do enjoy it and suggest that even if you don't want to buy it now, check it out when it is fully released. As long as they don't do a massive overhaul and completely change the entire thing, I can see this as something that will continue to be fun and only get better over time.

Dino AI:
The dinosaur AI is extremely annoying when it comes to following you. They will get stuck on every tree, rock, and dinosaur in their path. They won't try and go around it even if that means moving three feet to the left; they will just continue to walk into it until you walk behind them so they get unstuck. You have to be extremely careful or you will lose your dinosaurs. Your dinosaurs also won't be able to walk through a door 90% of the time. I have had the dinosaurs walk up to the door and then decide to just walk right and get stuck on the wall. These weren't big dinos trying to walk through a small door, these are dilos who can easily fit and sometimes do, but getting them out tends to be just as big of a hassle. The flying dinosaurs are horrible when they are following you. They will circle you at head level and bump you, go in front of you, etc. This makes it annoying to walk with them following you, and even more annoying if you are trying to attack a different dinosaur, as they will get in front of your attacks. Smarter dinos would be nice and far less frustrating.

Temperature:
A great idea that was poorly implemented. You get hot or cold depending on your surroundings. If you're hot, you have to go into water or shade and stop moving to cool down. If you're cold, you can carry your torch, stand next to a fire, go indoors, or run to get warm. The problem is that there seems to be about a 5 degree celcius range in which you aren't overheating or freezing. These statuses will affect how fast your stamina and food/water drains, at least as far as I can tell. Most areas of the island are either too hot or too cold, and it's annoying trying to remain in the small range that's fine. Armour adds hypo and hyperthermia resistances, with most armour making you more likely to overheat and offering protection from the cold.It's a pretty small island and yet the temperature ranges from 40+ degrees to 0 degrees and below just by going from the south side of the island to the north side.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this review is Early Access. The game has a lot of potential and I'd love nothing more than for it to succeed.

Right now, though, even with a fairly good machine (running most things at the highest graphical settings), ARK chugs along at anything above 'Potato'. That's all there is to it, the gameplay is solid, the survival and crafting aspects are rich, the concepts are interesting and engaging...plus, you know, dinosaurs.

It's a shame to see a game like this with so much to offer suffer from such poor optimization. I'll be checking back, of course, as more updates roll out and the game keep improving, but for now, even on sale, save your money until the massive memory problems are sorted out.

Here's my specifications if you'd like to compare:
AMD FX-8150 Eight-Core Processor (3.6GHz)
16GB RAM
NVIDIA GeForce GTX550 Ti [4GB VRAM](All drivers up to date)
Running Windows 7 Ultimate 64-bit/DX11

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ark Survival Evolved is an Early Access Dinosaur Survival Game. I have over 1,000+ hours on it and know a LOT about it. This game is for people that have a lot of free time or it just isn't that fun elsewise. The game is very slow, grindy, progressive, and rewarding. There are multipliers which can fix that by making it go faster, but if they are set too high they can make the game not fun and extremely cheaty.

Taming: 5/10 (Is extremely time consuming and simple)
Crafting & Inventory: 6/10
Dinosaur & Creature Design: 9.8/10
UI: 6/10 (Needs work)
Graphics: 8.7/10
Animations: 5.6/10 (Decent)
Multiplayer: 8/10 (Really fun to play with friends)
Singleplayer: 6/10 (Game is a tad bit boring without other players, but it is still fun)
Content Amount: 10/10

Overall Rating: 9.4/10

I gave it this score because most of the flaws in the game are due to the fact that it is in Early Access.

How many hours will you get out of this game no matter who you are? Between 100-2,400
Thank you for reading my review. If you would like to see more of my reviews, check out my profile.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Idea Still Needs Some Work.

I'm going start off saying that this game can be fun. I have spent a little over 100 hours and I can say most of it has been a pleasant experience. In my opinion when people market games as Survival" I think it's misleading. If you want a survival experience you can load up single player and enjoy. When it comes to multiplayer it becomes more about reaching optimal strength and stamping out any opposition. Take DayZ and every other zombie survival game out there. The difference between ARK and these games is the time it takes to reach optimal strength. In dayz it can be done quickly
date: but ARK has a leveling system. Now ARK's system isn't inherently bad. I actually enjoy it more than the others. It has a level system and when you level up you get a certain number of points to put into this long list of fun crafting items. It takes time and this kind of system is good in a way that it gives people goals. Unlike DayZ my interactions with players my level was more than a bullet coming from the tree line. Most were friendly
hoursPlayed: and didn't try to kill me on sight. The problem begins when the players who have already reached optimal strength
voteText: and there isn't anything to do other than raid and kill
helpfulPercent: find your base. They will rain down upon you with a force that will make your head spin to which you have no chance of defending against. In Dayz a well placed pistol shot can save you from the man with the assault rifle. In ARK you can do little more than stand and watch as the man with a level 220 T-Rex demolishes you and your base taking all your items with him.\n\nAnother problem I have with this game is the taming. Now before I continue I understand that this game is Alpha and subject to change. I am also aware it's going to have bugs. With that being said I think it is absolutely ridiculous that I have to sit at my computer for 6 hours to get a decent Dino tame. Some of the best tames will require you to watch over it for 10+ hours. Now this wouldn't be to much of a problem if it wasn't for how easy it is to lose them. Not only do you have to worry about other players killing them while your logged out
votesHelpful: but with the current amount of bugs its not even worth it. Call me unlucky but I had one Dino get stuck in a tree. I tried to cut it down and release it only to have it thrown into the air and out of sight receving a death message shortly after. Three hours wasted. Just today I tamed one of the flying creatures and was flying through the air only for it to get stuck in mid air and not move. After it ran out of stamina it ejected me from the seat causing me to fall to my death. After searching for it for almost an hour I was greeted with the death message across the top of my screen. Six hours wasted. I have also had multiple Dinos die in between 15 min server restarts. Now some people may enjoy this because they feel its hardcore
votesTotal: but for me i would rather put that time somewhere else.\n\nThis game also suffers from horrendous lag spikes which seems to only happen when your in a serious situation that can get you killed. Apart from that it has poor optimization. Now I don't have the best computer in the world
votesFunny:
but I can play more recent games such as Fallout 4 and Battlefront on max settings. I can't even play this on High without suffering huge frame rate drops. I can't even start the game up on full with 8 gigs of RAM. When I launch it I have to put it on the low memory option. This is the first time I have ever had this problem when playing a game.


In conclusion the game can be a lot of fun. I have had plenty of laughs with my friends. If you enjoy this type of gameplay and can cope with these issues then by all means purchase it and have fun. Its not how hard it is to build up in this game that bothers me. Its the soul crushing feeling you get when you lose everything. Especially when its not even from a player. I'm sure a lot of these problems will be fixed when the game is finished
commentsCount: but as of right now I can't recommend it"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access, especially following immediate pre/closed beta(some people call alpha, but defintely is not), is met with a lot of issues.  This game is WAY more polished than most games I have played in recent memories.  Especially in the survival realm.  Great promise with this game, and if you're like me whose enjoyed 7D2D, Rust, DayZ even with the bugs, this is another one to chalk to the list.  Enough people get into the Pros/Cons, but I would rather just say that you will enjoy it.

The sad fact that people STILL cannot understand meeting the demands of opening day and server hardware/OS spin up times baffels me.  Blizzard still struggles with new content release days, and you expect an early access game to flawlessly execute, when tens of thousands are looking to join in and play?

Either way, great game! They do not deserve to be voted so low in the recommendation scale at this point, but I know that this game is capable of raising back to the 95% it once was.  And deserve it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Spawn
punch a few dodos
get ambushed by a Dilo
get killed by the dilo
respawn and attack the dilo again
get killed again by the dilo
respawn, build a spear, attack again
kill the dilo
discover dilo had friends
run
10/10

Being warned that the game had massive performance issues and a buggy single player, I started my first game with a negative feeling and grafics on low. Being amazed, how bad a game can look on low, I put my grafics again on medium and SUPRISE the game is still running perfectly.

Being dropped on a mysterious island, you have to survive, build a shelter, level up (yes there are levels that you keep after death) and discover the secrets of the island.
All enemys are prehistoric creatures and some things, that belong in farytales. You start with nothing and have to punch a tree in minecraft style to build your first tool.
The first stage of equipment is simple. Grass and wood tools, spears, a sling and some grass clothes.
The second state is hunters equipment with Bow, leather cloths and some more advanced stuff.
I didnt got to the third stage of equipment yet.

Beside the first few enemys all animals have one in common: They are bigger than your. Way bigger. You have to find out how they react on you to know how to hunt them. Do they run away? How fast are they? Do they attack back? Do they behave differently in groups? Can they call for help?

The weather and environment system is very unvorgiving. The temperatur is constantly rising and falling, so your character is freezing to death or burning and need water. I died 2 times by freezing while swimming through a river and wasnt able to get out of the water (I drowned).

In the world are giant flying ?buildings? which I havent been able to explore because they were heavily guarded. I suppose there is where the action is going on. Also there are spawning smaller objects in gigantic light beams randomly over the island and giving the player stuff who reach it first.

There is a lot to discover in this game, even in its first alpha version. This isnt your regulary Rust. Not your old boring DayZ. This is something refreshing New.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It started as a good game, then great, then not-so-great to... whatever it is now.

Survival game featuring dinosaurs, what could go wrong? You arrive, you (mine)craft yourself some equipment and you survive everything the island throws at you. Taming a creature was grindy, the higher up the food chain the longer it took (A Spinosaur could take from 3 hours to 20 hours), new taming methods emerged speeding up the process.

Were you to play on a PvP server you would also have to worry about other players attacking/griefing/robbing you.

All in all it was an interesting experience that, with frequent patches, began to refine and improve over time.

Then came some heavy-handed changes, for me they were the infuriating forced" passive tames (rather than optional) where you had to spend hours sneaking behind creatures and feeding them one item at a time
date: The increased cost of behemoth gates
recommended: the even more ridiculous taming times (A Quetzal can take over a day with regular meat)\n\nIt almost feels like old days of playing Super Smash Brothers
hoursPlayed: remember the kids screaming about not picking items up and always playing "Final Destination"? Now imagine that they became developers.\n\nNow
voteText: I am not calling the developers childish

but their heavy handed "You are going to play the game our way" and catering to the "get good"/"I want to feel scared"/"Deal with it"/"CHALLENGE ME!" crowd seems toxic.

On a personal note: Bring back the river lake north of Cragg's Island!

In short

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game as a lot of great potential and the extra content received adds to it.  However, it is not enough to balance out the serious problems with player security.

I've had moments where I build something, spending hours and energy harvesting resources to make the tools > to harvest the resources > to assemble the parts > to build my dream home.  Only to have someone on or groups of raiders come in and destroy everyting I've built and robe me of everything I had.

Worse still is when it happens while you're offline.  You log off from the game, you are helpless.  Anyone can mug you in your sleep or murder you and take your stuff while they're at it.

Even the Tribes (ingame guilds) are not safe.  Anything you build belongs to them, including any tamed mounts.  So if anything you build before and after joining a tribe is theres, when you're kicked out you are left with nothing.  More wasted time and energy only to be screwed over.
It's more heart wrenching when you find out someone conned their way into gaining Tribe Admin rights, kicks everyone out and takes apart everything they had built.

So in summary:
Pros:  The game is gorgeous.
It's fun to tame, fight and survive in a jurassic world with dinosaurs.
Crafting new items as you progress along the way from a wood home > solid metal.  Crafting weapons from a spear > Rifle > Auto cannon > and full body armor.

Cons: You die, you lose everything you had on you before.  If you can't find your body and recover it in 15 mins, it's all gone.
You get a sense of paranoia 24/7 from other gamers.  You never know who you can trust if they'll just robbed you while you're offline.
Anything you build can be taken away or destoryed without giving you a chance to defend it yourself.
Getting mugged and raided while offline just spoils the fun in the game.
You'll spend hours a day in a week on something, only to log back on and find it's been taken away by someone else.  The only thing you can do is sit there, ♥♥♥♥ and moan at the loss of your time and energy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some background: I've put just over 1600 hours into this game. I ran the strongest tribe on a Public Server.

The game was very fun at first, but once you hit level 20-25 (which doesn't take long at all) all survival aspects of the game are gone. There's no longer any struggle to survive, chances are you might find yourself dying on purpose to fast travel, etc. After the survival aspect is gone, all you have left is building (which is very unintuitive in ARK), dino taming, and feeding your herd of dinos. Ok let's move on to pros and cons overal.

Pros:
+For your first day or so, this truly is a fun survival game.
+There is a lot of variety between the dinos and reasons to like/use most of them based on preference (I was the Argent King of the server)
+The island is really nice with a lot of unique scenery.
+The map doesn't tell you where you are, you have to figure it out (this might be a negative for a few).

Cons:
-THE GRIND!!!! (Everything is a grind. You need to Grind mats to build/craft. You need to grind food for dinos. Taming is a grind of spending hours looking for a dino you want with a decent level then having to baby sit it for the next 2-6 hours or longer).
-Lack of Dev response with problem players. (A single player can really damage the server by building on area of high metal spawns, building around someone else's base, players dropping foundations everywhere which kills the spawn of anything including dinos and mats for 75 meters) I have seen Dev response take upwards of a couple months, which by that time the damage is done.
-Once again, going back to griefing, there's no way to deter or retalitate.
-Raising baby dinos.... my experience of hatching a Giganato baby and raising.... I had to stay awake approx 32 hours and babysit it so it didn't die.
-The events in the game are generally pretty poor (but at least they do events I guess). The events generally spawn an uber dino such as the Dodorex (which I almost solo'd, but ran out of time, most people didn't want to risk a dino or two).
-Server lag. Server lag is really really bad on public servers. You'll experience 5-10 minutes of rubberbanding per hour (I have an excellent gaming rig and internet connection, it's actually server side lag).
-Dino claiming. Dinos have a timer where if you don't play for a week anyone can take them. This has lead to dino populations on servers going through the roof (since people never risk there dinos or kill them off) which leads to more lag. Also the other part of this issue is when a new player gets a lot of max level dinos and builds everywhere (because they're unfamiliar with an area, get lost, etc etc) and blocks tons of spawns.
-PvP virtually every server has one major tribe which controls the server. And over multiple servers I've never seen the power shift. Nothing Like having your base wiped EVERY time you log off, so you can't fight back.
-Also there is no 'end game'. Eventually the onyl thing left to do is feed your dinos so you don't feel like you wasted your time taming them. There is no challenge mid to late game at all.

There are a lot more negatives, but they're mostly minor. I put a lot of time into this game, I really enjoyed it at first. But it's terrible performance and grind are enough for me to say, stay away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(after 1st session, 48 hours straight) this game is relentless. if you can get passed the loading screen boss... then the shadows lag boss... then the reflections lag boss.... then survive the freezing raining cold while naked... then not starve to death....... then not get your face pecked off by a swarm of angry dodos ...... then not accidently wander into the other base with the aggressive 29 bronto.... then not wander too close to a horned trex.............. then you MIGHT actually build yourself a straw house and burn away 24 hours of real, actual real life time. seriously. 24 hours straight, first go. only to have it all ripped out from under you by a band of level 2 raptors... after a 3 hour hike into the mountains... your body with all your best armor and a weeks worth of food, lost in a ravine forever. your first dino pet, fallen. you stumble naked and disoriented back to your empty pitiful straw shack............. and kill another 24 real life hours.

EDIT (after 2000 hours): ... i'm still here. i'm still alive. i'm still surviving. this game has really been a blast. so many different ways to play, and so many things to do. pvp, pve, rp, murder, capture, form communities, paint, build, draw, collect, destroy, explode, fly, swim, cave dive, buidl castles, build alliances, kill your enemies, kill your friends, drugszsz, mods, and soo many different server settings. honestly, buy it. especially if its on sale. you will get your money's worth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would only play this game if you like getting owned by everything - literally. Unless you have a friend that is part of a tribe, otherwise you're pretty much screwed. It's got a great premise, and is fun for the first few hours or so, but soon you realize that it's practically impossible alone.

Playing on a PvE server is only a tad bit better. There are very helpful individuals, but the environment is impossible to deal with. You're never full or hydrated, dinosaurs that give the basic materials you need range from lvl 4 - 120, and the ones that you encounter will fall into that range, so yes, you will get destroyed by a lvl 80 bug and lose all your stuff. You spend 5 hours building up all your stuff just to have it taken away in under a minute. I wish I could have liked this game, but survival is taken a bit too extreme here.

Early Access Review

Ok. Just to be clear, i LOVE the game itself.

Pros

1.Epic Graphics/SFX
2. There are no rules when it comes to PVP.
3. Fairly balanced system overall.
4. It is in early acess which means it is subject to heavy change.

Now i started out absoloutly obsessed with this game. Dinosaurs. Who dosent like em? I do have quite a few problems with the game though, not neccecarily the content, that can be fixed overtime, but moreso the management.

Now for the Cons

1. Huge Lag Spikes (probably will be fixed)
2. Entity rubberbanding everywhere (also probs to be fixed)
3. PC Elitist, totally ♥♥♥♥♥ on MAC users there is a major non-content based update locking them out of the game for much longer than PC users, wouldnt be a big deal if it werent a Persistant environment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Devs seem to be completely out of touch with the community base, and reality. They recently nerfed dinos by as much as 1000%. The game just became a lot more grindy, a lot slower paced, and a lot less fun. They demolished any semblance of progression with dinos, removed any incentive to breed dinos, which was a really awesome system up until dinos became essentially glorified pets; there for mere aesthetics.

They fixed the gathering rates, but the HP and DMG is still nerfed heavily. The 1000% nerf I mentioned was due to dinos gathering rates being worse than a player with a metal pick/axe. Not only were they useless gatherers, they had so little HP that players with longneck rifles could one shot many of them. This happened on tons of servers, people lost dinos that they had bred and leveled quite a bit. Then they buffed HP a bit, but dmg remained low, and the amount of stats you gain per level was nerfed as well.

The only reason I'm even still playing is because I'm now on a modded server.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't buy this game,wait until full release because serious gameplay changes are happening without community approval. Another thing, after all those optimization updates,the game still is not playable enough for most of computers, if you want to play with normal launch mode you need at least a gtx970 or r9 280 minimum to play on medium settings at a wonky 60fps ish with many fps drops to 0 because of poor programming. They made updates to fix bugs and still,the same bugs are still happening,Dino's,eggs,characters falling under map,Dino's dissapear for no reason and comes back several days after loosing it. Still several game loading issues even after updates. At the moment,they balancing the Dino's and they are making them really nerfed. In fact, a Rex can't kill a small fish or a dodo bird under 3 hits, Dino's that are good for harvesting have been nerfed too,you will harvest faster by hand and the HP of the Dino's have dropped about 75% making them weak. If you plan to play on official servers only,don't get this game at all,it will take you hours to tame a single dino,you will need to stay next to a dino to protect it from other Dino's for hours and hours feeding it until its tamed. To level up it will take you weeks and months depending you want to play everyday all day long or play couple hours at the weekend and if you only play at the weekend couple hours...you don't want to be in a official server. The game is popular because of single player and unofficial servers and still,when they update unofficial servers crashes really often and nothing is really stable,you can loose all your Dino's and need to wait for rollbacks. Bugs,lags you will encounter,not fun at all. There's a limit to loose what you did in a game,there's a limit to make changes to the gameplay, and Studio Wildcards did pass this limit.

Edit: In the game trailer (from actual gameplay) they show a T Rex break into a dino gate by running thru it. First, that's false advertisement since the game is physicless ,Dino's can fall thru foundations,ceilings,ground. You can have dino heads thru walls too,if you wipe the tail of a bronto it will go thru anything,rocks,trees,walls without any collision . physicless. There's anlot of work in this game with around 30-40 Dino's to be added and they mostly add 1 ish per week,the game won't be done at release date and I'm ready to bet on that. Beta version need to be release like right now to start the optimization because that part takes time unless they think that dx12 will cover all their bugs,glitches but its not the case. They can't even run dx10 properly,imagine the work left for dx11 and dx12. If they think that it takes minimum requirements a 970 to play the game they must be drunk. Graphically on low it hurts your eyes,there's games out there that even on low, still looks OK but not ark and still,it doesn't run as fast,the game is just a map with tons of AI,nothing else and its physicless so not to demanding for a CPU. Ask yourself 7 times before buying this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't know the horror i was getting into when I decided to enter the world of ARK. It was a sunny day when me and my tribemate of The Beach Boys decided to introduce ourselves to our newly found neighbors called The Pizza Cult.
We came upon their base to find it was empty, we knocked and there was no answer so we decided to break into their compound. Only by using advanced parkour techniques were we able to jump over their wall. We overshot the wall and fell down a hill to their smaller compund.
We expected riches but only found human feces and water tanks. It was at that moment that we realized that there was no way out. We were trapped.
Unable to safetly destroy the spikes without dying we resorted to calling for help in the chat, we thought it was a good idea to tell the owners of the fort to help us. We were so wrong.
They came and used a scorpion to immobilize us. While darkness surrounded us, they began to take our blood. The Pizza Cult forced us to eat narcotics and barely kept us alive as they drained our disfigured bodies. They whispered in my ear that our blood would be the sauce of their most delicious pizzas.
I cried out and offered sexual uses of my disgusting body in exchange for freedom. They beat me and while they were distracted my tribemate escaped but told me that he was going hide and never come back. I cried some more.
They dragged my body back to my house as they stole my precious red moistness. They left me there, never to return again.

Beware The Pizza Cult. They hunger for blood.

10/10 would be a human blood bag again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

> Fart sound
> ''You defecated''
> Pick up own poop
> Fertilize lands with own poop

10/10 most next gen thing I've seen in any game.

Jokes aside, the game has a huge amount of content and I barely even scratched the surface. Currently, it's optimization is pretty bad which means you need a high end system to play on high or epic graphics and even then there are reports that the game won't get past 30 fps. The devs have been working hard and there are multiple (small and large alike) patches every day. Seeing how fast the patches are rolling out, I have good hopes for this game. But, as with every Early Access title, time can only tell.

The atmosphere is really something. The dinosaurs that graze quietly, the sunbeams flickering through the trees, the sound of waves gently breaking on the shore, it's a sight to behold. That said, it can turn around in no time as there are some really ferocious beasts that see you as food and won't hesitate to hunt you down.

Placing constructions is similar to most of the survival games out there. You gather the materials (wood, rocks, metal, thatch etc.) and craft them into the appropriate item and place them. However, learning recipes is a little different as each time you level up you gain points. WIth these points you unlock recipes. Leveling up goes rather quickly in the beginning and happens very passively by simply moving around, gathering materials, killing dodo's etc. Within no-time you have enough points to unlock all the recipes for an entire shack. As you level up more advanced recipes become available, for example, you start with a shack made of straw, when you leveled up enough you can unlock wood, even further you can make constructions out of metal. This goes for weaponry and clothing as well.

Once you are set and have some weaponry you can hunt and tame dinosaurs. The taming process is pretty aggrevating at the moment but I'm sure that gets balanced over time. Once a dinosaur is tamed you can ride it and it levels up much like yourself.

This is what I've experienced so far and will update this further in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR

Single Player:
Potentially amazing game, plagued with massive issues, poor design choices and bugs.

Multiplayer:
Same as above, but add in horrible community, hackers and elitism.
Useless co-op

Its time for me to do my review for Ark,   I will admit I've been enjoying the game and I would like to actually give a recommendation since its been the only game I've been playing lately, its potentially an amazing game with alot of good aspects, with plenty of room for growth and expansion however, currently as of 3/13/2016 I'm still not going to recommend this game due to the sheer amount of current problems that the game suffers from, many of the problems can really cripple the game and make it very frustrating.

One of the major issues is the game can get unstable with/without mods I've personally had the game refuse to run on multiple occasions and the only fix was to verify the installation, this isn't an isolated problem - its well documented and I've had a friend who had similar issues, the game would run perfectly then stop working just like that, either a driver crash or a wall of text appcrash.  Sometimes an update causes incompatiblity issues with mods, sometimes it just gets corrupted, and as such can get extremely frustrating having to deal with the problems.

The problems with the game are mostly balance issues, some dinosaurs are way too over-powered (Giga for instance).  The game also suffers from alot of weird deaths, you'll die...alot - sometimes, its your fault - other times its the games fault and you'll also lose alot of tamed dinosaurs the same way, heck I've lost a dinosaur to committed suicide by getting stuck on a standing torch...yes, the artifical stupidity is that bad sometimes.

More issues revolve around the placement of structures,  I get they went for simplicitity but sometimes, you just need better options to get the job done.  A prime example here is the power and cabling system, which is atrociously bad and really needs a major re-work, even with mods - its still a FusterCluck of a mess and something that the devs should really consider with a future patch.

Mods are a huge help to the game, but again - any modder will tell you that using them is at your own risk - which leads me to another issue, this game is still very similar to a roguelike, since its entirely possible to lose every single item your carrying when you die, sometimes when messing around with mods - those can even erase your character and force you to respawn, thus losing everything which can be very punishing when you lose everything to something that isn't really the players fault, sometimes dying due to a bug for instance.

Dinosaur taming again, since Dinosaurs are the main focus of the game and taming them as pets would be something enjoyable, but even this aspect of the game isn't without issues.  The requirements and even taming timers, especially the timers can be brutual - imagine spending countless hours, real time hours trying to tame a dinosaur? I'm sure some veterans could share many horror stories of the hours wasted taming - surely a better system could be done rather than spending as long as 24 hours taming something?   Sure, you could always play single player and greatly speed up the taming process, and even some private servers have increased taming speeds but not all.

Now, for the positives - the game looks amazing, great flow and great potential once they can really work out some of the bugs and problems,  ARK 2 is something I would be invested in too if that ever saw the light of day.   Especially if they could get a better co-op system in place, rather than having a useless tethered helper on a non-dedicated server.

I think ARK: Survival Evolved shows alot of promise provided they keep it in development and work at making the game more stable, more optimization and re-work some of the areas of the game where it fails, such as electrical cables.

* Update 3.29.2016

Uninstalled the game, had enough of the unstable client and waiting until such a time when the game is fully released and more stable.  Mods is the best way to play, and unfortunately then can make the client even more unstable especially each time a new patch is released and practically breaks every mod.

Pros

Great Atmosphere
Great Graphics
Dinosaurs look realistic
Mod Support

Negatives

Many bugs and glitches
Electrical cable system is bad
Way too easy to die
Tamed Dinosaurs have bad A.I
Terrible multiplayer
Unstable and prone to hard crashes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would have recommended this game, until this update on Jan 5. I don't know who was smoking what with this stat nerf, but they need to fix this. Goodbye Ark, at least until someone realizes how stupid of an idea this was.

This is so long I had to add it to the review and not in the comment section, but it does include some specifics as to why I gave a negative review.

To Bigmac; first off, nothing I said was anything but an opinion, so it by definition can't be false. Second, it's not hateful, nowhere did I add anything into the review that indicates any form of hate, just that I disagree with this particular update and that I would no longer recommend this game. Now, let me explain why I disagree with this stat nerf, and why I think implementing it was stupid. I love the game as a whole, but I strongly disagree with the methodology the devs are using to balance the games mechanics. This is a development game, true, but it is also a development game that people have paid for and have put 100's of hours into. People have gone to great lengths to build what they have and tame what they have and this patch ruined much of that. For example, I have a high lvl scorpion that I had tamed to knock certain things out. I had its damage at about 800%. Scorpions do 3x torpor to their damage over a 10 second period. Their base damage is 15. Now, it had very low damage when tamed, even though it was high lvl. That wasn't a problem at all, until this patch. It used to be a 10% gain on damage per lvl, so since I started out at 200% damage, I gained it at 20% per lvl. That's slow, but I only needed it to reach a certain point. Now, because it had low base damage, it has roughly 240% damage. I can't get those lvls back and even if I could what was once a useful creature would be worthless no matter what I do with it. This was a 120 scorpion. Now, scorpions are easy to tame so finding another one with better stats wouldn't be a huge problem, but there is nothing I could do to get one powerful enough to do anything close to what I wanted it for. That isn't my only useless creature now, it was just my hardest hit one, and it lets me easily explain the problem I have with the way they did the nerf. By nerfing the per lvl stats so much they made any and all choices made on certain creatures lvl's worthless and they limited the kind of customization allowed per creature. Your points now matter less, there is less progress to be had. I dislike any changes that limit what kind of builds or the degree to which your decisions matter. A better route would have been limited the max gain per lvl per stat, or dimishing returns with some possible base stat adjustments in either scenario. Even better yet they could, and should, and adjusted wild dino stats up rather than take tamed ones down. Many people within their playerbase feels, rightly, betrayed by this change which so adversly affected their hard work. This game is still in development, but since they have opened it to the public and since the public has largely funded it's progress and has largely affected the design of the game, they should be a little bit consious of how their actions affect the playerbase. I would not have been so short and harsh with my review had there been a hey

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While it is true that the devs have worked to correct the imbalance patch 231.0 has caused, some serious issues still remain and a couple more have been added. Tames can no longer one hit wild dinos which would be great, except for the fact that they are very low lvl wild dinos. (Lvl 20 for example) And alphas are nearly impossible without a giga, which again wouldn't be bad except that it takes an insane amount of resources to even begin to tame one, which most tribes simply don't have. While I do agree that the game needed to be balanced, doing it in such an extreme way has alienated most of the players.
While I can see the need for balance and getting rid of op tames, I can't agree with tames being weaker than their wild counterparts. Why? Because a tamed dino is a trained dino. It is trained to be better at resource gathering/fighting. While I don't think they should be able to one hit high lvl dinos or go after alphas solo, I personally can't agree with them being weaker than everything. It removes a great deal of realism for me.
Then there is the most recent nerf to the turrets... Again while it is great that your favorite flying mount can no longer be one shot out of the sky, defense against wild dinos/hostile players and their dinos, is now almost non-existant. In a pve server this wouldn't be as much of a problem, except for the fact that alphas can still spawn inside your base and the turrets can no longer kill them before they kill all your dinos, but most official servers are a mix of pvp and pve players and tribes. This means that players have no real means of defense any more. Against either wild dinos or hostile tribes and their tamed dinos. Meaning that raiding and entire tribes being wiped will happen more often, again it wouldn't be bad except that it will be smaller tribes that get hit the most often, larger tribes can easily add more turrets to make up for the nerf.
Then there is the lag. It's always been bad, but now, for me at least, the lag is so bad as to make the game almost un-playable. With wild dinos still slightly op compared to our tames...the last thing you would want is lag that is so bad your character freezes.
In short, the changes can be good, however, the way in which they have been implemented was very poorly thought out and ignored problems that have been in the game for months, while adding others.
While I do understand that this is an early access game and that there will be changes, the point of any game being early access is to involve the community in helping to shape the game. I personally feel like the developers didn't take into consideration the backlash that it would cause, and now although they are taking steps to fix it, communication is still somewhat lacking.
I will wait to see where the newest changes will take the game, I'm not ready to give up on it yet. But for now I don't recommend this game, because of the current issues with it. I will trust the developers to come up with solutions for these problems, but for now it isn't worth purchasing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never went from liking a game to hating it in such a short time.

The biggest thing I hate is that nearly Everything. Is. A. Gigantic. Time sink. Meaning it's ♥♥♥♥ing boring.

Want to  tame dinos? Don't make traps or cages- just pump that sucker with more tranquilizers than you can even imagine from specific ammo types and when it finally gets knocked out, just shove literal tons food down it's throat like no tomorrow, but wait!

Sit there and watch two bars go up and down for HOURS because you need to make narcotics to keep it knocked out and if you don't know what food it wants/likes, good luck, it will be kibble, and not just any regular kibble- kibble made from a specific dinosaur egg that you have to wait to get for hours, days even, to get. It won't help much, because it takes a LOT of kibble, so you have a vicious cycle where you need eggs to make kibble, but need specific female dinos to drop said egg after a terribly long time to tame dinos that drop a different egg. There are certain dinos you CAN'T tame with violence, so you have to sit there, for hours while a bar fills up, but the stakes are higher! because some of them will attack or run away if you get too close or don't have bug repellant on, setting up very pleasant fiasco where I was taming a giant bat flying into every wall it could with prime meat that spoils really fast, but I got too close and had to kill it because it nearly killed me in a few hits, I'd kill to do that again!.

It gets better if the dino has a high level, the higher the level, the harder it is to tame, which means more time and resources you have to waste, that might make sense, but if I have to sit out in the open for about 6 hours while taming a Rex surrounded by things that want a piece of it's giant behind, I won't have any of that crap.

Want to make elaborate houses? Bases? Fortresses? Then grab your tools and dinos, because you are going to GRIND, grind, grind and grind some more. Survival game with dinos on the outside; insanely slow grindfest on the inside

It's a grind, you'll grind resources, you'll grind experience, you'll grind eggs, you'll grind your teeth trying to make sense as to why everything goes at the same speed as a dead snail frozen in a glacier.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ARK: Survival Evolved is currently by far the best Survival Game you can get. For an Early Access game and for that matter a full release it has an unbelievable amount of content. I have played nearly 40 hours already and I have barely scratched the surface, I have explored about 5% of the entire map and about 1% of Game content. The level up system is fantastic although I would love it if there was a way to reset your engram points. The devs and staff are insanley active everywhere and deliver patches at an insane rate. I would fully recommend this game to anyone, it is well worth the money it costs and you will not find a better survival game anywhere.

Edit: 22/06/2015:
After playing this game for a bit longer, I would have hoped by now that optimization would be a higher priority than it currently is, on Medium settings with a GTX 970 I cannot get above 30FPS @ 1440P and above 40FPS @ 1080P unless I turn the Resolution Scale down, which makes the game look absolutely garbage. I still recommend the game as it is insanely fun, but I have to add that the optimization in this game is hands down the worst I've ever seen.
