reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has restored my faith in both game developers and early access!

First off this is my first review on Steam, and the only game I have ever felt the need to share my opinion about. It is hands down THE game worth your investment and time. I have played it mostly locally (single-player) due to poor connectivity at my current location. Still the Devs genuinely care about the community and the game, are very hard at work keeping new content coming, and have given us one of the best games in the history of the PC.

I have heard the complaints about FPS and optimization, and I understand the frustration. But the game is playable, and I am using a budget GTX 610 and 6GB Ram. We can expect nothing but improvements from here, so don't let that stop you from getting on board.

PROS:
Dedicated and passionate developers
Interesting and vibrant open world
Creative crafting and gathering system
Base building
DINOSAURS
Interesting cooperative system via Tribes
Massive amounts of content already present, with more to come

CONS:
That it took till 2015 for me to find this game
Optimization (though not really a con as it is being addressed and the game is still playable)

Well done to all the developers, this game is the model all early access games need to learn from going forward. Thanks for a great game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having not played on a server I cant review the game based on multi-player so this is my single player experience so far.

The game is tough at the start, and being a loan survivor makes it even harder, however once you start leveling up to around 40 and have yourself a crew of raptors, the game really opens up.

I'm at 50 hours so far in a single player world and I'm really enjoying the game.

I currently have a T-Rex being tamed and have quite a good strong group of different dinos.  Triceratops are excellent for foraging berries!

The game has now been optimized and the graphics and models are very well crafted a must buy for all.

This is one of the standout products in an already over populated market of survival games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, back in the days of Titanfall, i promised my self to never pre-order a game(Early access is close enough lol). But once i watched the trailer to this game....#instaboner, and i had to have it.
So to start off, this game if pretty fun, once you get it to work. Now dont get me wrong, it isn't that hard to get working if you are looking in the right place. The servers have not worked for me yet(That is expected as it is release day and they are probably over loaded). I see people complain that there is no single player. Now this is PARTIALLY true. There is no dedicated single player, but if you open up a server and select local play, it is basically single player, and i had no one join me

First, my PC specs:
-Intel i5-3570k
-Gigabyte Mobo
-Radeopn R9 290
-8GB DDR3 1333Mhz
-1 TB WD Blue
-750 watt fatality PSU


PROS:
-Dinosaurs
-Pretty Game
-♥♥♥♥ ton of crafting
-♥♥♥♥ ton of items
-Fist fights with Dinosaurs(♥♥♥♥ yeah)
-No crashes so far
-Very little bugs i have found
-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ yourself
-Leveling up system to increase your skills and crafting knowledge

CONS:
-Not very optimized(I have a 290 and was still having frame issues on medium)
-Servers did not work at launch, but they do now
-Long ♥♥♥ loading times, it will load, go to a black screen for like a minute, then finally load
-Single player was not in at initial release, but has been fixed now
-The dino AI is not the best, Pterodactlys will fly into rocks and other dinos just dont notice you when you are close
-The path finding and collision in the game is weird, a Brontasaurus will have 1 leg on a rock and the rest of the body will be floating mid air. Ive also seen raptors chase me and phase half way through me so that i can see their head and neck when they are behind me

Other thoughts:

- Ok, so fist fighting dinos.....♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Punching a dodo bird in the face is pretty damn fun.
- I got scared a few times and almost ♥♥♥♥ myself....oh wait....you actually do ♥♥♥♥ yourself, and that noise it what scared me the most.
- The game is pretty in itself, but i had no hope of playing any higher than medium, which is expected for an alpha game, so hey, what can i say?
-The amount of items you can craft is pretty damn awesome, there is a ♥♥♥♥ ton, and i havent even started to scratch the surface in crafting.
-The map is HUGE, i spent a while and probably only explored like 1/100 of the map.

Ill update as i go along

UPDATE
- They added the songle player to the game, people just had to wait a little and have some patience

-I keep getting stuck in ♥♥♥♥. I can sometimes walk a foot or so into a hill or mnountain, and i got stuck in a rock formation, had to restart the map because i couldnt get out.

-They are starting to optimize the game, slowly but surely, i am noticing less lag spikes and a bit smoother FPS, which is nice to see being implemented so quickly after launch

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unlike DayZ, Rust etc.

This game is very difficult to adapt to and get the hang of - whilst I found myself constantly dying to a herd of Dilos or Raptors, or the occasional Rex. I would stumble across bases on the beach with tamed Brontosauruses and numerous other dinosaurs.

With that being said, the first 10 minutes of spawning is very grindy - but once you've obtained an axe and a slingshot the game becomes an open book... Apart from Berries, at low levels meat is very hard to find due to Dodos being bottom of the food chain for the other dinos too. And try killing a Trike with your bare hands (it won't work)

Once you've got your bearings on this game, it is giant amounts of fun and I strongly recommend playing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a positive recommendation... But lets just address the Brontosaurus in the room first:

Games of this nature punish and put an unfair gap between casual and dedicated gamers. a casual gamer can never have a fair and decent chance of thriving when all their progress is potentially destroyed while they sleep, work or have a social life. (this is from a PvP server point of view, i haven't tried Non-PvP servers)

Fortunately this game atleast has a leveling system so regardless of what happens while you live your life, you wont start completely at square 1.

With all this negativity said... the game is fun, graphics are good, the atmosphere is captivating.... and the dinos... are ******* cool. It truely is a great game and i dont regret buying it.

EDIT: i also understand that while i described the game aspect of losing your progress as a negative, that is how many survival games are designed and for some people it helps to keep the game interesting and increases longevity immensly provided you dont find it too repedative.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is undeniably the greatest Dinosaur game on steam, and arguably one of the most enjoyable survival titles in early access currently.

TLDR: (ARK) is probably the closest you'll ever get to a nearly perfect dino-survival cross. Definitely worth checking out.


Full Review:

Ark: Survival Evolved is another early access title that appeared out of  literally  nowhere (the first one being theHunter: Primal) and yet again baffeled me and many other dino fanatics as to how awesome it looked. At first, I was taken back a little due to it's striking similarities with The Stomping Land (and we all know what happened to that atrocity) and I really doubted it would be any better. As it turned out, the Developers of Ark were right on the community's side, as they themselves were upset with The Stomping Lands as well, and motivated them to make their own game better and more enjoyable then it's predecessor.


Ark starts off with your character (male or female) is stranded on a mysterious island, naked and equiped with nothing but a mechanical gadget wedged in his/her arm, also it proves to be very uncomfortable as the intro cutscene depicts your character trying to scratch it. Your goal is to hunt for resources and attempt to survive blah blah blah...


As you may already know, there's dinosaurs. and lots of them. Also you can tame and eventually ride them. Making your dream of owning a pack of tamed  velociraptors  Utahraptors possible (admit it, you know you want to). So essentially as soon as the servers went up everyone frantically went on an arms race to see who got the biggest dinosaur on the block first, then brag about it to all their comrades in the neighborhood, and preferrably maul them before they rise up and overthrow you for who has the biggest  dild dino.


When I first got the game however, I was already noticing some very major flaws. First off, there wasn't nearly as much servers to hold the total amount of players currently in game. Secondly, there was no singleplayer initially. So there would be a massive waiting line for a server slot to be open. Normally with many other early access titles, this seemingly easy fix" would take days
date: maybe weeks to finally be addressed by the devs
recommended: and the community would be long gone by then. It took the devs of Ark less then  12 hours to add 300+ more servers and add a singleplayer mode  next day after the inital release
hoursPlayed: and they didn't stop there. I swear it was almost every few hours a new patch came out
voteText: addressing many bugs people were finding.\n\nOne of the major big things about this game is the fact that once you get into it
helpfulPercent:
its hard to quit for long periods of time. I come back almost every day to check on my dinosaurs and to see who's moved into the neighborhood.

And preferrably maul them.

Violently."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh, ARK. You could be so much more.

Here is a game that clearly WANTS and ATTEMPTS to surpass the current survival genre. It has has dinosaurs, it has a permanent leveling system outside of the perma-death. These are two grea things, but what is it missing that caused me to give this game a thumbs down?

This game has absolutely no player SKILL. I don't improperly capitilize words lightly. Here lies an incredibly deep game, with an icredibly basic combat system. You left click to attack. You left click to attack with all weapons. The shield is useless, there is no dodging.

In a survival game, the goal is usually to explore and survive. In Ark, it is to hermit for 10s of hours of gameplay to survive. I had achieved hide-level armor and level 20 weapons. Yet, the second I landed my Pterodactly in my 3-real-life day safe zone; it was assaulted by 2 raptors that killed it in 10 seconds. This is a beast I had to stand and NOT PLAY THE GAME, but simply tame"
date: for 2 hours to acquire.\n\nThis game should have a monthly fee
recommended: because that is what its gameplay mechanics inspire. A game that puts real-world time requirements on basic gameplay mechanics.\n\nIn the end
hoursPlayed: it's a great game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review, the only reason I write this to help people not trap themself with the unstable environment of ARK. For now, I've played 600 hours online and approximately 250 hours full offline. I'm not a professional but I've never got killed on a server by other players when I was online. I would like to share some of ARK's worst parts:

1. ARK: NO Survival Involved

ARK isn't a survival game, once you create and try a few stuff + read the wiki the game becomes easy. There is no challenge in this game: the dinos AI is bad, the boss is weak. There are only tank enemies with buffed attack damage. Only casuals die often in this game, experienced" players mostly just runs away when battle comes and they hide in the grass like scared rabbits... PvE(Player versus Environment) is mostly boring and the same as you playing offline except you depend on the ping. PvP(Player versus Player) is mostly just griefing: they will just harrass you from a safe distance. There is this "Fair Raid" phrase
date: when you got attacked only if you're online
recommended: but most if not all the time they'll just watch you and your friends to go offline and it doesn't matter how many turrets or x plants(ARK's automatic defense system) you've
hoursPlayed:
they'll just throw C4 or shoot grenades on your base and that's the end. Dinos are worthless when they don't have riders - they'll just entice your flyers and grenade the others. That's PvP - you can loose hundreds of hours of work in a few minutes and it doesn't matter if you're a skilled survival or not. ARK is too EASY to be a SURVIVAL game and too UNDEVELOPED to be a STRATEGY game while it's trying to be both and failing at it.

2. ARK: The Dino are Fusioned!
This game is full of bugs and the developers don't care: they just add new stuff slowly and fix nothing. You'll often see dinos fusion and then they won't be able to move... They'll stuck everywhere + their AI is pretty bad at pathfinding. A few times happened that I tried to swim out of the water and my dinos followed me and I was slower so I BUGGED IN THEM and I almost died in the water because I was in to the dino... Anyway
voteText: even if they give a patch which supposed to fix a certain bug it won't work because they didn't even try it... The same with new features: 1. they create the xxx patch; 2. they create the xxx.1 patch because an obvious thing doesn't work and they 'fixed' it; 3. they create the xxx.2 patch because they didn't really fixed the problem
helpfulPercent: just partially; they create the xxx.3 patch because they need to fix another thing which was fixed in xxx.1 but they accidentally removed it in xxx.2; they might give out xxx.x patches later if there were more "feature"(mostly these features are pretty useless
votesHelpful:
they just suspend the important things and create more secondary things).

3. ARK: Timewasting Evolved
Compared to how hard to get someting in ARK it's way too easy to loose it. There are plenty of time-wasting features like taming dinos(sometime it requires  8-9 hours and you need resources which might take 20-30 hours to get - and you'll loose this dino by a ridiculous accident or a headshot...) and gathering resources - some tools require an impossible amount of resources to make people feel like they play this game for fun but it's mostly slave work. You'll often find yourself in the need of cementing paste and then you'll need to kill trilobites and harvest rock - yes
votesTotal: you'll need to kill insects(for chitin) and harvest thousands of kilograms of stone to create an assault riffle... Seems legit. Or you can get a frog(beelzebufo) to kill the insects for cementing paste and chitin but this frog might die from insects...\n\nAfter all these rants this game might be still good if you play this on YOUR server with YOUR friends if you can ignore the bugs and install some mods which could introduce some useful mechanics. But if you think this game is about to play and fight with extinct animals you'll be disappointed - they're just mortal tools like in the flinstones and the only things matter there are the weapons."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What's that, you hear? A new survival game is making ripples on the Steam store?  But this time, its not zombies, but dinosaurs! Wowzers, you better go for that! But seriously, this is just another survival game, but with the new additive feature of being able to tame the natural enemies as pets, able to ride them or lead a pack. But this is about the same as every other survival game, just with more creative building on the side (but nowhere near the level of Minecraft, but it is still an early access game).

PROS
- Tries to break the survival game boom mould with the ability to tame the wildlife, allowing you to take them out on hunts, help you scavenge materials, ride them to explore the small island, or just be beast of burdens because you're a bully.
- Able to create tribes, allowing you to join fellow players in jolly cooperation, or to just be ♥♥♥♥♥. I don't know, each tribe has their own goal, and some of them are odd. But thats more dependent on the community than anything else.
- Constant updates, its not crazy to see this game update every day, some small, some sizable. The development team has put a lot of hours into working on this. Not to mention money, as they now offer a $100 USD bounty to finding bugs or exploits and reporting them.
- Simulates the real life necessities as much as they can. You need to eat, drink, um...poop, etc. But for some reason you don't need to sleep, but I guess you can when a jerk knocks you unconcious and now you're forced to look at a black screen.

CONS
- When you logout, your character is still in the game, making you vulnerable. Someone can come and ruin your day when you come back, or a part of the wildlife decides to spawn somewhere to give you the finger. Its an infuriating thing that is only added up still requiring you to eat and drink, even when you're offline. The later necessity is slightly remedied by having that process drastically slow down, but will still require you to come back online here and there.
- Building materials required to create things are incredibly exaggerated, 60 pieces of wood when you gather at a speed of 1-3 at a time to create one piece of wall? At this point it becomes more of a hassle when you have to do an eventual structural upgrade, causing it to feel more like a chore that doesn't really feel like much of a reward.
- The aforementioned taming process is poorly done, you simply knock the wildlife unconcious and shove food in its mouth while keeping it drugged. How does that make sense? Someone knocks you out cold and shoves food down your hole so that when you wake up you love them? You try to sell that to someone. Oh, did I forget this process can sometimes take HOURS? That's right, you sit there for hours to make sure its still out cold and force feed it while protecting it from any danger. You'd need to have a lot of freetime to enjoy this game.
- A level system that is something different for survival games...but half of it is poorly done. Instead of simply crafting the items when you have the materials, you have to know the recipe. Makes sense, right? But only until you realize you have a set amount of points per level to learn these recipes, forcing you to make decisions. Do you want to be able to hunt? Or do you want to have a home? Maybe you just want to gather stuff? WELL TOO BAD, its behind a certain level requirement and engram points to learn the recipes, making this game tedious for those who don't have a lot of free time.

This game is definitely getting a lot of attention, attention that I think is a bit silly, look at other survival games that made a big splash on Steam before, what happened to Day Z? Arma 3? Rust? The Forest? This is simply just another flavour of the month survival game, and while the development team is putting a lot of work into it, I don't see it lasting for too long. My only deep regret is that I put $30 on this due to a friend'a recommendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tremendous potential offset by extremely grind-heavy mechanics requiring an overwhelming amount of time investment on any server using standard settings.  Strongly recommend playing the game on a private server with enhanced resource gathering and taming speed.  Game still needs a lot of work.  The bugs are numerous and the game's performance (both server and client) is very poor.  Hackers and cheaters plague the game and have ruined many servers.  I would not recommend the game in its current form as it is far more likely for you to fall prey to poor game mechanics, poor game performance, and bugs than to anything else.  Don't bother playing solo on an actual server.  You stand no chance.  Play singleplayer.  The game caters to 10-20 man tribes far more than the solo player.

That being said, I enjoyed my time in Ark and fully intend to revisit it when they are done with it.  This may just end up being one of the greatest games ever made when they finally finish it.  I look forward to the day when the game mechanics are just as smooth as the server performance and the framerate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As much as I like the concept behind this game, its current implementation leaves a lot to be desired. I'm giving it a YES vote because of the concept and the numerous updates and patches from the dev team, but be aware that the game can be quite frustrating to play in its current state.

The live servers feel like they should be live public test servers at times as the game isn't fully optimised. This results in a lot of issues with rubber-banding even on the best of Internet connections, not to mention the rollbacks that occur whenever a server crashes.

The PvP in this game quickly descended into a grief-fest, so play that at your own risk. PvE is where I've spent the vast majority of my time in game and it's been quite the fun experience, all told, despite the frustrating rubber-banding isssues.

The game's key feature - the taming of dinosaurs - really seems to be only for the most hardcore of players simply for the fact that it can take hours in real time to tame a single dinosaur. Yes, HOURS. In that time, you will be running around collecting berries (for taming herbivores) or killing other dinos for meat (for taming carnivores) while also ensuring they stay unconscious by using narcoberries or narcotic paste. Even with multiple people doing the farming, the process still takes a ridiculously and unnecessarily long time. And while you're doing that, you also need to ensure that no other dinos or players come along and kill the dino you're trying to tame. Yes, even on PvE, people can kill dinos being tamed.

And heaven forbid if the server goes down when you're minutes away from taming a T-Rex that you've spent hours taming because when the server comes back up, the dino being tamed is gone. Not just rolled back like everything else, it's completely gone. Talk about frustrating!

I'm really hoping that this is just the first iteration of taming and that it will be revamped and revised as time goes on, because if they want people to keep playing the game with the hope of taming a favourite dinosaur, they can't expect those people to devote hours at a time to just berry/meat farming in order to get one.

All that said, there is still a lot of fun to be had. Riding around on the back of a raptor or soaring through the skies on a pteranodon are definitely highlights, as is the sheer terror of running from not one but two spinos!

I really hope the optimisation and rubber-banding issuess are resolved with quickly so as not to detract people from playing the game as is, because there's a lot of gems of fun to be found beneath its unpolished exterior.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1.  Woke up on a beach.
2.  Made some tools and a shack.
3.  Killed a dodo bird.
4.  Cooked dodo meat.
5.  Saw big turtle looking dinosaur.
6.  Made a spear to attack turtle dinosaur.
7.  Attacked turtle dinosaur.
8.  Died.
9.  Woke up on a beach.
10.  Found my stuff.
11.  Made more spears.
12.  Decided to attack turtle dino again with ranged weapons instead.
13.  Winning turtle fight!
14.  Wait... turtle is running towards the water.
15.  Chasing turtle into water!
16.  Almost caught up with turtle!
17.  Eaten by Megalodon.
18.  Woke up on a beach.

In all seriousness, this game is enjoyable and has a lot of promise.  You should really give it a look.  Think of the newer Unity 5 Rust, but much better graphics, a ton more PVE type content, and a sort of RPG character system.  Overall, the game is doing well.  You do have some early access pains to deal with here and there, the most annoying being the load times as you travel, but that's to be expected.  This game can only get better, and it's already thoroughly enjoyable as is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

500+ hours played

While I love(d) this game, I can no longer recommend it in good faith to any one. I have played on PVP servers, PVE, Survival of the Fittest and single player on a variety of difficulties, and tried nearly every mod out there to make my experience with Ark better. While I adore the core concept of this game, it's slowly losing it's appeal. The devs have little-to-no interest in fixing game-breaking bugs;

i.e -- the level 120 spino that you spent hours taming? yeah, it just fell through the map, oops! Oh, you were attacked by a dino and fell through the map and lost your entire inventory of mastercraft riot armour and gear? that's too bad! Your level 240 quetzal randomly got stuck in midair in an invisible barrier and there's no way to get it to move again? Aww, so sad.

While I understand  this is an alpha game and bugs are too be expected, the purpose of an alpha is to find the bugs, report them, and then the devs are supposed to fix them. They haven't even ATTEMPTED to fix these. Instead they released another stand alone game, released it to console, and have the time and money to add new dinos and content every 2 weeks.

Playing in single player I've never experienced lag and I usually have about 90FPS. However, once I switch to a server, even a locally based one with good ping, lag spikes occur every 15 seconds, rubberbanding, crashing, and 1FPS is all too common.

I can't complain about the player base because, well, it's people. They're in every game, both the good and bad ones.

The devs are all to excited to add new content but if you even complain once about the bugs on the forums, just wait for the ban-hammer.

Also, THE PATH MAPPING, ARGH! It's not really that difficult to map AI (or at least I assume since every other game on the planet seems to do fine with it) but good luck walking your dinos on follow" any where because they WILL get stuck on every rock and tree.

With every "large update" this game receives
date: I lose more faith in it. If the devs actually fix some of the major issues people have with this game
recommended: I would come back in a heart beat. However
hoursPlayed: as it stands now

helpfulPercent: it's so poorly optimized that I had to replace my 6 month old motherboard because this game fried it. It's happened to many people with a few hundred hours played on it. So sad."

-Your gaming experience is mostly based on the server's admins and those in the server with you at the time.
-Admin abuse is very common

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm going to start this by saying I understand it's in alpha, and I will not be complaining about bugs/explouts and or crashes. You basic start is going into a server (for this sake it's a NORMAL EXP/GATHER server) you realize the game looks very pretty. Graphic wise the game is amazing.  You start gathering materials then get killed in pvp by someone on a dino. After a lot of trail and error you will come to realize the pvp is broken. People who have been on the a server for any point in time longer then you will destroy you your dinos and your base repeatedly because of a broken leveling system. As you level you are able to build new things and tame new dinos, and it's sounds good in theory, but you will never harm a metal base and they will wreck you wood/stone base with just a few grenades. Which comes to another problem. The time it takes to do anything. You pretty much have to no life this game hardcore. crafting recipes cost to much, you gather to little, and dinos can take up to 4 hours to tame. It makes losing your stuff in a 5 min period that much worse. You are pretty much required to tame dinos if you want to be useful in anyway, and the taming is ridiculously dull. Beyond the long taming times, the actual way to tame is actually bad. You just sit there looking at numbers keeping the knockout meter up by force feeding it drugs. When it comes to the building in this game, it's generic.  Every house comes out being a square as there isnt much customization other then just changing the color of the wall. You are also forced into a tribe, since your not able to learn every engram (The talent system for learning new crafting recipes). This forces you in with total strangers if not with friends who will steal or cause wars on your server getting you wiped. Overall the biggest problem with the game is that everything feel like a chore. You have to log on as often as possible to just make sure your alive, your base survived, your dinos are fed, ect. It almost feels like it's a forced way to get you to log back into the game. TLDR I do not reccomend this game, it is just a lot of hype. A good idea, badly executed

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere is no reason to buy this game unless you plan on hosting your own server or you have friends who host.  Although the game has over 400 official servers there are almost always less than 20 people on each one.  The reason for this is that every official server is dominated by a single tribe that wipes out all new players.  There is literally no way to level and get started since anything you build will be wiped by the dominant tribe literally daily.  Even if you want to avoid pvp, every location that might be fun to build on a PvE server has had the major tribe drop construction in those locations which prevents you from building.  The game mechanics seem fun; but again, you will never get the chance to tame dinos for example when someone will kill them daily whenever you log off.  Having tried multiple official servers with the same result I can only express disapointment with this game and with humanity.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignoring the bad side-effects of Early Access games, this one is currently quite fleshed out. The crafting system may not be to everyone's liking and i'm not sure if it's possible to acquire everything in a singleplayer game just yet, but for what there is, it's certainly enough to keep you busy. A couple of notes for new starters:

1. Try not to build anything you'll use too close to the water - having a large alligator decide to come out of the water to patrol right where you are and proceed to destroy stuff as it tries to kill you is not fun!
2. Aim to build a bed as quickly as you can - It acts as an anchor point so that when (not if) you die, you won't spawn a mile away and have to trek past a t-rex or some other nasty in order to reach safety again.
3. Upon said death, like most things, your previous body will start to decompose/spoil usually around the 10 minute mark. If you can't get back and loot your ex-body by then, all the stuff you've crafted/gathered will be lost!. Try to remember where you are when near death so that it'll be easy to find your body.
4. Punch trees/driftwood to get thatch and wood, then make a pickaxe. Use a hatchet on a tree for more wood, use a pickaxe for more thatch (stop using your hands by this point, no point lowering your health for a dino to munch you easier).
5. Nighttime is extremely dark!, either hole up safe, or if you must go out, make yourself a torch so you'll actually see raptors coming to get you before it's too late.

Don't be expecting to be able to make guns/tame a t-rex straight away as certain things will unlock as your get higher levels, not just different materials. Overall it's definitely been worth the money so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am recommending this game because I see the potential in it, and even with the numerous problems it is currently suffering from, it is a lot of fun. Unlike most reviews, I am going to start off by listing the issues that I personally have with the game first. Keep in mind that this game is in early access. When purchased, you should know and acknowledge that there will be bugs, and things will be broken. Afterall, that is the whole point of the game. Also, for the sake of comparison, at the end of this review I will also list my PC specs so you can get an idea of how your computer may run the game in its current state as well.

At the time of writing this review, the game has been horribly optimized. The ARK dev team has already ackknowledged this, and they stated that when they initially developed the game, their focus was on content, with optimization taking a back seat until the launch of early access. As of right now I am forced to play in 720p on the lowest graphics settings and I still only get around 20-23fps. If I jump to medium on 720p I drop to around 9-10fps. This is probably the most irritating thing about the game as it currently stands.

Ok the game also suffers from absolutely horrible loading times, it probably takes a close to 2 minutes for me to load up the world, and it literally uses up about 90% of my CPU while doing it. The reason that a lot of people think this is happening is because the entire world is loading at one time, and then it remains loaded. ARK is collectively close to 70 square kilometers I believe so that is alot of foliage and textures constantly being generated, which would also explain the terrible fps.

I have not tried to join a server yet, but I have attempted to host a server, and whenever I do it maxes out my computers memory and the game crashes leaving my with the cmd prompt up.

Graphics on low are really really bad, even for low. ARK has acknowledged this and said that they will be fixing it.

Now I know that I listed a lot of bad stuff right off the bat, and im sure you are thinking, why in the world does this game get a recommended rating? Well let me list off the things that I really like about the game, and the things that give me hope for it.

1. The game has been out for less than 2 days and they have already released 7 patches for it. This team is obviously dedicated to making this game good and fixing the issues already at hand. I think back to the only other time I have gotten an early access" game which was cube world
date: and that developer never released a patch
recommended: so the fact that they have already done 7 should be acknowledged.\n\n2. Even on low graphics settings this game is bringing out my inner child. Every time is see a dinosaur I just have to stop and look at it. They did a really good job of making you feel really small and insignificant when you start out. And let's be honest
hoursPlayed: in a world of dinosaurs
voteText: thats the atmosphere that should be set.\n\n3. the overall game mechanics (minue fps) are actually really fun. The hunger and water is easy (maybe even to easy) to maintain
helpfulPercent: and the leveling system is really cool. I also really like that the inventory system is weight based instead of quantity. Makes it easier to travel around. Also
votesHelpful: one thing that I have never cared for with survival games was the aspect of when you die you are done. I really enjoy that they give you a choice in this game.\n\n4. ARK team has already said that graphics and optimization are their top priorities
votesTotal: and they plan on significantly improving within days- a few weeks. Even if you can't open it now
votesFunny: with the 17% early adopter discount
commentsCount: I would personally be willing to wait a couple days to possibly a week or 2.\n\nSo yeah

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a great game for people who are into survival games like Rust or DayZ. The only thing is there is so much more to do in this game. There is an actual leveling system where each time you level up you can increase your health, stamina, O2(how long you can stay underwater), food, water, and the list goes on. There is also a character creator in which you can choose your gender and customize the size and looks of each of your body parts, which has already led to horrifying characters being created. Anyways, each time you level up you get things called engram points, which you can put toward blueprints that allow you to be able to craft stuff, like torches, campfires, hatchets, guns, bows, slingshots, and things like that. But to get guns you have to be a really high level and play the game a lot, which is a good thing because this game shouldn't be a gun fest like most other survival games. So seriously, if you're really into survival games, get this. Even though you might have a little trouble joining servers at first, it'll be worth it. And you'll give the developers an extra $25 to put towards the developing of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OOOOOH MY GAWD WHERE DO I START!?!?!?
110 hours so far in this game...Stumbled upon this randomly in the steam store and my god was that the best thing ever!!!
My hours on this game will only go UP UP UP UP AND UP from here on out!!! 110 hours feels like nothing in this game.

Pros:
-Dinosuars...a vast amount of them..
-CONSTANT updates!!
-Brand new map for free! Which btw...is AMAZING and i've seen next to NOTHING of it!!
-Base building surival in dino time! ALWAYS wanted this!
-They are insanely active in their community
-They definitely do research to keep all dinos in a historical reference
-It has a weird unknown story behind why you're there and what your objective is
-FREE ROAM WHEREVER YOU PLEASE, unless a mean and scary dino says other wise!
-Stabbed a turtle in the eye with a spear, spear was stuck inside his eye and i lost my weapon cause i couldn't pull it out.
-Took a dino egg, the mother NEVER stopped chasing me (anklyosaur)
-I knew nothing about this company and took a risk on them, BEST thing i've ever done before! I fully support this company after this game.
-Wardrums, have yet to bang them but i must bang! NEED to bang them, imma bang them so hard when i make a set.
-Poop...my character poops in situations when id definetly poop myself, 10/10 realism
-Stego/Spino! My favorite dinos!
-Entertaining multiplayer, great with friends. (Characters save on ONE server, you can transfer saves through the mystery of the obelisk)
-Baby dinos coming sometime!!!!

Cons:
-Poorly optimized, the new map seems to be insanely better though! They are working to smooth the performance out
-CURRENTLY (GTX 1080 FE INBOUND!) i cant reach the max settings, i play with a GT640 (lol..) and it performs 'ok' i feel like im wasting potential amazingness with the current card
-Dinosuar painting, its a great concept but so far...the paint looks HORRIBLE on them!
-Character saves need to be directly transfered to another server, if a server shuts down and never starts up again goodbye save, or you cant get to an obelisk in time.

HIGHLY recommend this game if you have a card like mine or better, keep in mind the performance is still an issue and they are working on it, unless you have a crazy hardcore card it won't look like a pro youtubers video (my first impressions was that)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game had potential, and about a year ago, the update cycle made it feel like this was an active Early Access project that was destined for greateness. Alas, it seems that only Goat Simulator has been able to reach the finished stage whilst carrying the survival title.

This game's current problem is that it rewards people with no jobs like no other.

This game can be fun still if you're more into pure PvE, but understand that it will get grindy fast. There's private servers that will fix that but then that kinda takes the challenge out of it.

If you're looking for an element of PvP to try and make it more challenging, you have some options but none are very good. The official servers run pretty terribly - as in laggy, stuttering, and generally feel like they're on a toaster. There's private servers and a lot of the time the private servers outperform the official ones.

Private servers often also have mods that help with some of the games' inbalances to some extent, but I don't think I've yet seen one that addresses the core issue of this game. If the server is populated, you'll likely get crushed by one of the established tribes as soon as any newbie protections the server rules afford you expire. Or if you show up with enough friends you might be able to develop your tribe up quickly enough to be one of those powerful established tribes. And then at some point, you'll encounter someone who plays 20 hours per day and has way more weapons and explosives than your tribe would ever have the patience for and you get wiped off the face of the map pretty quickly. At best it gets grindy and boring and at worst it can get really infuriating.

A year ago, the frequency of new content and updates was so high that it felt there were significant new changes and mechanics introduced weekly, daily even, and it made it kind of exciting to open it up every night. Today, not only has the pace of content slowed down, but even the bug fixing hasn't really been a thing for them. Things clip, warp, teleport, and can generally become bothersome to deal with. All this sacrifice for what? To allow resources to develop this game on Xbox. That's great and all but that decision has sacrificed what was one of the strengths of this studio in favor of attemptint to pursue a larger audience... but the problem is that as little as PC gamers tolerate bugs, console players tolerate them even less; so in pursuit of a larger audience, the studio has lost its ability to actually complete the game. And that sucks.

Bottom line is that I will now no longer buy another early access game because of the frustrating experience I've had with thsi one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So after many hours playing this game I am at my verdict so far... I will update closer to final release!

EDIT: Be careful with this developer and the game, reasons are simple they are liars and Stomping Land.... The reason they lie is easy, they said that the game works great on both AMD and Nvidia, they said they do not choose sides or partner with anyway, yet back in June or July hey partnered with Nvidia... That is not something that happens in a day or weeks, that is a long process and that is why the game works better on Nvidia and ♥♥♥♥ed for everyone else so bare that in mind when playing or considering buying!

So the game is about survival, taming dinosaurs and living out trying to survive and harvest items to build. There is no terraforming in this game, only destroying rocks, trees etc, everything above ground!
Also the game is designed for Nvidia and you can tell that with AMD cards.... Serious lag and under-performance while I write this article.... I am able to play all my games I own on max graphics but this game struggles even at medium. For that is loses a massive chunk of respect for me not making it fair like AMD do.

The audio: It is simple hack slash, swing, swoop, dinosaur noises, birds tweeting etc and the ocean sounds cool.  What do you expect from a survival game on a tropical island?

The controls: These are still being worked on and upgraded because only recent strafe was introduced,  it it is massively better now than then and the character handles extremely well with the redefined controls now... Positive.

The graphics: Well, as you can see from photos they are most likely ultra which are Titan graphics or more.... The game literally runs better on nvidia than AMD and the game right now as it speaks only supports single graphics cards, and is seriously unoptimised, seriously no matter the graphics setting it will lag, but then the game is early access and that is too be expected but not this bad.  If you can get above medium then awesome because you will enjoy the game just on the visuals.

The game as it stands:

If you take out the insane lag, the unoptimised, the stupid errors and bugs in the game, the insanely long loading times. And whatever else I missed, you have a solid core base building survival game with dino taming.... The developers are probably the first I have seen releasing patches every single day and listening to what the community has to say, seriously every day patches and trying to fix the game, just my only issue is the nvidia thing and that is it.
The game has some amazing features and the fact it has no terreforming is a little off putting because it would be nice to build under ground.  You can tame almost every dinosaur in the game from a megladon to a dodo... Pretty cool, you can build some amazing bases while running around getting supplies and being chased from raptors or whatever else wants to eat you, you can name and ride dinosaurs... The game really is a lot of fun, and when you get friends playing the game and you all join a tribe, then the became shines even more.

If you love survival, base building then this is the game for you and then add on top of the ability to completely knock down emigre forests and clear entire area (it does reload when you leave the area and back in) and taming dinosaurs, then this is the game for you even more.

Would I recommend?

Yes and no, sadly there is no option to select this.

Yes, because of all the above.
No, because of nvidia only, serious unoptimised and no terreforming!

On that note I will just vote yes!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A solid game full of promise dragged down by impatient self-entitled twatwaffles barely an hour after it launches. Don't let the (currently) Mixed rating fool you. The game is much better than that. My only warning is that if you are the kind of person that NEEDS 60FPS on every game you play, you may want to wait a week or two to let them work on the optimizations a bit more. They've stated over and over that getting the game optimized is one of their main focuses of the EA shtick. So, this being said, my personal thoughts:

PROS:
Dinosaurs everywhere set on a gorgeous island.
Extreme level of body slider customization allowing you to make your preferred ideal survivor.
You can punch Raptors in the face.

CONS:
Afore-mentioned dinosaurs everywhere set on a gorgeous island will likely result in you face down in the dirt...again.
Equally afore-mentioned bodysliders result in some true horrors shambling about most servers. I'll admit, I'm guilty of my share of top heavy ape people.
After punching a raptor in the face it will likely gouge your eyes out and eat your liver after selling your kidneys on the black market. They also tend to run faster than you...
***Also, crafting recipies are locked behind a levelling system so there IS bit of a grinding element to it. Fortunately, pretty much everything you do gives xp. On top of that, there will be a way to transferr your levelled characters across official servers or some such plottery. Details are forthcoming on the boards I hear.

FINAL THOUGHTS:
WIth the devs hammering home the fact they're focusing on making the game run smoother for everyone, as well as future workshop support for MODS, I can't recommend this game enough for people who either want more than other survival games offer, or just want to kick dodos and ride a Pteradon throwing poop at a T-Rex as you fly overhead.

Just remember: EARLY ACCESS means there's still work to be done. So don't buy if you're gonna ♥♥♥♥♥ about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review on steam so lets see how it goes.

This games concept is outstanding, very rough but outstanding all the same. With new content coming out weekly the devs should pat the selves on the back.

So what is this game, Imagine waking up on an unkown island on the beach. No clothes on. No food. No where safe from the multitude of beasts you will encounter.  The first thing you need to do is to collect resources to make your tools, a campfire and  clothes. without clothes you are more susceptible to the elements and attacks. once this is all done  you will need to create a shelter and then you must upgrade this shelter or move on and create a better shelter, as most usually do. then you can try establishing contact with the others on your server to join a tribe. once within the saftey of the tribe it is easier to create your base as people pool resources and knowledge. taming dinos to go hunting and farming to upgrade your base and your equipment and wepons. this is the absolute genius of this concept it is survival 101.

There are a few types of severs you can jointhe main ones been  PvP or PvE.
PvE is for the guys who prefer not to fight other players. Im not saying they are cowards or anything just not my cup of tea, or thats what i use to think but im getting on to that.
PvP this is for the purists the people who want a better experiance feeling a real challange against other players. saying that pvp is broke in this game it is a crying shame that the devs have allowed this to happen.

Here is the gripe with PvP with this game. Imaging creating a base, working tirelessly for hours upon hours gathering resources, training dinos ,  making equipment. i am talking aboout days of work, your base is the strongest it could be. you go to sleep and the next day to your despair everything you worked for and i mean everything is gone and raided somone has come in while you were not log in killed your dinos took all your resources and destroyed  your spawn points, and in some cases decimated the entire base. thats 5 days of your hard work gone its frustrating and many people quite playing after that. this is how the game is annoying gamers. this is not PvP its really PvThePersonWhoIsLoggedOff.

So here are some solutions -allow a tribe to make 1 single sturcture impenatrable no bigger than 15 cubic build units.
make birds die on 3 hits from a person who its carring in its claws .
other suggestions i would make
do not allow structures to be built with in caves as it stops the progress of other players.
introduction of the skinning knife and hammer.
new resource of bone from animals to in♥♥♥♥♥♥♥e a new teir of tools and basic wepons
new resource of wool or fur from mammals to add new tier to cloth.
introduction of crytaline metal for structure and equipment.
ablity to make leather with hide and oil.
introdution of back packs with diffrent levels to carry a set number of slots for tools and resources.
upgrade spots on dino saddles and clothing  ie more storage/ more armor
glass window to be made from crystal and stone.
work stations upgradeable and degradable as they are been used.

All and all this game is great but i dont think ill be playing it for a while, as been raided and losing 5 days work has left this gamer with a bad taste in his mouth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awaking on a beach to a triceratops regarding you as you get up is disconcerting indeed. I gave him a wide berth and made my way down the beach.

Managed to craft a some tools before I was killed by a dillo. Round 2 - after finding a nice location and awaiting some friends finding me I did some harvesting, crafted some primitive tools and created a rudimentary shack before being murdered not by a dino but 2 dudes wearing akubra hats and armed with axes. They broke my wall down and hatcheted me to death!

Round 3 I found myself trying to make my way to a lat and long given to me by a freind who, in his efforts to find me had linked up with and joined the Dothraki tribe. Needless to say I did not make it before being eaten by a raptor.

I went into this game after reading alot of reviews and comments about issues not expecting a huge deal on its first day. While I know others did have issues, I found gameplay performance to be smooth and the graphics are very nice (if not heavy on your card). Despite the odd gfx glitch or lag spike, my experience was fine, and I found myself drawn into this world completly much like how Rust did when it first came out.

The Inventory and build system still need work and is a bit clunky plus many of us still have no idea how to properly tame a dino, the process seems rather mysterious, so that is my mission tonight in my next binge on Ark. Highly recommended and I can already see they are pumping out patches and hotfixes for this game like mad.

You, sir, have my vote!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So as you can see from my playtime, I've played a LOT of ARK: Survival Evolved. Considering this is early access and just the beginning of it, too, the developers have done and continue to do an excellent job producing an excellent game. With almost daily updates and new things to build/do in almost all those updates, this game is a prime example of how Early Access should be handled.

As of writing this review, there are still several issues which should be addressed. On the official PVP servers, the taming times take far too long. The AI on the dinosaurs is also rubbish and they basically struggle to defend themselves from players. What this means is that your T-Rex which takes several real life hours to tame is basically going to last you about 2 days, maybe 3 on average before some griefer comes along and wipes out your collection. This makes taming a waste of time.

Some guy came to my base, wiped my Trike and Scorpion in less than 10 seconds with his T-Rex. I followed him, waited until he got off his T-Rex, aggroed it and jumped off a cliff, to which the T-Rex followed me and drowned. It was level 50+ too. A complete waste of that players time.

The best way to Survive on PVP servers is to group up with a lot of people who are well geared in good bases and usually have many people online at once. The problem is that many tribes don't recruit because players are known to sabotage tribes they've joined or tribes don't want to risk someone causing their collected dinosaurs to die, lose gear etc. Which is understandable.

Basically, don't PVP in this game. Not yet. It's incredibly imbalanced and it takes far to long to accumulate any sort of viable defence, which can then easily be wiped out by better players. If this isn't an issue for you, though, and you don't mind wasting hours taming dinosaurs and building bases only for them to be wiped out while you sleep/work/do something other than play ARK, then you'll enjoy it.

PVE wise, the game is great. But there's also that issue of ... now what?" once you've built a strong base and collected an array of dinosaurs
date: because there's nothing to be fearful of PVE wise and there's nothing to do with your dinosaurs once you've built your base. I suspect this is also why PVP is so brutal
recommended: because there's not much to do once you've got a metal base and guns
hoursPlayed: so just go raid the bases of those who aren't at your level yet.\n\nOverall
voteText: the game is good
helpfulPercent: I recommend it and has a ton of potential both now and in the future. If they can some how balance PVP or offer more to do in PVE mode
votesHelpful: then the game will go up in quality."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played during the Extinction Event (Free Weekend). Tried like everyone else to get a Steam code. The event was pretty difficult in that sens, since you had to keep that code for 4 hours before it was revealed to you. Other players could steal it from you anytime.

And here comes the first problem of one of the game modes - PvP: high level players rule the landscape, kill everything that moves and steal everything from you. You don't stand a chance. Advancing in levels is difficult and takes a loooooot of game hours.

But the biggest problem is the lack of optimisation. Don't trust the system requirements listed on the store page. Chances are with that configuration that the game won't even start. At the time of writing, you need a hell of a gaming PC to event get medium settings without lag. My configuration:

Asus ROG G75-VW gaming laptop
Processor i7 @ 2,3Ghz
Video: nVidia Geforce GTX 670M 3GB
RAM: 12GB

Had a hard time playing with the constant stuttering on medium settings (which look pretty ugly). High settings is unplayable.

So, optimisation is non-existent. If you don't have a monster gameing PC, don't bother playing this game at it's curretn state.

Then there is a total lack of balance regarding gameplay. Food and water drop like crazy and you basically have to farm for resources the whole time. You have to tape down the use key and just move along the landscape to get by. Goat Simulator's Goat Z DLC was making fun of Survival games by having to eat every 10min. Now I know why...
For new players it is really difficult to advance, since every higher level player can kill you in a blink of an eye. The numerous creatures on the map will do that too, and you can't do anything about it. Running is not an option since everything will outrun you. Armor and weapons are not an option since you must advance in levels to learn to craft them. So you die and that's it. A couple of hours of gameplay thrown out the window and in vain. Not much fun in that,

In conclusion, until the game gets a serious optimisation fix and a total rebalance of it's gameplay, I would not advise anyone to buy it. It is a great idea and will surely become much more interesting in the future, but at it's current state, there was no fun in playing it, at least not for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is less a gameplay review than an overall quality review, so please bear that in mind when continuing forward.  In most cases where there have been negative recommendations it's usually been due to 'personal feelings' guiding the typist.  Although I do not hold any official title in the gaming world of critique, I do believe that the facts should be presented as they are, not as some would like to paint them after a 'Rage-Quit' moment.

***

To begin with, Ark: Survival Evolved is an EA(Early Access)game.  I'm well aware that for some this is an instant 'No-Go' decision and seeing as certain developers here on Steam have no problem allowing their tripe to continue to exist and therefore bilk unfair amounts of coin from the community, it's no wonder why this opinion currently exists.  However, despite some of the less than stellar entries tagged with the 'EA' moniker, I can truthfully say that this game has gone well beyond what many have grown accustomed to when buying into an 'EA' game as far as the current development speed and patches/hotfixes currently being displayed.

Within the first few weeks Ark was released on Steam those of us who took the chance and dove in were inundated with update patches on a schedule unheard of when dealing with the Early Access model.  Now I know from personal experience that a strong showing from a development team right out the gate does not a great game make, but the facts are easy enough to view for all that care to take 5 minutes out of their day.

This team seems to have waited a bit longer than others before releasing their 'EA' game and in so doing had a ton of content ready to greenlite out the chute from day 1.  The current ingame roster of creatures has easily doubled if not tripled from the original cast we had to work with as well as new tech trees adding logical upgrade paths and fan favorite suggestions to the Engram pool.  Couple that with their ever-present team committed to keeping the gaming community up to date with possible changes/additions, this particular instance may very well be the first time a Dev-Team got 'Early Access' right.

Now, have there been issues with players unable to get into the game?  Yes.  Did the developers take proper steps in creating patches/hotfixes to alleviate these issues?  Yes.  In fact, I was unable to play the game when it initially launched due to my apparent 'potato-system'.  Within a few weeks, though, there were new options the Dev team had included that allowed players like myself to use when starting up the game such as Low Memory: 4Gb"
date:
"Low Memory: No Sound" etc.

At one point there was even a real life reward being handed out by the Dev-Team to those of us that could prove a certain Selachimorpha was still able to be beached even after they hotfixed the issue out.  How many developers do you know are willing to do this?

The facts are available for anyone willing to look for them.  Since releasing back in June of 2015 there have been 132 patches/hotfixes to this game.  Those that bought into this game have been able to freely communicate with the Dev-Team Community reps and in doing so have seen their suggestions make it into the game.

The Long & Short of things is this: Simply put
recommended: "Ark: Survival Evolved" has risen past many if not all other 'EA' games currently available on Steam.  The Dev-Team has clearly demonstrated their passion towards the Survival genre as well as the Dino-love we all share from childhood.  The fact that they're able to join the 2 in a seamless union of awe inspiring moments such as the first time you see a Brontosaurus thundering across the land to the chilling terror of spotting a T-Rex sprinting out of the jungle towards you makes this game a definite top choice for those looking for a Dino-Survival game worth whiling away the hours online.\n\nWith all that said
hoursPlayed: it's one thing to be upset because you were griefed in some way while playing Ark
voteText: or chose to purchase an 'EA' game that you knew your Pc couldn't handle on Medium settings let alone Extreme.  As unfortunate as those issues are
helpfulPercent: these particular situations fall on you and shouldn't be held against the game in a negative manner.  Typing out a 'Thumbs Down' feedback here because of how some players treated you or because you had to struggle to get your Dorito-chipset desktop with its Etcha-Sketch display to run an unoptimized version of the game reaks of childish ignorance.  "Ark: Survival Evolved" is a game that's able to stand atop a steadfast platform of Dedication from the Dev-Team and Commitment to it's Community of supporters.  Let the facts speak for themselves when deciding on whether or not you want to purchase this game
votesHelpful: not the few irate gamers that allow their myopic viewpoints to dictate their final judgement.\n\n-Tyger"
votesTotal: March 18
votesFunny: true

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ark was way too much fun when I first started. I joined some of my friends that had played before and we hit the ground running. We built an awesome base, tamed some dinos, worked and worked. Then the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with the rockets showed up. Turns out they had been playing since launch and their past time was messing with new players because they have nothing better to do. They played with their food for a while, the food being my tribe. Eventually they just outright took everything we had and laughed.
My issue with this game is how fast you can lose things. I am 100% about a pvp sandbox survival game. I played eve for a good while. I like that knowing you can lose your work. It means it has value. However, this game you lose it way to quickly. You can build for days on end, then when you go to bed and come home from work the next day, its all gone.

The devs need to take a page out of Eve's book. In eve structures take a number of attacks to be destroyed. The game has reinforcement timers. When a structure's hp is brought to a certain threshhold it becomes immune for a day. During that time the corp that controls it can go repair it. A structure has to be brought into reinforcement multiple times before it is destroyed completely.

Having something like that would give a tribe a fighting chance against ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who wait for you to log off to blow up your base and kill the dinos that take 2 hours to tame with the kibble you spent a week working for.

The game is still unfinished and perhaps the devs will invest in this. At any rate if you're looking to buy this game right now, don't.

So here i am again with yet another review :steamhappy:

This game i have had my eye on for some time before i finally could no longer resist and had to buy this for myself. Ironically the game was available with 17% off for the whole time i had my eye on it and i ended up buying it at full price :P

So around 5 weeks ago there was a free weekend or something for this game, so i decided to jump on singleplayer and see if it is all its hyped up to be. Upon waking up naked on the beach it was immediatly obvious my graphics cards were not able to run the game smoothly at the maximum settings that my computer automatically sets so i turned all the graphics down to a minimum and started to explore. First thing i see is a Dodo on the beach so what do i do? I punch it in the face until it falls unconcious of course and it has a taming bar?? I'm like 'how do i tame it??'. Long story short i tame him and call him Bobo and eventually figure out how to make some basic tools and build a nice little thatch hut by the ocean with a campfire. Myself and Bobo the Dodo were then both eaten by a Raptor that literally made me jump out of my skin :P

I then went onto buy the game at full price and jumped straight onto a Public/Private server that is mainly used for a Twitch Livestreamer that i watch and had to start from scratch and i have to say that despite the fact that most players on the server are already established there i have had such a huge amount of fun playing Ark that i literally haven't touched another game since buying it. I think in the first 3 weeks i had managed to put in over 200 hours into the game primarily on the server that i play on, this is ontop of working upto 50 hours per week at my workplace which is just incredible. The only other games that have captured my attention this much ever in my entire life are World of Warcraft and Diablo 2 - both very different games but games that i may have put thousands of hours into.

As the game is in Alpha stages it is continuously changing so as of writing this review the game as you buy it consists of only one map that you can play on either singleplayer or on a server whether it be an Official Ark server or an Unofficial server. As i have stated above i personally so far have put in over 250 hours primarily into an Unofficial server and i could see myself very easily just on that server for thousands of hours to come.

However, this game does also have Steam Workshop content which allows for various mods to be downloaded such as different tools or building structures. There is currently one particular Workshop mod that has been made by one of the Developers that is known as a Total Conversion mod - meaning that it converts the game completely into a new mode. This Total Conversion mod is called 'Survival of the Fittest', and basically this mode is a Hunger Games style game mode where upto 100 players are dropped into a modified version of the standard Ark map. They start by dropping around a central circle with various loot in the centre such as spears, hatchets, pickaxes, bows, arrows, cooked meat and many other items and the last man standing or the last Tribe standing wins the game.

There are a whole tonne of changes in this game mode in order to balance it and speed up the levelling and make the whole game fast paced. On top of the standard changes to the game, there are various modifiyers that activate every 15 minutes that will either help you to survive for longer or hinder your survival. Such modifyers can be Mega Cold/Heat which are self explanatory and The Beast Within which makes all non aggressive Herbivores aggressive and all Carnivores  much more aggressive, and an example of a beneficial modifyer that can occur is Double Taming, which will of course allow you to tame any Dinosaur at double the speed.

So Survival of the Fittest is a huge separate game mode that i can see myself also putting in thousands of potential hours  despite this being a Workshop mod, i do hope when this game is finally released for those on console that this game mode is included in the game because it really is well made and watching some streamers playing this mode i have quite frequently been at the edge of my seat its so gripping and immersive with such tense moments. Also did i mention you can tame and fly a fire-breathing Dragon in this game mode??

All in all this review is probably already too long but i can't stress enough just how immersive this game is and its only in Alpha stages! There have often been multiple updates daily for various content or fixes and if you haven't already, you just need to buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ARK Survival Evolved is exciting, addictive survival game which has many features which just make you want to play more and more!
Although this is a brilliant constructed survival game packed with so many enjoyable things to do within it, it has some pretty nasty down sides to it too:

# Good things #
1. Creativity within the game is incredible with so many creatures/animals to tame
2. So many upgrades and objectives to complete you are always on the roll!
3. You can choose to play either by your self (Where you can change the settings e.g. taming time) or you can play online with your friends and create awesome clans/factions!
4. You can choose between PVE and PVP servers

# Bad things #
1. Many graphical errors/crashes, you need a good PC to run this game unfortunately
2. A MASSIVE time waster, meaning you need a LOT of time to do anything in this game as taming certain dinosaurs can take up to 24 hours to complete
3. Although this game is still going through updates/changes, there are still MAJOR glitches/bugs within the game
4. Online PVP or even PVE servers have one massive division between big clans and smaller clans, once a big clan has setup in a server, its very hard for smaller, newer clans to start building up.

Overall, this game does have amazing features and great potential, the disadvantages (bad things) are extremely bad and stop the player from playing sadly, this is why i will NOT recommend this game until future updates fix these unfortunate bugs/features.

Thats my review for ARK: Survival Evolved, i would like to point out that there are still big updates coming in the future which will hopefully fix the gitches/bugs and hopefully optimise the game. Please note you need a good PC to run this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While walking our new turtle home, my tribe-mate said it just disappeared. Seeing that it hadn't been killed we continued on, turtle-less and clueless.

The next day; my personal watercraft turtle, SeaDoo, disappeared. Not killed, just gone.

Two days later; more dinos gone.

A week later; all that remains is my prized Dodo, Slutt McNugget.

A week and 45 minutes later; Though he valiantly fought off the attackers, killing 12 of them in the battle, Slutt McNugget was slain. My beautifully deformed black man's body was savaged. Base destroyed.

A week and 2 hours later; Wisely having spec'd into nothing but melee damage, I tracked down and mercilessly killed all of The Butt Vikings who attacked. While questioning a few before castration I discovered that they too had encountered vanishing dinosaurs.

A week and 3 hours later; I dedicate myself to finding the source of lost dinos in ARK.



These disappearances and others like them are now known as, The Turtle Files.
5 minutes later; Game crashes for the last time. Uninstalled. Wrote a review.

I never played a PC game before. I saw Twitch videos of this game and thought, this looks like a game I imagined up. It has all the elements from the console games I loved with none of the drawbacks. Skyrim's open world, but not silly sidequests. The ability to build, but in a world worth building in.

There is so much the game needs to work on but they're working on it. The drawbacks are not greater than the perks. The ability to create this home" and community had been an incredible experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: Game is too unpolished, the online community is way too aggressive to newcomers but love the dinosaurs (them dinos, man, DINOS!)

I like this game, I really do, I've played it a lot, lately. But I would not recommend it in its current state, UNLESS you have a way to play on a private server and even then there's just too many issues.

Cons:
- The world is unbalanced, the dinos, the loot, the taming is not very proportionate to one another. (Ever try farming hide from a dilophosaurus vs. a dodo or a compy?)
- The world is empty; particularly single player could have benefited from some human NPCs (I realize it's meant to be played online with others but even the official servers wouldn't be worse for wear).
- The game could use some backstory or just story in general.
- The official servers are not properly policed leading to rampant hacking, 'noob-killing', Alpha Tribe 'bullyings' and other incidents which generally makes the game an unpleasant experience for many new-comers.
- It's a freaking killer for most systems, and the graphics are just not good enough to justify it (they're not bad, just not high enough to make such demands), the island also isn't large enough. It seems every patch pushes the system further rather than improving the performance.
- There are a LOT of glitches, bugs and technical annoyances, not least of which is the rubber banding (Oh GOD, the rubber banding! Make it stop, PLEASE!)

Pros:
- The world is really interesting to explore.
- The dinos (freaking love dinos, ever since 'Land Before Time', 'Dinotopia' (the books) and 'Jurassic Park', dinos FTW!)
- The game is a mix of Dinotopia and Minecraft, which sounds weird but is AWESOME!
- If you can get on a private server with some friends, the game is a ton of fun, when you band together to try and tame a Bronto or take on an Alpha.
- The dinos' appearance; a lot of detail went into this and it's exciting to try and find a dino with a distinctive pattern to tame.

In conclusion: The game can be a lot of fun but right now it has WAY to many issues, WAY too little oversight and is just generally unpolished for something they wish to release in June.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started out on a beach picking berries, getting some materials and explored the surroundings. Witin 5 minutes I got mauled by a Sabretooth but I went back at it. I've been zerged by dodo birds, munched on by megladon sharks, taleswiped by a Steganosaurus, almost stomped on by a huge brontosaurus. punched a pterodactyl and I've run from poison spitting raptors... yet I have stll to see a lot of creatures as this is about survival after all... so I'm working on my house.

There is nothing more cringeworthy than hearing a scorpion approching in the distance. The sound just makes my neckhair raise and run for the hills.

I fell in love with this game already when I watched the trailer on Youtube and I've been playing for the last three days non stop. I must say I'm quite impressed that this is so awesome already in the Alphastage. I don't see myself playing anything else ever...

I used to pray I live 50 more years just so I could see where Game of Thrones and technology goes. Right now I just want to spend 50 years in this jurrasic world of Ark. It's pure awesomeness... Get your snack on and try out this gorgeous game. Farm farm farm, run run run and hide... All you need to know is that you don't have to outrun a dino, just make sure you're ahead of another living thing and you'll be fine.

PS. Don't be surprised if your building is damaged when you wake up as T-Rexes and other nasty creatures comes along at night when you're sleeping. Get some guard dogs". A great game to play with friends.

There is only one downer with the game. Each server takes 70 people so it's full at times but just keep on trying to get back in 'cause there is always someone getting annoyed over getting killed that takes a break which opens a spot for you.

I can't state enough how much I have fallen for this world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Among the many games I've played in my 20+ years of gaming, this is by far the most enjoyable and most memorable experiance I have ever had. This game is offering an immense amount of content for it's early release build, it's being updated weekly as we speek!

Fulfilling my childhood dream of being able to ride a dinosaur finally came to fruition. The first parasaur I successfully tamed (named Ducky ;) helped out a ton for starting fresh on the server. Unfortionatly she died by a carno when I logged on the next morning... was a bit heart broken.

Working alongside tribe members to overcome monumental tasks (such as preparing to raid a giant base filled with baddies) is thrilling when everyone does their part.

However, the one big downside I'm not a fan of in this how people harass lower level players (kind of like high school bullies) and consistantly get away with it. Starting fresh in this game is rough. I would recommend seeking help from a tribe, as long as you're willing to contribute. This brings me to my next point...

From a personal experiance of starting fresh on a normal official server recently, I felt like I didn't belong to the tribe I was in. They already had an incredible base, tons of dinos, tons of defenses, and so on. I could have helped out, but it's hard to find a place to belong when most people (including tribe members) frown upon low leveled players. Very disheartening.

If you can overcome the learning curve of this game and see it through to the high level content (and possibly get revenge on those that does harassment daily), you will be in for a huge treat.

As it stands right now, I would recommend this game to anyone that can run it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first bought the game I was very disappointed because my computer wasn't the best at high graphic games such as this. But since the releases of the patches and the team working hard on releasing optimization and tweaks on performance, I have no doubt in my mind this is by far the best dino game ever!!! The content they release on a weekly basis is amazing. There are so many things you can do and I never get bored. I'm always either gathering meat and berries for my dinos, upgrading my building or exploring. Dino taming is really awesome, I can now fulfill my dream as being a raptor tamer ;p

For a newbie this game should be very easy to figure out and eventually you'll be on your way to becoming dino master :p
There are tons of servers for everyone to play on official and unofficial. You will not be disappointed on spending your money on this game!!

UPDATE 2/24/16

To give an update on the review I wrote previously. Ark is one of those games you keep coming back too. Whilst I don't play as much as I used too, I still really like this game. I even finished my computer build, which makes this game even perform better. This game obviously isn't made to perform at its best on low end laptops. But you can still manage to play in the mean time. Since completing my computer, I can say this is a whole brand new game to me and I really appreciate the hard work the devs put into the graphics!! :)

I like that the devs put a hold on dino dossiers and decided to work on the backlog of creatures they still need to put in the game. The devs are amazing and really listen to what the community wants and thinks about there game. There is always being something posted and fixes for bugs come out almost immediately, which is better then most games out there.
